Sec. 4-39. - Abandoned vehicles. 
(a)  Defined. For the purpose of this section, the term "abandoned motor vehicle" means a motor vehicle that is inoperable and is left unattended on public property for more than 48 hours, or a motor vehicle that has remained illegally on private property without the consent of the owner or person in control of the property for more than 48 hours, or a motor vehicle on private property that is inoperable and on which no repair or attempt to make it operable is being made. 
(b)  Authority of housing inspector. The housing inspector shall have the authority and jurisdiction over the removal of abandoned vehicles, whether on public or private property, according to this section. 
(1)  Twenty-day notice of violation. Twenty days' written notice shall be given to the owner of the property where the vehicle is located (with a copy to the owner of the vehicle, if known) to license, repair or remove same, and a copy of such notice shall be posted on the vehicle. 
(2)  Procedure upon noncompliance with violation notice. If the terms of the notice are not complied with within the 20-day period as provided, the housing inspector shall then have power and authority to physically remove the vehicle by towing or otherwise moving it to an open storage area maintained by the city, where the vehicle shall remain for at least 60 days. 
(3)  Public notice by city of possession; reclamation. During the 60-day period the vehicle shall remain posted and the housing inspector shall publish at least one notice in a local newspaper, identifying the vehicle by make, year, model, serial number, color and owner's name (if known), stating that such vehicle will be permanently disposed of unless reclaimed by the owner within 60 days. During the 60-day period the owner shall be entitled to reclaim the vehicle by furnishing the city sufficient proof that the vehicle will be licensed or repaired, or both, as the case may require, and by paying to the city its towing charge, cost of notice and storage charge, if any. 
(4)  Application for authority to dispose of unclaimed vehicle required. If the vehicle is not reclaimed within the 60 days, the housing inspector shall apply to the police department for authority to sell, give away or dispose of the vehicle to a scrap processor or wrecker. 
(5)  Contents of application to dispose of unclaimed vehicle. The application shall set out the year, make, model and serial number of the motor vehicle, if ascertainable, together with any other identifying features, and shall contain a concise statement of the facts surrounding the abandonment of the vehicle, and the housing inspector shall execute an affidavit stating that the facts alleged therein are true and that no material fact has been withheld. 
(6)  Authorization by police to dispose of vehicle; certificate to serve in lieu of title. If the police department finds that the application is executed in proper form and shows that the motor vehicle has been abandoned, it shall give the housing inspector a certificate of authority to sell the motor vehicle to any wrecker or scrap processor for demolition, wrecking or dismantling. The wrecker or scrap processor shall accept such certificate in lieu of the certificate of title to the motor vehicle. 
(7)  Special provision for vehicles in excess of eight years old. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, the housing inspector is authorized to dispose of the abandoned vehicle to a wrecker or scrap processor without the title or police certificate if the vehicle is over eight years old and has no engine or is otherwise totally inoperable. 
(Ord. No. 768, § 1, 8-1-91; Ord. No. 843, 6-30-97; Ord. No. 962, 9-28-98) 
Cross reference- Removal of abandoned vehicles by health officer, § 8-18; junkyards, § 10-4; motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 11. 
Sec. 4-39A. - Inoperable vehicles. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this article is to prevent the accumulation of inoperable motor vehicles, or parts thereof, in unapproved and inappropriate locations throughout the city of Cambridge, to the extent that they constitute an unsightly, obnoxious and unsanitary condition. The presence of such motor vehicles constitutes a condition detrimental to the general well being of the citizens of the city, and is hereby declared a public nuisance. Therefore, this article is adopted for the preservation of health, safety and general public welfare, by implementing and enforcing adequate regulations concerning inoperable motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers which require property owners, tenants, occupants or lessees to remove the same from their premises. 
(b)  Definitions. For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings: 
(1)  Inoperable motor vehicle. Any motor vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer which is not in operating condition, or does not display valid license plates; or displays a license plat and decal which has been expired for more than 60 days. 
(2)  Private property. Any area which is not owned by the federal, state or local government or any instrumentality, agency or political subdivision thereof. 
(3)  Trailer or semi-trailer. Every vehicle without motive power designed for carrying property or passengers, wholly on its own structure and for being pulled by a motor vehicle. 
(4)  Person. Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or location of any kind, whether such person is the owner, tenant, lessee or occupant of private or public property. 
(5)  Shielded or screened. Completely precluding visibility of the subject vehicle from view by a solid, rigid, opaque fence or other improvement. All fencing shall comply with current zoning regulations of the city. 
(c)  Prohibition. 
(1)  Generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, except within a fully enclosed building or structure, on any property within the city of Cambridge, any inoperable motor vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer. 
(2)  Exceptions. This section shall not apply to a licensed business which is regularly engaged in business as an automobile dealer, salvage dealer, commercial garage, auto repair facility or state certified school which train and/or teach auto repair. 
(d)  Authority to remove inoperable vehicles. The commissioners of Cambridge, through its agents or employees, may remove any such inoperable motor vehicle, trailer, or semi-trailer, whenever the owner of the premises, after 15 days' advance written notice, has failed to remove such vehicle from his/her property. 
(e)  Notice. The city shall provide 15 days' written notice to the owner of the property where the vehicle is located. Such notice shall be sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, and shall be mailed to the last known address of such owner, as shown on the current real estate assessment records/books of the city. Such notice shall state that the owner shall have 15 days to license or repair the vehicle so as to bring it into compliance with this section, or to remove the vehicle. Said 15-day notice period shall begin on the date of actual receipt by the owner, or five days after the date of mailing such notice, whichever shall first occur. A copy of such notice shall be posted on the vehicle and a copy shall be sent to the owner of the vehicle, if known to the city. The notice shall also state that the failure of the property owner to respond to the notice shall constitute an admission by the owner that the vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer was located on his/her property with his/her permission and therefore, does not constitute an "abandoned vehicle." In the event that the owner of the inoperable vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer cannot be determined by investigation through the state motor vehicle administration or the comparable agency of the state in which such vehicle or trailer is registered, or if same cannot be reasonably ascertained from the inoperable motor vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer, or if same cannot be reasonably obtained from the owner of the property from which it was removed, then no such additional notice to the owner of the motor vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer shall be required. 
(f)  Removal by city. The city is authorized to remove such inoperable vehicle. In the event that the owner of the property fails to remove the inoperable vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer within the 15 days' notice period, the city, through its agents or employees, may remove any such inoperable vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer pursuant to the provisions of this section, and may dispose of such vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer as follows: 
(1)  For vehicles, trailers or semi-trailers which are not "abandoned vehicles" as defined in section 4-39, the city, through its agents or subcontractors shall remove the vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer to an authorized vehicle storage or scrap processing facility, which has been approved by the city. The city shall give the property owner, and any known secured party of the vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer, notice that the vehicle has been removed pursuant to this section, and shall give the location of the facility where the vehicle is being stored. Said notice shall be made within seven days from the date of removal of the vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer. The notice shall also state that the owner and secured party shall have 21 days to reclaim the vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer, by payment of all towing, preservation and storage fees and charges resulting from the removal. The notice shall also state that the failure of the owner or secured party to exercise its right to reclaim the vehicle shall constitute a waiver of their right, title and interest in the vehicle, trailer, or semi-trailer, and shall constitute their consent to the disposal of the vehicle either as scrap metal or to its sale at public auction, in the sole discretion of the city. 
(2)  For vehicles, trailer or semi-trailers which are not titled in the name of the property owner and which have remained illegally on private property for more than 48 hours without the consent of the property owner, then such vehicles, trailers or semi-trailers shall constitute "abandoned vehicles" and shall be removed pursuant to section 4-39 hereinabove, and pursuant to sections 25-201, et seq., as amended, of the Transportation Article of the Annotated Code of Maryland. 
(g)  Disposal of vehicle. In the event that inoperable vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer is not an "abandoned vehicle" as defined hereinabove, then the city, in its sole and absolute discretion may elect to sell the vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer at public auction, or may elect to dispose of the vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer, as scrap metal. 
(h)  Assessment of costs. The cost of any such removal and disposal shall be chargeable to the owner of the inoperable motor vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer, or the owner of the property from which such inoperable motor vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer was removed, and may be collected by the city in the same manner as taxes and levies are collected, and shall constitute a lien on the property in the same manner and effect as taxes, and shall accrue interest at the same rate as taxes. Any amount which may be realized by the city from the sale of any such inoperable motor vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer, shall be applied to such costs. 
(i)  Failure to respond. The failure of the property owner to respond to the notice from the city shall constitute an admission by the property owner that the vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer was on his or her property with his or her permission, and therefore, shall not constitute an "abandoned vehicle." 
(j)  Extension for good cause shown. The owner of the property or vehicle may make application to the housing board of review for an extension of the period for maintaining an inoperable vehicle on property within the city of Cambridge. Such extension may only be granted for good cause shown, and shall not exceed a period of one year. 
(k)  Penalty for violation. In addition to the remedies set forth hereinabove, any person who shall violate this section shall be deemed guilty of an infraction, the fine for which shall be $100.00, and every day that the violation continues, after due notice prescribed herein, shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 900, 1-28-02; Ord. No. 921, 1-13-03) 
Sec. 4-39B. - Storage of vehicles. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this article is to prevent the excessive accumulation and storage of motor vehicles, or parts thereof, in approved and licensed impound yards and automobile repair and assembly businesses throughout the city of Cambridge, for the protection of the public health, safety and general welfare. The presence of excessive motor vehicles constitutes a condition detrimental to the general well being of the citizens of the city, and is hereby declared a public nuisance. Therefore, this article is adopted for the preservation of health, safety and general public welfare, by implementing and enforcing adequate regulations concerning the storage of motor vehicles. 
(b)  Prohibition. 
(1)  Automobile repair and assembly businesses. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, on any property within the city, more than 50 motor vehicles stored on property as an accessory use for an approved automobile repair service or automobile assembly business. 
(2)  Licensed impound yards. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, on any property within the city, more than 50 motor vehicles stored on property approved and licensed for an impound yard. 
(c)  Prohibitions mutually exclusive. The prohibitions as set forth above are mutually exclusive. Therefore, a person who lawfully operates a licensed automobile and assembly business, and a licensed impound yard may store up to 100 motor vehicles. 
(d)  Authority to remove inoperable vehicles. The commissioners of Cambridge, through its agents or employees, may, but shall not be required to, remove any such motor vehicles in excess of the number permitted by this section, pursuant to the same procedures as set forth in section 4-39A, which procedures are incorporated herein by reference. 
(e)  Penalty for violation. In addition to the remedies set forth hereinabove, any person who shall violate this section shall be deemed guilty of an infraction, the fine for which shall be $100.00 per vehicle in excess of the permitted number, and every day that the violation continues, after due notice prescribed herein, shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 904, 7-29-02) 
Sec. 4-40. - Roominghouses. 
A.  Compliance with article. All roominghouses, hotels and motels operated in the city shall be subject to the provisions of this article. 
B.  Rooms to be numbered. All rooming units shall be numbered in a plain and conspicuous manner, with the numbers to be placed on the outside of the door, and no two doors shall bear the same number. 
C.  Bed linens and towels. The operator of every roominghouse shall change supplied bed linens and towels therein at least once each week, and prior to the letting of any room to any occupant. The operator shall be responsible for the maintenance of all supplied bedding in a clean and sanitary manner. 
D.  Cleanliness of premises. The operator of every roominghouse shall keep the same and every part thereof clean and free from any accumulation of dirt, filth, rubbish, garbage or similar matter and shall keep the same free from and effectively protected against vermin and rodent infestation. 
E.  Heating facilities. Heating in all roominghouses shall comply with the provisions of section PM 602.0 et seq. of the BOCA National Property Maintenance Code/1996. 
F.  Light and ventilation. Light and ventilation in all roominghouses shall comply with the provisions of sections PM 403.0 et seq. and PM 404.0 et seq. of the BOCA National Property Maintenance Code/1996. 
G.  Basement occupancy. No rooming unit, bathroom or toilet room serving a rooming unit shall be located in any basement unless it complies with the following provisions: 
(a)  The floor and walls are impervious to leakage of underground and surface runoff water and are well drained and protected against dampness. 
(b)  The total window area in each room is not less than five percent of the floor area of the room as measured between stops and is entirely above the grade of the ground adjoining each window area. 
(c)  The total openable window area of each habitable room is 45 percent of the required window area. 
(d)  All heating equipment or other equally hazardous equipment is separated from the dwelling unit. 
(e)  Access can be gained to the unit without passage through a furnace room. No cellar space shall be used as a habitable room of a dwelling unit. 
H.  Space and occupancy. Space and occupancy in all roominghouses shall comply with the provisions of section 405.0 et seq. of the BOCA National Property Maintenance Code/1996. 
I.  Bathing facilities. Every dwelling unit in any roominghouse shall contain, within a room which affords privacy, a bathtub or shower in good working condition, which shall be properly connected to both hot and cold water lines and to the public sanitary sewer facility or to an approved sewage disposal system. Such bathing facility shall be within and accessible from within the dwelling unit. 
    Every roominghouse shall contain, within a room which affords privacy, at least one bathtub or shower for each eight persons or fraction thereof who are occupants of rooming units. Such bathtub or shower shall be in good working condition and shall be properly connected to both hot and cold water lines and to the public sanitary sewer or to an approved sewage disposal system. Where such bathtub or shower facility is not provided within the rooming unit, it shall be within and accessible from within the building from a common hall and not more than one story removed from the rooming unit intended to be served by such facility. 
    The floor of any such room shall be made impervious to water to prevent structural deterioration and any development of unsanitary conditions. 
J.  Sinks. Sinks in every dwelling unit in all roominghouses shall comply with the provisions of section PM 506.0 et seq. of the BOCA National Property Maintenance Code/1996. 
K.  Toilet facilities. Every dwelling unit in any roominghouse shall contain, within a room which affords privacy, a water closet and a lavatory basin in good working condition, which shall be properly connected to the public sanitary sewer or to an approved sewage disposal system. Such water closet and lavatory basin shall be within and accessible from within the dwelling unit. The lavatory basin shall be properly connected to a cold water line. The facilities shall be in addition to those required for rooming units. 
    Every roominghouse shall contain, within a room which affords privacy, at least one water closet and at least one lavatory basin for each eight persons or fraction thereof who are occupants of rooming units. Such water closet and lavatory basin shall be in good working condition and shall be properly connected to the public sanitary sewer or to an approved sewage disposal system. The lavatory basin shall be properly connected to both hot and cold water lines and the water closet shall be properly connected to a cold water line. Where such water closet and lavatory basin facilities are not provided within the rooming unit, they shall be within and accessible from within the building from a common hall and not more than one story removed from the rooming unit intended to be served by such facilities. 
L.  Water heating facilities. Water heating facilities in all roominghouses shall comply with the provisions of section PM 506.4 of the BOCA National Property Maintenance Code/1996. 
M.  Plumbing installation and maintenance. All plumbing, water closets and other plumbing fixtures in every roominghouse shall be installed and maintained in good working condition and repair and in accordance with the requirements of the BOCA National Building Code/1996, chapter 29. 
N.  Cooking. Cooking is prohibited in any rooming unit. An occupant of a rooming unit shall not prepare meals in any shared or public areas of the roominghouse or the premises thereof. 
O.  Garbage and trash disposal. Every roominghouse shall be provided, in a location accessible to all rooming units, with an adequate number of receptacles to contain all garbage, rubbish and ashes that may accumulate during the usual interval between the collections thereof. All such receptacles shall be maintained at all times in good order and repair. Receptacles shall be made of watertight metal and provided with handles and tight covers and/or those approved by the department of public works. 
P.  Entrance and egress. There shall be for each rooming unit a separate access either to a hallway, landing, stairway or street. Every rooming unit shall have safe, unobstructed means of egress leading to safe and open space at ground level as required by this article and other ordinances of the city. 
Q.  Lighting of halls and stairs. Lighting of public halls and stairways on all roominghouses shall comply with the provisions of section PM 403.2 of the BOCA National Property Maintenance Code/1996. 
R.  Posting of regulations. It is a requirement of this article that a copy of this section be posted in all rooming units within the city. 
S.  Violation; penalties. Any violations of the provisions enumerated in this section shall be subject to the penalties provided for in section 4-34 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 768, § 1, 8-1-91; Ord. No. 843, 6-30-97; Ord. No. 962, 9-28-98) 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, ch. 8. 
Sec. 4-41. - Amendment of section PM 501.2, Responsibility. 
    Section PM 501.2, entitled "Same-Responsibility," of the BOCA National Property Maintenance Code/1996 is amended to read as follows: 
    Sec. PM 501.2. Same-Responsibility. The owner of the structure shall provide and maintain such plumbing facilities and fixtures in compliance with these requirements. A person shall not occupy as owner-occupant or let to another for occupancy or use any structure or portion thereof or premises which does not comply with the following requirements of this article. 
    In the event that any water lines or plumbing fixtures are damaged by freezing weather or other act, it shall be the responsibility of the owner to promptly repair them, and, in the case of water lines, failure to promptly repair may result in the municipal utilities commission entering upon the premises to so repair, the cost of which shall be a lien against the property. 
(Ord. No. 768, § 1, 8-1-91; Ord. No. 843, 6-30-97; Ord. No. 962, 9-28-98) 
Sec. 4-42. - Registration of non-owner occupied residential dwelling units. 
(a)  By September 30, 2011 and on each September 30 annually thereafter, every owner of a non-owner occupied residential dwelling unit shall file a registration statement with the city's designated department ("department") for each such dwelling unit on a form to be provided by the department. Notification of the annual registration and registration fee will be mailed by the city in July of each year. 
(b)  For each such non-owner occupied residential dwelling unit, there shall be an annual registration fee as established by resolution duly approved by the Commissioners of Cambridge, to be paid at the time the owner files the annual registration statement. For any two-family dwelling or multiple-unit dwelling the registration fee shall apply to each individual residential dwelling unit within the structure. 
(c)  Any person becoming an owner of such a dwelling unit shall file a registration statement on the date of the property transfer; however, the new owner will not have to pay the registration fee until the next September 30 registration date if the previous owner had registered the property and paid the registration fee. In the event that a registration fee was not paid, then the new owner shall be required to register the unit an pay the registration fee at the time he/she acquired ownership. 
(d)  The registration statement shall contain the following information: 
(1)  A description of the premises by street number or otherwise, in such manner as to enable the code official to find the same. 
(2)  The name and address of the owner of record and of the managing operator if other than the owner; and, in addition, if the owner is a corporation, the name and address of the resident agent thereof. If the owner is a partnership or other business entity, the statement shall further include the name and address and position of a responsible partner or officer. 
(3)  Designation of a resident agent. If the owner does not reside within Dorchester County or 40 miles of the city, the owner shall designate a resident agent defined as follows: a natural person 18 years of age or older who resides within the designated boundaries of Dorchester County, Maryland, or within 40 miles of the city, who is designated by the owner as his authorized agent for receiving notices of violations, for receiving court process on behalf of such owner in connection with the enforcement of ordinances relating to such units, and for notification of emergency conditions or repairs. For purposes of this subsection a physical address is required; a post office box does not suffice as an address. The department must be notified within 30 days of any change in the name or address of the designated agent. Where the owner has failed to notify the department of a new authorized agent or has failed to file a new registration statement by September 30 of any year as required, service of violation notices and court process on the last registered authorized agent shall be legal and sufficient service on any other until the department is notified of any change. 
(4)  Such other information as may be prescribed by the department from time to time. 
(e)  Exemptions. The following property owners are expressly exempt from the registration requirements set forth herein: 
(1)  Owners of bed and breakfasts, provided all licensing fees as required by section 20-15C of the city's zoning code are paid and not in arrears; said exemption shall apply to the structure which is being used as the bed and breakfast; and 
(2)  Any person who resides on a property, in which he or she is vested with a deeded interest, including a life interest or remainder interest, and which deed is of record among the Land Records for Dorchester County, Maryland. 
(f)  Any violation of the provisions of this section shall constitute a municipal infraction, the fine for which shall be $100.00, and every day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. Any owner of a residential unit who shall fail to file a registration statement as required by this section shall be liable for said fine without notice. 
(g)  Pursuant to section 1-9(b) of this Code, the commissioners hereby designate the director of public works, the city code enforcement officers, or the director of the municipal utilities commission as the code enforcement officials authorized by the commissioners to issue citations for infractions hereof. The commissioners hereby designate the director of the municipal utilities commission as the official of the city responsible for the billing and collection of all rental registration fees. All charges and fees due to the city for rental registration fees, shall be collected by the director of the municipal utilities commission in the same manner as unpaid water and sewer charges and trash disposal charges, pursuant to section 18-16. Furthermore, all unpaid rental registration fees shall be collected in the manner as taxes. 
(h)  The dollar amount of the annual registration fee may only be amended by ordinance duly approved by the commissioners of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1006, 2-28-11; Ord. No. 1084, 6-20-16) 
Editor's note- Prior to the reenactment of § 4-42 by Ord. No. 1006, said section was repealed by Ord. No. 995, adopted June 21, 2010. The former § 4-42 pertained to registration of rental units and derived from Ord. No. 800, adopted Nov. 8, 1993; Ord. No. 843, adopted June 30, 1997; Ord. No. 962, adopted Sept. 28, 1998; Ord. No. 871, adopted Aug. 30, 1999; and Ord. No. 924, adopted July 19, 2004. 
Sec. 4-43. - Boarding of structures. 
(a)  The owner of a structure within the city, who desires to board up the structure, shall first obtain a boarding permit from the city. 
(b)  The owner of a structure within the city, which structure is boarded up at the time of the adoption of this section, shall obtain a boarding permit within 60 days of the adoption of this section, and shall comply with the terms and provisions of this section in the same manner as if the structure had not been boarded at the time of adoption. 
(c)  All boarding of structures shall comply with the standards as set forth on Exhibit A "Boarding Standards" attached to Ordinance No. 999 and incorporated herein by reference. 
(d)  Boarding permits shall be valid for a period of six months from the date of issuance, and may only be renewed for one additional six-month term, which renewal shall only be granted pursuant to a formal appeal therefore being made to the housing board of review. The housing board of review may only grant a renewal upon a showing by the owner that strict compliance is not possible due to financial hardship. 
(e)  Upon the expiration of the boarding permit, the boarding of the windows and doors shall be removed, and the entire exterior of the structure shall be brought into full compliance with the applicable requirements of the city's property maintenance code, residential code and/or building code. 
(f)  Exemption. 
(1)  The temporary boarding of windows or doors shall be permitted without the issuance of a permit, where the boarding is required to secure a broken window or door of an inhabited or occupied structure. Such temporary boarding shall not exceed 30 days in duration. 
(2)  The initial boarding of a structure immediately following a fire or act of God which causes significant damage to the property, may be undertaken by the owner without the issuance of a permit, in order to secure the property and eliminate risks to public health and safety. In such event, the owner shall have 72 hours from the date of the damaging event, to obtain a boarding permit and to bring the boarding of the structure into compliance with the boarding standards adopted by the city. 
(g)  The fee for the boarding permit shall be shall be as established by the commissioners of the city by resolution from time to time. 
(h)  Violations of this section shall constitute a municipal infraction and be subject to applicable penalties under the City Code in addition to those imposed by any other applicable code or ordinance, including, without limitation, the city's property maintenance code, residential code, and/or building code. 
(Ord. No. 999, 6-21-10) 
Cross reference- Boarding of residential structures, § 4-70 et seq. 
Sec. 4-44. - Regulation of bamboo. 
Sec. 4-44.1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: 
    Bamboo. Any monopodial (running) tropical or semi-tropical grasses from the genera Bambusa including, but not limited to Bambusa, Phyllostachys, and Pseudosasa as well as Common Bamboo, Golden Bamboo and Arrow Bamboo. 
    Bamboo owner. Any property owner or resident who has planted and/or grows bamboo, or who maintains bamboo on the property, or who permits bamboo to grow or remain on the property even if the bamboo has spread from an adjoining property. Any property owner or resident at which bamboo is found on the property will be considered a bamboo owner, except any property owner or resident who: 
(a)  Did not plant or grow or cause bamboo to be planted or grown on his property, and 
(b)  Has provided satisfactory proof to the city that, within a reasonable period of time after discovering the encroachment of bamboo onto the property from an adjoining or neighboring property, he advised the owner of such property of his objection to the encroachment of the bamboo, and 
(c)  Has initiated steps for the removal of the bamboo from the property, including remedies at law. 
    City. The City of Cambridge, Maryland, a Maryland Municipal Corporation. 
(Ord. No. 1028, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 4-44.2. - Applicability. 
    For purposes of this section, bamboo found growing upon a property shall constitute presumptive evidence that the bamboo was planted and/or grown by and/or with the consent of the bamboo owner. 
(Ord. No. 1028, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 4-44.3. - Prohibition. 
    Upon the effective date of this section, the planting or growing of bamboo shall be prohibited within the city. Any person who thereafter plants or grows, or causes to be planted or grown, bamboo within the city, shall be deemed to be in violation of this section, and shall be subject to such penalties as are set forth hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 1028, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 4-44.4. - Regulation. 
    Any bamboo that has been planted or otherwise permitted to grow on any property within the city, prior to the effective date of this section, may remain on such property subject to compliance with the following: 
(a)  Bamboo shall not be planted, maintained or otherwise be permitted to exist within 25 feet of the edge of the pavement or traveled portion of any public roadway, public right-of-way or public sidewalk; 
(b)  Any bamboo owner whose property contains bamboo shall remove and abate the growth of the bamboo within 25 feet of the edge of the pavement or traveled portion of a public roadway, public right-of-way or public sidewalk; 
(c)  Bamboo shall not be planted, maintained or otherwise permitted to grow or encroach upon an adjoining property in the city; 
(d)  Each bamboo owner shall be responsible to ensure that the bamboo planted or growing on the property prior to the effective date of this section does not encroach upon or grow onto, or within 25 feet of any adjoining public roadway, public right-of-way or public sidewalk; 
(e)  Each bamboo owner shall be responsible to ensure that the bamboo planted or growing on the property prior to the effective date of this section does not encroach or grow upon, any adjoining or neighboring property or properties in the city; 
(f)  Each bamboo owner shall be required to take such measures as are reasonably expected to prevent such bamboo from invading, encroaching upon or growing onto adjoining or neighboring properties, unless both adjoining property owners enter into a written agreement in recordable form, in which each property owner consents to the planting and encroachment of the bamboo onto his/her property. Such measures may include, but not be limited to: (1) installation of sheathing comprised of metal or other material impenetrable by bamboo at a sufficient depth, but not less than 30 inches in depth, where the running bamboo is planted or is growing to prevent the growth onto or encroachment upon adjoining or neighboring property by the bamboo; or (2) any other legal method which effectively prevents the growth onto or encroachment upon adjoining or neighboring property by the bamboo. 
(Ord. No. 1028, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 4-44.5. - Removal, repair and compliance. 
    When it has been determined by the city that any bamboo plant or root is encroaching on the property of an adjacent or abutting landowner, or public way, the city shall, prior to taking any other action to enforce compliance with this Ordinance, give written notice to the person or legal entity causing such condition to exist, which notice shall: 
(1)  Specify the nature and location of the violation; 
(2)  Provide notice of the need to remove and/or to begin taking corrective action to abate such condition within 30 days from the effective date of such notice; 
(3)  Require that the removal and/or correction of such condition includes: 
a.  The removal and eradication of any bamboo plant or root from any adjoining or nearby lot or public way to which it has spread from its original planting site, and the correction and repair of any property damage sustained to said adjoining or nearby lot or public way, in removing such bamboo; and 
b.  The containment of the bamboo plant causing said encroachment, by mandatory and full compliance with this section; 
(4)  State that upon failure to comply with the notice and order for removal and/or containment, the city may enter upon the property to abate the violation by removing and eradicating the bamboo upon the land of any nearby or abutting property owner, public way and/or upon the property of the person or entity planting or causing such bamboo to grow, as provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 1028, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 4-44.6. - Abatement of bamboo violation. 
(a)  If the violation is not remedied within the time set forth in the notice and order as outlined above, the city is hereby authorized, but not required, to enter upon the property to remove or have removed any encroaching bamboo and to take all reasonable steps to eradicate its re-growth from said adjacent or nearby property or public way, and to reasonably restore any such lands to its natural condition prior to such removal and eradication. 
(b)  The city shall also be authorized, but not required, to enter upon the property to remove and eradicate the plant causing the encroachment, upon the responsible party's failure to properly contain the plant after notice. 
(c)  The cost of corrective action taken by the city shall be billed to the property owner whose property was the source of the bamboo encroachment. 
(d)  If the charges assessed by the city for removal or eradication of the bamboo are not paid within 30 days from date of billing, then the city, after having abated the deficiency and violation, shall place its charges and expenses as a municipal lien against said property, which charges and expenses shall be collected the same as real property taxes. 
(Ord. No. 1028, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 4-44.7. - Replanting prohibited. 
    Any bamboo either planted or caused to be planted or existing on a property prior to the effective date of this section may not be replanted or replaced in kind once such bamboo is or has become, for any reason, dead, destroyed, uprooted or otherwise removed. 
(Ord. No. 1028, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 4-44.8. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any property owner or possessor of a property determined to have violated this article shall be subject to pay a fine in the amount of $100.00 per day, that the violation persists; the responsible party shall also be liable for all court costs, legal fees and other fees incurred by the city to enforce this article against the responsible party. Each day of a continuing violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1028, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 4-45. - Portable on-demand storage units ("PODs"). 
(a)  Portable on-demand storage units or PODs: 
(1)  Defined. Portable containers that are placed on or, in very limited circumstances, in front and/or side yards of a property, for the purpose of storing, loading, unloading furniture, clothing or other personal or household belongings as part of the process of renovation or moving, the relocation of belongings to an off-site commercial storage location, or on-site storage in the aftermath of the property being affected by a natural disaster, fire or other destructive act. Portable storage units shall be no larger than 8' × 8' × 16'. 
(2)  Residential properties only. Portable on-demand storage units are permitted in accordance with the regulations set forth herein, only on the following types of occupied property primarily used for residential purposes: Single-family detached dwellings, single family semi-detached dwellings (duplexes), and single family attached dwellings (townhomes). The regulations and provisions set forth herein are not applicable to the use of storage trailers used on commercial properties, industrial properties or other non-residential properties. 
(b)  Portable on-demand storage units (PODs) regulated. 
(1)  Location. Portable on-demand storage units ("PODs") are prohibited from being placed on an unpaved area in the front yard of a property, without the prior written approval of the permitting official, building official or code enforcement officer. PODs kept on-site must be kept in the driveway or paved, off-street surface on the property at the furthest accessible point from the street. Where possible the POD unit shall be placed on a paved surface to the rear or side of the principal structure. When placed on the driveway or paved area in side or rear yard, POD units shall be located at least three feet from any property line, and at least ten feet from any occupied residential structure. In no event shall PODs be placed in the street or on any public sidewalk or right-of-way, without the prior written approval of the permitting official and the authorized member of the Cambridge Police Department. Only one POD may be placed on a residential property at any given time, subject to exceptions set forth below for natural disasters. 
In the event that the only practical location for the placement of the POD is in the street, or on a public sidewalk or right-of-way, then in such event, the proposed placement of the POD must be reviewed and approved by the Cambridge Police Department and the permitting official to assure that said placement does not jeopardize the public's health and safety. 
(2)  Time limitation. A POD unit may remain on a property for 60 days in one twelve-month period, with up to one 30-day extension pursuant to the permitting provisions set forth below for good cause shown. Absent an emergency condition or natural disaster as set forth in item no. (3) below, in no event shall a POD remain on a property in excess of 90 days in one 12-month period. 
(3)  Use during natural disaster. The above restrictions notwithstanding, when the principal structure on the property has been made uninhabitable as a result of a natural disaster for which a local state of emergency declaration has been issued, or a fire or other damaging event beyond the control of the owner, one or more POD units may be used for on-site storage. The authorization for such use shall be dependent upon issuance of a building permit for the reconstruction/repair of the principal structure(s) on the property and shall expire upon issuance of a certificate of occupancy for the principal structure(s) or 12 months from the date of the event that caused damage to the structure, whichever first occurs. For good cause shown, and to recognize extenuating circumstances, the permitting official, building official or code enforcement officer may extend the authorization for as much as an additional 12-month period or until a certificate of occupancy is issued, whichever first occurs. 
(4)  Advertising prohibited. Advertising is prohibited on a POD unit, with the exception of the name and telephone number of the unit's supplier, which shall be required. 
(5)  Hazard materials prohibited. The use of PODs for storage of hazardous materials is strictly prohibited. 
(6)  Condition of PODs. All PODs shall be maintained in good condition and repair, and shall not have holes, breaks, tears, or large areas of rust on the exterior of the POD. The area around the POD shall be kept free of debris and litter, and shall be in strict compliance with the weed and rubbish provisions of the city's property maintenance code; 
(7)  Use limited to property. A POD shall only be used to contain and store items and material generated at the location where the POD is placed for the residential property being serviced. In no event shall debris and/or material generated off-site be deposited or stored in any POD. 
(8)  Enforcement. Upon reasonable notice to the permit applicant, the code enforcement officer may inspect the POD to ensure compliance with the requirements and conditions of this section. 
(c)  Permit required. 
(1)  A permit shall be required for all portable on-demand storage units. The permit shall be valid for a period of 60 days, and may be renewed for one 30-day extension for good cause shown. The permit shall be obtained from the department of public works, and the permit fee shall be set by the Commissioners of Cambridge by resolution. The permit shall be displayed in a weather proof material on the dumpster or POD. Extensions of the permits are permitted pursuant to paragraph (b)(2) above, based upon a showing of good cause. Permits issued as a result of a natural disaster or other qualifying emergency shall comply with the requirements set forth in item (b)(3) above. 
(2)  Exemption. In the event that the property owner obtains a building permit for renovations or new construction to a residential structure, and the building permit application includes a request for permission to locate a POD on the property for storage as part of the construction or renovation project, then a separate POD permit shall not be required, and the placement of the POD on the property shall be covered by the building permit. In such event, the building permit shall specify that the time limitations set forth in subsections (b)(2) and (b)(3) above apply to the POD. 
(d)  Abatement. Any POD not in compliance with this section is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and may be abated by the city at the property owner's or responsible person's expense. Abatement shall, at the city's option, include the removal and/or emptying of the POD as the case may be. All costs incurred by the city in the abatement shall constitute a lien on the subject property and shall be collected the same as real property taxes by the city. 
(e)  Violations; penalties. 
(1)  Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a fine in an amount of $100.00 for each day that the violation continues. 
(2)  In addition to the fine, a person who is found guilty of a violation of this chapter shall be ordered to abate the problem and to pay the cost incurred by the city if the city abates the problem. 
(3)  All fines and costs incurred by the city in the abatement shall constitute a lien on the subject property and shall be collected the same as real property taxes by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1055, § I, 1-27-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1055, § I, adopted January 27, 2016, set out provisions intended for use as § 4-44. As there were already provisions so designated, the provisions have been redesignated as § 4-45, at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 4-46-4-49. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IV. - BOARDING OF RESIDENTIAL STRUCTURES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1019, adopted Oct. 24, 2011, did not specifically amend the Code and has been included herein as art. IV, §§ 4-70 and 4-71, at the discretion of the editor. Formerly, art. IV pertained to the industrialized dwelling code and was repealed by Ord. No. 763, § 1. The former art. IV derived from Ord. No. 570, § 1. 
Cross reference- Boarding of structures, § 4-43. 

Sec. 4-70. - General boarding requirements for all residential structures. 
(a)  Boarding standards. The boarding up of windows and doors of residential structures within the city shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  All boarding materials shall be cut to fit the window openings and secured with corrosion resistant torx-type fasteners at six inches on center; other types of fasteners and fastening schedule may be utilized as approved by the building official; 
(2)  All boarding materials shall be a minimum of one-half-inch structural panel (plywood/OSB, etc.) and painted flat black in color; 
(3)  The front entrance (the street-facing doorway) shall not be boarded, but shall remain secured against unauthorized entry, and shall be maintained in an operable condition so as to permit access for emergency purposes; and 
(4)  Proper "911" identification numbers shall be affixed to the structure pursuant to code requirements. 
(b)  Boarding permit. A boarding permit shall be required for each residential unit. The boarding permit fee shall be $100.00 The application for boarding permit shall specify the materials to be used. No windows or doors shall be boarded without the issuance of a valid boarding permit, unless otherwise exempted as set forth below or accepted in to the monitored rehabilitation program. 
(c)  Time limitations. 
(1)  Initial boarding. All properties requiring boarding up of windows and/or doors at the time of enactment of this article, (properties boarded at the time this article is enacted) shall be boarded in compliance with the city boarding specifications set forth herein, within 60 days of notification by the department of public works; and 
(2)  Structure boarded after enactment. All structures requiring a boarding permit after the enactment of this article shall be boarded in accordance with this article within 60 days of notification by the department of public works or of the approval of the boarding permit, whichever is sooner. 
(3)  Removal of boarding materials. With the exception of those residential units accepted for participation in the monitored rehabilitation program set forth below, all boarding materials shall be removed and all windows and/or doors installed or repaired to code within nine months from the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(d)  Compliance with code requirements. With the exception of those residential units accepted for participation in the monitored rehabilitation program, and which remain in strict compliance with said program, all residential properties which are boarded shall remain subject to all applicable city property maintenance requirements and subject to all applicable enforcement procedures, as set forth in the International Property Maintenance Code and/or International Building Code, as amended from time to time. 
(e)  Exemptions. Fire and other accidental damage. Windows and/or doors may be boarded-up prior to the issuance of a permit, if the boarding-up is required due to a fire or other accidental event which causes damage to the structure, subject, however to the following: 
(1)  The structure must be occupied or have been occupied within six months prior to the fire/damaging event; 
(2)  The owner of the structure shall immediately notify DPW, in writing, of the fire or damaging event; 
(3)  The boarding up of windows and/or doors shall comply with the boarding requirements set forth herein; 
(4)  The owner shall make application for a building permit (if applicable) within 45 days from the date of the fire/damaging event; or 
(5)  All boarding materials shall be removed and the windows and/or doors repaired or replaced, and in compliance with the property maintenance code of the city, within 45 days from the date of the fire/damaging event; and 
(6)  No permit fee shall be required for minor damage, which is hereby defined as damage to no more than two doors or windows or combination thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1019, 10-24-11) 
Sec. 4-71. - Monitored rehabilitation program for the renovation of multiple residential units. 
    In an effort to encourage rehabilitation of structures for affordable housing units, the city hereby adopts a monitored rehabilitation program ("program" or "MRP"), which permits owners of two or more units, to make application to have units accepted into the program, with some of the units boarded-up for an extended period of time, while other units within the program are completely rehabilitated for occupancy (seeking a certificate of occupancy). 
(1)  Limitation on number of units. This program shall only apply to applicants enrolling at least two, but no more than ten residential structures in need of renovation. Applicants which are sole members of LLC's may combine properties which are also owned by the same individual, but as a sole member of another LLC, as a single "package" subject to the limitations that the application shall be at least two but not more than ten residential structures in need of renovation. For an owner or applicant to include more than ten units, approval must be obtained from housing board of review; 
(2)  Completion date. The owner may be granted a permit to keep each property boarded up for a period of nine months per property, with a maximum program duration of five years. At the termination of the permit period, all of the properties shall be in full compliance with the applicable International Building Code and International Property Maintenance Code, so as to qualify for a certificate of occupancy. Failure to bring all properties into full compliance prior to the expiration of the boarding permit, shall constitute a municipal violation; 
(3)  Enrollment/participation fee. To participate in the monitored rehabilitation program, the property owner shall remit an enrollment/participation fee in the amount of $100.00 per residential unit per year of enrollment within the program, to cover administrative expenses; 
(4)  General schedule of renovations required. Each property owner who elects to participate in the monitored rehabilitation program, shall submit a general schedule of renovations (such as address of property, order of renovation, phases of renovation), and completion dates for each phase thereof, as well as the completion date for each structure, as part of the application. Structures which are completed prior to the date of The schedule of renovations shall either be accepted by DPW or rejected based on noncompliance with the provisions of this article. In the event that the schedule is rejected by DPW, no boarding permit shall be issued and the owner shall not be authorized to include the residential unit which was rejected into the program. Copies of the accepted schedule shall be attached to the permit; 
(5)  Issuance of permit. Upon the payment of all applicable fees, and upon the acceptance and approval, in writing, by DPW of the schedule of renovations, DPW shall issue a permit authorizing the owner's participation in the monitored rehabilitation program; 
(6)  Timely boarding up of participating properties. Owners shall properly board up all properties which are included in the monitored rehabilitation program within 60 days from the date of acceptance into the program. All boarding of properties shall be done in strict compliance with the boarding standards in effect at the time; 
(7)  Identification of participating properties. Each property included within the monitored rehabilitation program shall be placarded by DPW which clearly and conspicuously identifies the property as one within the "monitored rehabilitation program"; 
(8)  Obligation to maintain property in safe condition. The owner shall maintain the surrounding yard of any property within the program in a safe condition, and shall comply with any and all exterior yard area maintenance notices, emergency/hazardous conditions notices issued by DPW. Failure to comply with said notices shall result in termination from the program, as set forth in subsection (9) below; 
(9)  Failure to complete renovations within the approved schedule; penalty fee; termination from the program. In the event that an owner fails to timely complete the renovations pursuant to the completion dates set forth in the approved schedule of renovations, the owner shall be assessed a penalty fee in the amount of $1,000.00 per unit. Said penalty fee shall be collected the same as taxes, and shall constitute a lien on the property. In addition thereto, failure to strictly comply with the schedule of renovations shall result in termination from the program, which termination shall be communicated to the owner in writing by DPW and said penalty shall be assessed to all properties originally enrolled in the program. The owner shall have the right to appeal the decision of DPW to terminate the owner's participation in the program to the housing board of review. Any and all properties which are terminated from participation in the program shall immediately be subject to all applications and provisions of the city's International Building Code and/or International Property Maintenance Code, including notices and orders for repairs, and all applicable enforcement provisions thereof; and 
(10)  Re-enrollment. In the event an owner is terminated from the monitored rehabilitation program for any reason, his/her re-enrollment may only be permitted by the decision of the housing board of review, pursuant to a timely appeal, filed in accordance with section 4-35 of this Code. 
(11)  Exemptions. 
a.  Properties which initially receive a boarding permit only, and are still within said permit time frame, may only be enrolled in the monitored rehabilitation program as granted by the HBOR, so long as the owner meets the requirements of section 4-71. 
b.  Properties which have received a boarding permit for which the time frame has expired are ineligible for enrollment in the program unless purchased by another bonafide owner meeting the requirements of section 4-71 and submitted as part of a new "package." 
c.  Properties having received a demolition order from the division of building safety services shall be excluded from participation in the monitored rehabilitation program. Properties which successfully appeal a demolition order may be eligible for enrollment in the monitored rehabilitation program as approved by the HBOR subsequent to meeting the requirements of subsections (1) through (9) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 1019, 10-24-11) 
Secs. 4-72-4-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - NUMBERS[5] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 4-90. - Generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any dwelling, commercial building or industrial building, etc., to fail to display a number in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Each structure shall display a number assigned to it by the department of public works, in accordance with the following regulations: 
(1)  Numbers shall be displayed prominently on the side of the building facing the street. Such numbers shall be of a height and composition to be clearly visible from the street and shall contrast in color to their background. 
(2)  Numbers shall be placed on or adjacent to the exterior of the building, preferably around or over the front entrance, and shall not be obscured by screened or glass-enclosed porches. 
(Ord. No. 570, § 1)

    Any person, firm or corporation owning any dwelling, commercial building, industrial building, etc., who shall violate any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of an infraction, the fine for which shall be $15.00, and every day that a violation continues after due notice has been served in accordance with the terms and provisions of Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3(b), shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 636, § 1, 1-2-81; Ord. No. 639, § 1, 6-8-81)

ARTICLE II. - FAIR HOUSING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 679, § 1, enacted June 11, 1984, provided for the addition of § 4-92 to ch. 4, which provisions the editor has redesignated as art. II, §§ 4.5-12-4.5-16, of a new ch. 4.5, for purposes of classification and reference. 
Cross reference- Buildings and housing, ch. 4. 
State Law reference- Housing discrimination, Ann. Code of Md. art. State Government, § 20-701 et seq. 

Sec. 4.5-12. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the content, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
(a)  Discriminate or discrimination means any difference in treatment in the sale, lease, rental or financing of housing units or housing accommodations because of race, color, religion, creed, ancestry, sex, age, national origin, handicap, or use of a guide dog because of the blindness of the user. 
(b)  Housing unit means a single room or suite of rooms, or an apartment or dwelling, occupied or intended for occupancy as separate living quarters by an individual or a family, or a parcel of real property or a lot available for the construction of a housing unit. 
(c)  Lending institution means any person, as defined in this article, regularly engaged in the business of lending money or guaranteeing loans. 
(d)  Owner includes the lessee, sublessee, assignee, managing agent or other person having the right of ownership or possession or the right to sell, rent or lease any housing unit which is part of a housing accommodation, or to furnish services in connection therewith. 
(e)  Person includes an association, partnership or corporation, as well as a natural person. When applied to partnerships or other associations, it includes their members, and as applied to corporations it includes the officers of the corporations. 
(f)  Real estate broker means any natural person, partnership, association or corporation who, for a fee or other valuable consideration, or other purposes, sells, purchases, exchanges or rents, or negotiates or offers or attempts to negotiate, the sale, purchase, exchange or rental of the real property of another, or holds himself or herself out as engaged in the business of selling, purchasing, exchanging or renting the real property of another, or collects rental for the use of the real property of another, or attempts to secure the listing for sale or rental of a housing unit by representing that a change has occurred or will or may occur with respect to the racial, religious or ethnic composition of the street, block, neighborhood or area in which said housing accommodation is located. 
(g)  Real estate salesperson or agent means any person employed by a real estate broker to perform or to assist in the performance of any or all of the functions of a real estate broker, or to provide any services in connection therewith. 
(Ord. No. 679, § 1, 6-11-84) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 4.5-13. - Scope of article. 
    This article applies to discriminatory housing units located within territorial limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 679, § 1, 6-11-84) 
Sec. 4.5-14. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  No real estate broker or real estate salesperson or agent, or owner or other person, shall refuse to sell, lease, sublease, rent, assign or otherwise transfer or refuse to negotiate for the sale, lease, sublease, rental, assignment or other transfer of the title, leasehold or other interest in any housing unit to any person, or represent that a housing unit is not available for inspection, sale, lease, sublease, rental, assignment or other transfer when in fact it is so available, or otherwise deny or withhold any housing unit from any person because of race, color, religion, creed, ancestry, age, sex, national origin, handicap, or use of a guide dog because of the blindness of the user. 
(b)  No owner shall refuse to sell, lease, sublease, rent, assign or otherwise transfer the title, leasehold or other interest in any housing unit, which is part of a housing accommodation, to any person, or otherwise deny or withhold such housing unit or deny or withhold the furnishing of services in connection therewith, from any person because of race, color, religion, creed, ancestry, age, sex, national origin, handicap, or use of a guide dog because of the blindness of the user. 
(c)  No real estate broker or real estate salesperson or agent shall include in the terms, conditions or privileges, or services in connection therewith, of any sale, lease, sublease, rental, assignment or other transfer of any housing unit any clause, condition or restriction discriminating against any person in the use or occupancy of such housing unit because of race, color, religion, creed, ancestry, age, sex, national origin, handicap, or use of a guide dog because of the blindness of the user. 
(d)  No person shall include in the terms, conditions or privileges of the sale, lease, sublease, rental, assignment or other transfer of a housing unit, which is part of a housing accommodation, any clause, condition or restriction discriminating against any person in the use or occupancy of such housing unit because of race, color, religion, creed, ancestry, age, sex, national origin, handicap, or use of a guide dog because of the blindness of the user. 
(e)  No person shall discriminate in the furnishing of any facilities or services for a housing unit, which is part of a housing accommodation, because of race, color, religion, creed, ancestry, age, sex, national origin, handicap, or use of a guide dog because of the blindness of the user. 
(f)  No real estate broker, real estate salesperson or agent, owner or any other person or any lending institution shall publish or circulate or cause to be published or circulated any form of application for the purchase, lease, rental or financing of housing, or make any record or inquiry in connection with the prospective purchase, rental or lease of housing, which expresses directly or indirectly any limitation, specification or discrimination as to race, color, religion, creed, ancestry, age, sex, national origin, handicap, or use of a guide dog because of blindness of the user, or any intent to make any such limitation, specification or discrimination. 
(g)  No person, whether or not a real estate broker, real estate salesperson or agent, owner or lending institution, shall aid, incite, compel, coerce or participate in the doing of any act declared to be an unlawful housing practice under this article, or obstruct or prevent enforcement or compliance with the provisions of this article or any rule, regulation or order of the enforcement body of this article, or attempt directly or indirectly to commit any act declared by this article to be an unlawful housing practice. 
(Ord. No. 679, § 1, 6-11-84) 
Sec. 4.5-15. - Exemptions. 
    Nothing in this article shall bar a religious or denominational institution, or religious or denominational organization which is operated, supervised or controlled by or in connection with a religious organization, from limiting admission to or giving preference to persons of the same religion or denomination, or from making such selection as is calculated by such organization to promote the religious principles for which it is established or maintained, as long as such selection or preference is not on the basis of race, color, creed, ancestry, age, sex, national origin, handicap, or use of a guide dog because of the blindness of the user. 
(Ord. No. 679, § 1, 6-11-84) 
Sec. 4.5-16. - Enforcement of article. 
    The provisions of this article shall be enforced by the grants administrator pursuant to procedures and regulations which he shall establish. 
(Ord. No. 679, § 1, 6-11-84)

Chapter 6 - FIRE PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of city to regulate storage of explosives, firearms, etc., § 3-27(22); authority of city to suppress fires, § 3-27(25); authority of city to enforce fire regulations, § 3-27(51). 
Cross reference- Buildings and housing, ch. 4; electricity, ch. 5; unsafe buildings, § 8-5; siphoning water from fire hydrants, § 12-5; fire protection in mobile home parks, § 17-35; water, ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Authority to provide for fire prevention and protection, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 2(b)(12); fire prevention and protection generally, Ann. Code of Md. art. Public Safety, § 9-101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Inspection for fire hazards. 
(a)  The chief of the fire department may at any reasonable time enter any building or other structure or premises used for commercial purposes for the purpose of examining and inspecting conditions with regard to the presence or arrangement of any article, materials or goods or any other thing which may in his opinion tend to create danger of or from fire, or unnecessarily and unreasonably interfere with the work of the fire department in the event of fire on the premises, or endanger the life of the occupants or other persons on or in the building, structure or premises in the event of fire. He shall also examine the condition, size, arrangement and efficiency of any appliances for fire prevention or for protection against fire on the premises. 
(b)  The chief of the fire department may direct such members of the fire department as may in his judgment be necessary to make the inspections provided for in this section. They shall report in writing the results of their inspections to the fire department. For the purpose of making such inspections, the members of the fire department who are so designated have the same power to enter upon and into and inspect any premises, buildings or structures within the city as is given to the chief. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any private dwelling, curtilage, building or outbuilding attached or used in connection therewith, or to any farm property or farm building in the city. 
(Code 1972, §§ 13.14, 13.16) 
Sec. 6-2. - Report of fire hazards; order to abate. 
(a)  If, as a result of the inspection authorized to be made, the chief of the fire department is of the opinion that any rubbish, debris, waste or inflammable or combustible material found on any premises or in any structure is not so arranged as to afford a reasonable safeguard against the danger of fire or from fire; or that articles, materials or goods on the premises are so arranged that persons in any building or structure would not be afforded reasonable access to exits in case of fire; or that by reason of such disposition the members of the fire department would be unnecessarily and unreasonably obstructed in the exercise of their duties in the event of fire, he shall immediately make a detailed report in writing to the commissioners of the conditions so found. If in their judgment such conditions are found to exist, the commissioners shall immediately give notice in writing to the owner or occupier of the premises where such conditions have been found to exist, warning such person of the existence of each condition so found. 
(b)  The commissioners may also order in writing that such conditions be abated, corrected or removed within the time and in the manner prescribed in the notice. If the owner or occupier considers himself aggrieved by such order, he may, within three days after the receipt of the notice, appeal to the commissioners in writing for revocation of the order, whereupon the commissioners shall grant a hearing, which shall be held within three days. If the order is not revoked by the commissioners and the owner or occupier fails to comply with the terms of the order, the commissioners shall remove or correct the dangerous condition at the expense of the owner or occupier, which cost may be recovered by the commissioners from the owner or occupier by suit if necessary. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to any private dwelling, curtilage, building or outbuilding attached or used in connection therewith, or to any farm property or farm building in the city. 
(Code 1972, §§ 13.14, 13.16) 
Sec. 6-3. - Penalty for violation of section 6-1 or 6-2. 
    Any owner or occupier who obstructs or refuses to permit the free entrance to and the inspection of any premises, buildings or structures as provided in section 6-1 or neglects or refuses to comply with the terms and conditions of the order authorized in section 6-2, unless such order is revoked, shall be fined not less than $25.00 and not more than $500.00. 
(Code 1972, § 13.17) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Sec. 6-4. - Damaging alarms or other property of fire department. 
(a)  Any person who interferes with, defaces or damages any fire alarm box, wires, apparatus or other property of the fire department shall be fined not less than $5.00 and not more than $50.00, or be imprisoned for not less than 15 days and not more than six months. 
(b)  Any person who enters any firehouse with intent to deface any apparatus or any other property belonging to the fire department shall be fined not less than $5.00 and not more than $30.00. 
(Code 1972, § 13.07) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Sec. 6-5. - Driving over fire hose. 
    Any person who drives any vehicle over or across a fire hose shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof before a court of competent jurisdiction shall be fined not less than $25.00 and not more than $200.00 and shall stand committed to jail until such fine and costs are paid, or be confined to jail for not less than 30 days and not more than 60 days, or be both fined and imprisoned, in the discretion of the court, and be ordered to pay restitution for any damage resulting to the fire hose. 
(Code 1972, § 13.09; Ord. No. 712, § 1, 3-9-87) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 11. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ann. Code of Md. art. Transportation, § 21-1110; restriction on powers of local authorities, Ann. Code of Md. art. Transportation, §§ 25-101.1, 25-101.2; penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Sec. 6-6. - Interference with firemen. 
    Any person who resists or improperly interferes with any officer of the fire department or any fireman, or any officer of the city, while engaged in the discharge of his duties at any fire, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof before a trial magistrate or a court of competent jurisdiction shall be fined not less than $25.00 and not more than $200.00 and shall stand committed to jail until such fine and costs are paid, or be confined in jail for not less than 30 days and not more than 60 days, or be both fined and imprisoned, in the discretion of the court. 
(Code 1972, § 13.10) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Sec. 6-7. - Right-of-way of fire apparatus; parking near fires. 
    No operator of any vehicle shall obstruct any fire apparatus proceeding to a fire, but, immediately upon being warned of the approach of a fire apparatus, shall give the apparatus the right-of-way and stop, and shall not again move until the fire apparatus is 200 feet ahead. No operator of a vehicle shall park within 200 feet of any fire apparatus attending a fire. Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than $5.00 and not more than $50.00, or be imprisoned for not less than five days and not more than 60 days. 
(Code 1972, § 13.11) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 11. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Ann. Code of Md. art. Transportation, § 21-1109; restriction on powers of local authorities, Ann. Code of Md. art. Transportation, §§ 25-101, 25-101.1; penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Sec. 6-8. - False alarms. 
    Any person who gives false alarm of fire or by any means leads persons to believe that some building within the corporate limits of the city is on fire shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof before a trial magistrate or a court of competent jurisdiction shall be fined not less than $50.00 and not more than $300.00 and shall stand committed to jail until such fine and costs are paid, or be confined in jail or a house of correction for not less than three months and not more than three years, or be both fined and imprisoned, in the discretion of the court. 
(Code 1972, § 13.13) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- False fire alarms, Ann. Code of Md. art. Criminal Law § 9-604; penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Sec. 6-9. - Entering firehouse. 
    No person except the mayor, any commissioner, a police officer or a member of the fire department shall enter any firehouse belonging to the fire department or in its charge, unless accompanied by the chief of the fire department or assistant chief or a member of the department or other person in charge of such firehouse. 
(Code 1972, § 13.05) 
Sec. 6-9.5. - Fees for the deployment of public safety services rendered by the city. 
(a)  The city's fire and rescue services shall initiate user fees for the delivery of fire and rescue services, hazardous materials services, personnel, supplies and equipment to the scene of motor vehicle accidents (MVA) and other incidents on the highways, fire suppression, removal and clean-up of hazardous materials, and other related emergency services. The rate for the fees for services as authorized by this section shall be as established by the city commissioners by resolution from time to time. 
(b)  The user fee shall be billed to the responsible party or property owner, representing an add-on cost of the claim for damages of the vehicles, structure(s), property and/or injuries. In the event services are required relating to utilities causing safety problems to highway areas, and if the area is deemed unsafe by emergency responders, the same billing process shall apply to said utility, whose equipment related problems cause for an emergency services response. The claim costs shall be billed to the insurance coverage of the owner of a vehicle, owner of property, or responsible parties. 
(c)  The office of the city clerk shall be responsible for the billing for these fees or the collection thereof, and all monies collected shall be made a part of the city's general operating budget. 
(d)  The fees and charges approved by resolution for the services set forth herein shall be applicable for all service calls provided by Rescue Fire Company for the city, within the "First Due Area" of Rescue Fire Company, with the exception of the following services, the fees and charges for which shall be applicable and billed for all calls and services made: 
(1)  Hazardous materials ("haz-mat") calls, all of which shall be billed to the responsible party; 
(2)  Marine vessel incidents, all of which shall be billed to the responsible party; 
(3)  Confined space calls, all of which shall be billed to the responsible party. 
(Ord. No. 994, §§ 1-4, 6-21-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 994, § 1-4, adopted June 21, 2010, did not specifically amend the Code and has been included herein as § 6-9.5 at the discretion of the editor. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; personnel, ch. 13. 

Sec. 6-10. - Management; composition. 
    The fire department of the city shall be under the management of a chief of the fire department subject to the authority and control of the commissioners, and shall embrace such companies as may be organized under the authority of the commissioners. 
(Code 1972, § 13.01) 
Sec. 6-11. - Election and term of officers.
