If the applicant is a corporation, the names and addresses of the president and secretary thereof shall be given. 
(b)  Definition. The term "taxicab," as used in this section, means any and all vehicles carrying passengers for hire, except motor buses or motor coaches operated by bus lines over designated routes in and to the city. 
(c)  Qualifications for issuance of taxicab license. No such license shall be issue to or held by any person who is not a person of good character, or to one who has been convicted of a felony crime of violence or a felony drug distribution for a period of 36 months after said conviction or for a period of 36 months after the completion of a period of incarceration for said felony (whichever period is greater); nor shall such license be issued to or held by any corporation where any officer or stockholder thereof would be ineligible for a license under the conditions stated in this subsection. 
(d)  Taxicab license fee. The annual fee for such license shall be as resolved from time to time by the commissioners of the city, payable in advance on May 1 of each year. Whenever the number of cabs so operated shall be increased during the license year, the licensee shall notify the city clerk of such change and shall pay the additional fee. The clerk shall issue suitable receipts for the number of cabs covered by each license. Such receipt shall be displayed in a prominent place on each taxicab while it is in use; it may be transferred to any taxicab put into service to replace one withdrawn from service. The licensee shall notify the clerk of the motor number and the state license number of each taxicab and of the corresponding municipal receipt number. 
(e)  Taxicabs to bear state license; equipment. No taxicab shall be operated unless it bears a state license duly issued, and no such cab shall be operated unless it is equipped with proper brakes, lights, tires, horn, muffler, rear vision mirror and windshield wipers in good condition. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to inspect or have inspected every taxicab as often as may be necessary to ensure the enforcement of this section. 
(f)  Drivers to have state chauffeur's license. No person shall drive a taxicab, or be hired or permitted to do so, unless he is duly licensed to do so as a chauffeur by the state. 
(g)  Obedience to traffic rules. It shall be the duty of every driver of a taxicab to obey all traffic rules established by statute or ordinance. 
(h)  Involvement of taxicabs in crimes. It shall be unlawful to knowingly permit any taxicab to be used in perpetration of a crime or misdemeanor. 
(i)  Driver's license required; fee. No person shall drive a taxicab unless he shall have secured a license from the city clerk. The annual fee for a taxicab driver's license shall be $5.00. 
(j)  Issuance of driver's license. No such license shall be issued to any person who is not competent to operate a motor vehicle, or who is not familiar with the traffic laws and ordinances, or who does not have a valid chauffeur's license issued by the state or who is not a person of good moral character or who has been convicted of a felony. The chief of police shall examine each applicant for a taxicab driver's license and determine the competency of the applicant. No such license shall be issued except on certificate of the chief of police that the applicant has demonstrated to him his ability to operate a taxicab. 
(k)  Revocation. The mayor and city clerk may revoke any taxicab or taxicab driver's license for repeated violation of traffic laws or the violation of any ordinance regulating the conduct of such drivers, but any such licensee may appeal within ten days to the commissioners. 
(l)  Posting of driver's license. Every driver licensed under the provisions of this section shall post his driver's license in such a place as to be in full view of all passengers while such driver is operating a taxicab. 
(Code 1972, § 14.07; Ord. No. 630, § 1, 6-30-80; Ord. No. 732, § 1, 8-22-88; Ord. No. 857, § 2, 7-13-98; Ord. No. 944, 4-24-06) 
Charter reference- Taxicabs, § 3-79 et seq. 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 11. 
Sec. 10-7. - Businesses manufacturing or processing poisonous gases. 
(a)  License required. No person shall operate or permit to be operated any business that manufactures, processes or repackages any poisonous gas that is specified as such by the standards established by the division of labor and industry of the state without first obtaining a license therefor from the commissioners of the city. 
(b)  Issuance; term. No license shall be issued unless, in the opinion of the commissioners of the city, the location and method of operation will be such that no injury will be caused to any person or property, and, in the determination of such, the appropriate industrial standards applicable to the operation shall be considered as well as the standards established by the division of labor and industry of the state. No such license shall issue as a matter of right or as a ministerial duty of the city to the applicants. All such licenses shall expire on May 1 of each year, and license fees shall be prorated as of the date of granting. 
(c)  Fee. The fee for the license required in this section shall be in the amount of $25.00 per year. 
(d)  Revocation. Upon violation of the standards established by the division of labor and industry of the state, such licenses may be revoked. 
(e)  Penalty. Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than $100.00 and not more than $500.00, and each day's operation without a license shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 535, § 1) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Sec. 10-8. - Mobile home communities. 
    No person shall operate or permit to be operated any mobile home community in the city without first obtaining a license and permit, as required and provided by section 20-15A. 
(Ord. No. 558, § 1) 
Cross reference- Mobile home parks, § 17-26 et seq.; mobile home communities zoning district, § 20-15A. 
Sec. 10-9. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
    Except where it is otherwise provided, any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of an infraction, the fine for which shall be $50.00, and every day that a violation continues after due notice has been served in conformity with the terms and provisions of Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3(b), shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 732, § 1, 8-22-88) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Sec. 10-10. - Septage haulers. 
(a)  The city wastewater treatment plant shall not accept any sewage from septage haulers unless they possess a valid license for the same from the city. 
(b)  The annual fee for such license shall be $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 773, § 1, 7-1-91; Ord. No. 857, § 3, 7-13-98) 
Cross reference- Plumbing and sewers, ch. 14. 
Sec. 10-11. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1006, adopted Feb. 28, 2011, repealed § 10-11 which pertained to permits for residential rental units and derived from Ord. No. 995, adopted June 21, 2010. 
Chapter 11 - MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 11-1. - Stop signs. 
(a)  Generally. The operator of any motor vehicle, bicycle or other vehicle approaching any street intersection at which a stop sign is installed at the instance of the commissioners shall completely stop the vehicle at such a distance from the intersection as will permit free and unobstructed pedestrian traffic across the intersection, and shall keep the vehicle stationary until the intersecting street is clear of approaching traffic and can be entered or crossed with safety. 
(b)  Emergency vehicles. Any member of the rescue fire company operating a motor vehicle or any other vehicle, in going to a fire for which an alarm has been given, when approaching any intersection where there is a stop sign, shall slow down and ascertain whether or not there is any approaching traffic on the intersecting street, and if there is approaching traffic he shall come to a stop until such approaching traffic has passed, but if there is no approaching traffic he may proceed to enter or cross the street without coming to a stop. This provision shall not apply to any fireman returning from a fire, or unless there shall be prominently displayed on the vehicle some suitable emblem showing that the operator or user of the vehicle is a member of the rescue fire company. 
(Code 1972, § 21.01) 
State Law reference- Stop signs, Ann. Code of Md. art. Transportation, § 21-207; authority to erect stop signs, Ann. Code of Md. art. Transportation, § 25-102(a)(6). 
Sec. 11-2. - Stoplight signals. 
(a)  Generally. The operator of any motor vehicle, bicycle or other vehicle approaching any lighted traffic stop and go signal shall stop the vehicle at least 15 feet from the nearest curb corner when the light shows red toward him, and shall there remain stationary until the light shows green. 
(b)  Emergency vehicles. Any member of the rescue fire company operating a motor vehicle or any other vehicle, in going to any fire for which an alarm has been given, when approaching a stop and go signal showing red, shall bring his vehicle to a complete stop 15 feet from the curb corner, but if there is no cross traffic he may then proceed slowly through the red light. This provision shall not apply to any fireman returning from a fire, or unless there shall be prominently displayed on the vehicle some suitable emblem showing that the operator or user of the vehicle is a member of the rescue fire company. 
(Code 1972, § 21.02) 
State Law reference- Traffic control signal legend, Ann. Code of Md. art. Transportation, § 21-202. 
Sec. 11-3. - Speed limit. 
    Any person who operates any vehicle at a speed greater than is reasonable and proper, having regard for the width, traffic and use of the street or alley, or at a speed greater than posted, or recklessly, or so as to endanger the property and life or limb of any person, shall be fined not less than $5.00 and not more than $100.00. 
(Ord. No. 480, § 1) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Speed generally, Ann. Code of Md. art. Transportation, § 21-801 et seq.; penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Sec. 11-3A. - Prohibition of operation of certain motor vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for anyone to operate an untagged and/or unregistered motor vehicle on public property or property used for public purposes, such as parks, public streets, or public parking lots, within the city. 
(b)  Unless otherwise permitted by statute or ordinance, it shall be unlawful for anyone to operate a motorbike, mini-bike, quad, go-cart and other all-terrain motor vehicle on public property or property used for public purposes, such as parks, public streets, or public parking lots, within the city, unless such vehicle is tagged and registered, and is otherwise permitted to be operated on public streets as a licensed motor vehicle, in which event, the motor vehicle shall only be operated in areas paved and designated for use by motor vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 949, 10-23-06) 
State Law reference- Speed generally, Ann. Code of Md. art. Transportation, § 21-801 et seq.; penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Sec. 11-4. - Prohibited turns. 
(a)  No operator of a vehicle shall make a left turn from the first alley east of Race Street into the south side of Gay Street. 
(b)  No operator of a vehicle on Market Street shall make a left turn on the west side of the Cambridge Creek Bridge into the Market Square parking area. 
(c)  No operator of a vehicle shall make a right turn from Milbourne Street onto Glasgow Street. 
(Code 1972, § 21.04; Ord. No. 821, 11-13-95) 
State Law reference- Authority to restrict turns, Ann. Code of Md. art. Transportation, § 25-102(a)(9). 
Sec. 11-4A. - Left turn from Market Street onto Market Square property. 
    No operator of a vehicle shall make a left turn from Market Street into the entrance of the parking lot of the Market Square Condominiums and Shopping Center. 
(Ord. No. 860, 7-27-98) 
Sec. 11-5. - Race Street-Entering or crossing. 
    No operator of a vehicle shall enter or cross Race Street from any street or alley on the west side of Race Street between Muir Street and Gay Street. 
(Code 1972, § 21.05) 
Sec. 11-6. - Same-Loading zones. 
    No person shall park any vehicle on the eastward side of Race Street between Cemetery Avenue and Gay Street for a longer time than actually necessary to load or discharge freight or merchandise. No person shall load or unload merchandise on the eastward side of Race Street between Cemetery Avenue and Gay Street between the hours of 11:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. or between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 6:00 p.m. 
(Code 1972, § 21.16) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate parking, Ann. Code of Md. art. Transportation, § 25-102(a)(1). 
Sec. 11-7. - Yacht Basin Drive. 
    The roadway situated on the southern side of the municipal yacht basin, referred to in this section as Yacht Basin Drive, is hereby subject to the following regulations: 
(a)  All vehicular traffic on Yacht Basin Drive shall be one-way in an east to west direction. 
(b)  No vehicle shall be operated on Yacht Basin Drive at a rate of speed greater than five miles per hour. 
(c)  No vehicles shall be driven or parked on the grass or sidewalk adjacent to Yacht Basin Drive. 
(d)  Parking on Yacht Basin Drive shall be limited to loading and unloading purposes only. 
(Code 1972, § 21.22; Ord. No. 537, § 1; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 8-29-88)

State Law reference- Authority to establish one-way streets, Ann. Code of Md. art. Transportation, § 25-102(a)(4). 
Sec. 11-9. - Truck routes. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate at any time any commercial vehicle exceeding 5,000 pounds gross weight upon any of the streets or parts of the streets of the city, except upon the following streets, which shall be available for such traffic: 
(1)  Bayly Road. 
(2)  Washington Street. 
(3)  Stone Boundary Road. 
(4)  Boundary Avenue, from Stone Boundary Road to Goodwill Avenue. 
(5)  Goodwill Avenue, from Boundary Avenue to Washington Street. 
(6)  Front Street. 
(7)  Perimore Street. 
(8)  Cedar Street, from Sunburst Highway to Race Street. 
(9)  Gay Street, from Poplar Street to Muse Street. 
(10)  Muse Street, from Gay Street to the Cambridge Creek Bridge. 
(11)  Sunburst Highway. 
(12)  Maryland Avenue, from Sunburst Highway to Academy Street. 
(13)  Roslyn Avenue, from Sunburst Highway to Dorchester Avenue. 
(14)  LeCompte Street. 
(15)  Green Street. 
(16)  Trenton Street and Hayward Street. 
(b)  Such vehicles may be operated upon other streets of the city for the purpose of delivering or picking up materials or merchandise and, with the exception of Lake Street between Washington Street and Brohawn Avenue, for the purpose of arriving at or departing from terminals or offices of business. 
(Code 1972, § 21.20; Ord. No. 469, § 1; Ord. No. 549, § 1; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 8-29-88) 
State Law reference- Authority to establish truck routes, Ann. Code of Md. art. Transportation, § 25-102(a)(11). 
Sec. 11-10. - Selling from parked vehicle. 
(a)  Generally . 
(1)  Prohibited. In the absence of special permission as specified in subsection (b) of this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to park on any street or municipal parking lot any vehicle for the purpose of selling or offering for sale any produce or merchandise whatsoever, except laurel, holly or other Christmas greens. 
(2)  Sale of Christmas greenery. A vendor/seller of laurel, holly or other Christmas greenery is exempt from the prohibition set forth in subsection (a)(1), the requirement of obtaining special permission as required in section (b), and any parking-meter or other time-limitation for parking, provided that such a vendor/seller abides by the following: 
a.  This exemption applies only to sales of such items during the following dates: from the Friday following Thanksgiving to December 25; 
b.  This exemption applies only to the following locations: Gay Street, the 200 and 300 blocks of High Street, Poplar Street, the 400 and 500 blocks of Race Street, and the municipal parking lots at Gay Street and the 500 Block of Race Street; 
c.  No more than one vendor/seller is permitted within any one block/parking lot; 
d.  The vendor/seller shall notify the city in writing of his/her intention to sell and of his/her intended locations; 
e.  No more than three such vendors/sellers shall be exempted in any given year, with priority being given to the vendors/sellers who sold such products and who were exempted during the prior year; otherwise, the exemption shall apply on a first-come basis. 
(b)  Special permission. The city council may permit selling from parked vehicles on the occasion of special promotions or other similar events if the council deems it to be in the best interest of the public health, safety and welfare of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 21.21; Ord. No. 652, § 1, 5-3-82; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 8-29-88; Ord. No. 899, 12-17-01) 
Cross reference- Peddlers license, § 10-2. 
Sec. 11-10.5. - Automated speed enforcement in designated school zones. 
(a)  The city is authorized to operate an automated speed monitoring system to enforce the speed limit in conformance with Ann. Code of Md. art. Transportation § 21-809, as amended. 
(b)  Before activating an unmanned stationary speed monitoring system, the city shall: 
(1)  Publish notice of the location of the speed monitoring system on its website and in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(2)  Ensure that each sign that designates a school zone indicates that a speed monitoring system is in use in the school zone. 
(c)  The operation of a speed monitoring system in a designated school zone shall be limited to the following days and times: Monday through Friday between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. 
(d)  For a period of at least 30 days after the first speed monitoring system is placed and is operational in the city, a violation recorded by any speed monitoring system may be enforced only by issuance of a warning. 
(e)  The city council is hereby authorized to designate school speed enforcement zones consistent with this section by resolution. 
(f)  Failure to pay an automated speed enforcement citation by the due date, or failure to elect to stand trial as stated on the citation, shall result in a late fee of $35.00. 
(g)  Any person who pays any penalty assessed under this section shall further pay a $35.00 returned check fee to the city should the check be returned unpaid by the payor's bank. 
(h)  The city shall, in accordance with the procedures prescribed by the state motor vehicle administration (MVA) and state law, give or cause to be given notice to the MVA of all vehicles registered by the state and the subject of any outstanding and past due automated speed enforcement citations and request that the MVA refuse registration or transfer of registration of the subject vehicle, until notified by the city that the violation penalty has been satisfied. In such cases, the city shall impose an additional cost of $45.00 for each registration withheld and the owner of the vehicle shall be subject to payment of such costs, and all other fines, penalties, fees and charges applicable before notice is given to the MVA that the subject citation has been satisfied and the registration is released. 
(Ord. No. 1010, 4-25-11) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1010, adopted April 25, 2011, did not specifically amend the Code and has been included herein as § 11-10.5 at the discretion of the editor. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of city to install parking meters, § 3-27(45). 
Cross reference- Parking during street sweeping operations, § 16-20. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate stopping, standing or parking, Ann. Code of Md. art. Transportation, § 25-102(a)(1). 

Sec. 11-11. - Prohibited parking generally. 
    No person shall park any vehicle at any time in the city: 
(a)  Within 15 feet from any fireplug. 
(b)  On any street within 15 feet from its intersection with another street. 
(c)  On any street opposite any public or private alley or driveway in any manner which impedes access to and from such alleys or driveways. 
(d)  At the same location on any street for more than 48 consecutive hours. 
(e)  In front of any school building where the curb is painted yellow, between 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on all days when school is in session. 
(f)  In front of any curb that is officially painted yellow, except as provided in subsection (e) of this section. 
(g)  Which carries a boat, at the same location on any street for more than 24 consecutive hours. 
(h)  On any street or portion of a street which is designated or posted as "No Parking." 
(i)  On the left side of a two-way street, resulting in the tires on the left side (i.e. driver's side) of the vehicle being immediately adjacent to the curb. Parking may occur on the left side of one-way streets, provided the left side of the street is not designated or posted as "No Parking." 
(Code 1972, § 21.07; Ord. No. 1085, 7-11-16) 
Sec. 11-12. - Temporary parking restrictions. 
(a)  The chief of police is authorized and empowered, as the official agent of the commissioners, to regulate, modify or prohibit the parking of vehicles in any section of the city on special occasions such as weddings, funerals or parades, or whenever in his opinion such an emergency exists as would make it desirable, convenient or necessary for the welfare and safety of the citizens of the city. 
(b)  The chief of police, in the exercise of the discretion and power given him by this section, shall, before the time that he shall seek to regulate, modify or prohibit parking in a designated area, first display in the area several regulatory signs bearing an appropriate legend, which shall warn operators of vehicles of the temporary restriction then in force. If any operator of a vehicle shall fail to comply with such temporary restriction, the chief of police may cause any offending vehicle to be towed away and impounded until such time as the owner shall pay the towing charges, in addition to the penalty set forth in this article if the state elects to prosecute under this section. 
(Code 1972, § 21.08)

Sec. 11-14. - Overnight parking. 
(a)  No person shall park any vehicle on any of the following streets between 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m.: 
High Street, between Church Street and Poplar Street. 
Race Street, between Gay Street and Cedar Street. 
Poplar Street, between High Street and Gay Street. 
(b)  No person shall park any vehicle on Race Street from Washington Street to Poplar Street, on any part of Poplar Street, or on High Street from Poplar Street to the Long Wharf, for a longer period than three hours between midnight of any day and 6:00 a.m. the following day. Between any midnight and 6:00 a.m. the following morning, the moving of a motor vehicle from the place where parked, in any of the streets named in this subsection, to some other place in any of the same streets, so that the vehicle shall be parked for more than three consecutive hours in such streets between midnight and 6:00 a.m., shall have the same effect as if the vehicle had not been moved, and the keeping of a vehicle in the prohibited area for more than three successive and continuous hours shall be an unlawful parking of the same under this section. 
(Code 1972, § 21.10) 
Sec. 11-15. - Limited use areas. 
(a)  Two-hour parking. No person shall park any vehicle where allowed on any of the following streets and parking lots in any one place for a period longer than two hours between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. of the day, excluding Sundays and legal holidays as recognized by the city: 
Cedar Street, from Race Street to Academy Street and 115 feet on west side of Race Street intersection. 
Cemetary Avenue, south side 109 feet east from Race Street intersection. 
City Hall, parking lot adjacent to City Hall except those spaces marked "City Hall Employees and/or Mayor." 
Elm Street, north side 172 feet west of Race Street intersection. 
Gay Street, municipal parking lots. 
Gay Street, north side 266 feet west of Race Street intersection. 
High Street, west side from Church Street to Muir Street and east side from Court Lane to Gay Street. 
Lake Street. 
Maryland Avenue, both sides of 500 block, between Dorchester Avenue and Sunburst Highway. 
Muir Street, both sides between Race Street and Academy Street, and both sides 163 feet west of Race Street intersection. 
Poplar Street, north side between High Street and Gay Street. 
Race Street, from Gay Street to Washington Street. 
Pleasant Street, northeast side, between Academy Street and a point 222 feet from Race Street. 
(b)  One-hour parking. No person shall park any vehicle on the parking lot adjacent to the rescue fire company and public library for a period longer than one hour between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, legal holidays excepted, unless they are on fire call or ambulance call. 
(c)  Franklin Street boat ramp. During the period of time commencing April 1 and ending October 31 of each year, the city-maintained parking area at the Franklin Street boat ramp may be used only by vehicles with boat trailers attached. No single vehicular parking shall be allowed during that designated period of time. 
(d)  Fifteen-minute parking. The commissioners shall establish, on the streets and in the parking lots of the city, at their discretion, parking spaces and zones which are marked as being limited to fifteen-minute parking. 
(Ord. No. 447, § 1; Ord. No. 613, § 1, 7-2-79; Ord. No. 625, § 1, 2-11-80; Ord. No. 668, § 1, 9-19-83; Ord. No. 686, § 1, 11-5-84; Ord. No. 782, § 1, 5-4-92; Ord. No. 791, § 1, 1-18-93; Ord. No. 839, 4-28-97) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 668, § 1, adopted Sept. 19, 1983, added a new subsection (a) to § 11-15, which the editor has redesignated as subsection (c) inasmuch as § 11-15 already contained a subsection (a). 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Sec. 11-16. - Truck parking prohibited on certain streets. 
    No person shall park any vehicle more than seven feet wide on any of the following streets at any time: 
High Street, either side, from Pine Street to Poplar Street. 
Pine Street, either side, between Washington Street and High Street. 
Poplar Street and Race Street, from High Street to Stone Boundary Avenue. 
Washington Street, either side, from Race Street to the city limits. 
    Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the parking of a vehicle on the streets named in this section for the purpose of loading and unloading, if the vehicle is parked within six inches of the curb. 
(Code 1972, § 21.12) 
Sec. 11-17. - Time limit for truck parking. 
(a)  Generally. Subject to the parking restrictions as set forth in section 11-15 of this chapter, no person shall park any motor truck, commercial vehicle or bus with a capacity of more than three-quarters of a ton on any street, lane or alley for more than four hours continuously. The provisions of this section shall not apply to commercial trucks actually loading or unloading, or which are parked for the purpose of doing work for any person within a radius of one block from the place where the vehicle is parked. 
(b)  Authority to remove vehicles. The police department has the authority to take possession of and remove or cause to be removed any motor vehicle, truck, commercial vehicle or bus parked in violation of this section. The owner of the vehicle shall be required to pay the costs of the removing of same and the storage thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 21.13; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 8-29-88; Ord. No. 839, 4-28-97) 
Sec. 11-18. - Parking in alleys. 
(a)  No person shall park any vehicle in any public alley which leads from the following streets: 
Church Street, at the rear of the U.S. Post Office. 
High Street, between Church Street and Poplar Street. 
Muir Street, between Race Street and Academy Street. 
Poplar Street. 
Race Street, between Gay Street and Washington Street. 
(b)  No person shall park any vehicle in that part of the alley which lies between the south side of Gay Street and a point where the alley makes a right angle turn located in the rear of the properties situated in the first block of the east side of Race Street and running in a southeasterly direction from the south side of Gay Street to a point where it makes a right angle turn, whether such alley is a part of the municipal street system or privately owned. 
(c)  The parking of vehicles as prohibited in this section is a private and public nuisance, whether such alleys are a part of the municipal street system or privately owned. 
(Code 1972, § 21.14) 
Sec. 11-19. - Use of streets by garage operators. 
    No person operating a garage or auto sales or auto repair shop shall park any motor vehicle that is being or is to be repaired, leased, stored or sold by him on any street except on the same side of the street and in front of such garage or shop. No waste matter or things used in or about any auto repair work shall be left on the street after its use, but such items shall be removed by the operator of the garage or repair shop. 
(Code 1972, § 21.15) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and public places, ch. 16. 
Sec. 11-20. - Parking spaces for individuals with disabilities. 
(a)  Spaces established. The commissioners shall establish on the streets and parking lots in the city, at their discretion, parking spaces or zones which shall be marked as restricted for the use of individuals with disabilities. 
(b)  Restriction of use. A person may not stop, stand or park a vehicle, unless said vehicle is properly identified as being for the use of an individual with a disability, in a space or zone marked as restricted for the use of individuals with disabilities. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person violating this section shall be deemed guilty of an infraction and subject to a fine of $40.00. 
(Code 1972, § 21.17; Ord. No. 461; Ord. No. 464; Ord. No. 500; Ord. No. 522; Ord. No. 526, § 1; Ord. No. 580, § 1; Ord. No. 615, § 1, 9-9-79; Ord. No. 620, § 1, 11-26-79; Ord. No. 839, 4-28-97) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Sec. 11-21. - Penalty for violation of articles I and II. 
(a)  Imposition of fine. Except where it is otherwise provided, any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any provision of articles I and II of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of an infraction, the fine for which shall be $25.00, and every day that a violation continues after due notice has been served in conformity with the terms and provisions of Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3(b), shall be deemed a separate offense. This penalty may be used as an alternative to any other penalty that may be available. 
(b)  Failure to pay fine within 30 days. In the event that a fine, issued pursuant to this chapter, is not paid within 30 days of its issuance, then, in that event, a service charge shall be assessed in the amount of the fine, thereby doubling the amount which is due and payable as a result of the infraction. 
(c)  Authority to remove vehicles. In order to provide for a more effective enforcement of the regulations set forth in this chapter, the chief of police is authorized to take possession of and remove, or cause to be removed, any vehicle parked in violation of articles I and II of this chapter. In the event that a vehicle is removed pursuant to this provision, the owner of the vehicle shall be responsible for the cost of removal of the vehicle and the cost of storage of the vehicle. These charges shall be in addition to any fine or other penalty imposed for violation of these articles. 
(Code 1972, § 21.18; Ord. No. 523, § 1; Ord. No. 527, § 1; Ord. No. 614, § 1, 7-9-79; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 8-29-88; Ord. No. 839, 4-28-97) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
ARTICLE III. - SNOW EMERGENCIES 

Sec. 11-22. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Director means the director of public works or his designated representative. 
    Roadway means that portion of a street or highway improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the berm or shoulder. 
    Secondary streets means any streets which are not marked snow emergency routes. 
    Snow emergency routes means those streets marked as such in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
    Snow tires means any tires mounted on drive wheels of motor vehicles which are especially designed to give effective traction on snow-, mud- or ice-covered streets by means of extra heavy duty treads with special high-traction patterns, except that no tire so defined shall be construed to be a snow tire if it is damaged or worn to the extent that its performance would be substantially impaired. 
    Street or highway means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained, when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
    Tire chains means any metal chains mounted on drive wheel tires of motor vehicles which cross the tread of each such tire laterally in at least three different places. 
(Code 1972, § 21.19) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 11-23. - Administrative responsibilities. 
(a)  Mayor. It shall be the responsibility of the mayor to declare the existence of a snow emergency and to also declare the end to such an emergency. He shall act as chief administrator of all forces during the emergency. In the absence of the mayor the director of public works shall act in his stead, and in the absence of the director of public works the chief of police. 
(b)  Director of public works. The director of public works shall be responsible for the removal and plowing of the snow. 
(c)  Chief of police. The chief of police shall be responsible for the movement of traffic and the removal of vehicles from snow emergency routes indicated in this section. 
(Code 1972, § 21.19) 
Sec. 11-24. - Snow emergency routes designated. 
    The following city streets shall be classified as snow emergency routes, and parking shall be restricted on one side, on both sides or on neither side during the snow emergency, in accordance with the following schedule: 
Academy Street, from Gay Street to Washington Street, both sides. 
Aurora Street, from Maryland Avenue to the hospital emergency entrance, west side. 
Bayly Road, from Race Street to the city line, both sides. 
Boundary Avenue, from Goodwill Road to Stone Boundary Road, both sides. 
Cedar Street, from Pine Street to Crusader Road, south side. 
Crusader Road, from U.S. Route 50 to Roselin Avenue, both sides. 
Dorchester Avenue, from Washington Street to Maryland Avenue, both sides. 
Fairmount Avenue, from Rigby Avenue to High Street, north side. 
Gay Street, from High Street to Spring Street, both sides. 
Glasgow Street, from High Street to the city line, north side. 
Glenburn Avenue, from Hambrooks Avenue to Glasgow Street, neither side. 
Goodwill Avenue, from Goodwill Road to Appleby Avenue, both sides. 
Goodwill Road, from Washington Street to Wire Cloth Gate, both sides. 
Hambrooks Avenue, from Choptank Avenue to the city line, north side. 
High Street, from Washington Street to Long Wharf, west side. 
Leonard's Lane, from Glasgow Street to Washington Street, west side. 
Locust Street, from High Street to Glenburn Avenue, north side. 
Mace's Lane, from Washington Street to Bayly Road, both sides. 
Market Street, from Muse Street to bridge, both sides. 
Maryland Avenue, from bridge to U.S. Route 50, neither side. 
Muse Street, from Gay Street to Market Street, both sides. 
Pine Street, from Washington Street to High Street, west side. 
Poplar Street, from Gay Street to High Street, both sides. 
Race Street, from Washington Street to the Cambridge Beltway, both sides. 
Race Street, from Washington Street to Gay Street, both sides. 
Radiance Drive, from Dorchester Avenue to Abaco Road, both sides. 
Rigby Avenue, from Washington Street to Fairmount Avenue, both sides. 
Roselin Avenue, from U.S. Route 50 to Woods Road, north side. 
School Street, from Somerset Avenue to Talbot Avenue, north side. 
Somerset Avenue, from Glasgow Street to School Street, west side. 
Spring Street, from High Street to Gay Street, both sides. 
Stone Boundary Road, from Boundary Avenue to Route 16, both sides. 
Talbot Avenue, from Glasgow Street to School Street, east side. 
Washington Street, from Race Street to city line, both sides. 
Water Street, from High Street to Choptank Avenue, north side. 
Woods Road, from Roselin Avenue to city line, both sides. 
(Code 1972, § 21.19; Ord. No. 559, § 1; Ord. No. 879, 6-5-00) 
Sec. 11-25. - Posting of signs. 
    On each street designated by this article as a snow emergency route, the director shall post special signs at intervals with the wording: "Snow Emergency Route. No Parking During Emergency. Tow Away Zone." These signs shall be distinctive and uniform in appearance and shall be plainly readable to persons traveling on the street or highway. 
(Code 1972, § 21.19) 
Sec. 11-26. - Authority to declare parking prohibition. 
    Whenever the mayor finds, on the basis of falling snow, sleet or freezing rain, or on the basis of a forecast by the U.S. Weather Bureau of snow, sleet or freezing rain, that weather conditions will make it necessary that motor vehicle traffic be expedited and that parking on city streets be prohibited or restricted for snow plowing and other purposes, the mayor shall put into effect a parking prohibition on parts of or all snow emergency routes as necessary, by declaring it in a manner prescribed by this article. 
    Once in effect, a prohibition under this section shall remain in effect until terminated by announcement of the mayor in accordance with this article. While the prohibition is in effect, no person shall park or allow to remain parked any vehicle on any portion of a snow emergency route to which it applies. However, nothing in this section shall be construed to permit parking at any time or place where it is forbidden by any other provision of law. 
(Code 1972, § 21.19; Ord. No. 892, 1-20-01) 
Sec. 11-27. - Termination of parking prohibition. 
    Whenever the mayor shall find that some or all of the conditions which give rise to a parking prohibition in effect pursuant to this article no longer exist, he may declare the prohibition terminated, in whole or in part, in a manner prescribed by this article, effective immediately upon announcement. 
(Code 1972, § 21.19) 
Sec. 11-28. - Stalled vehicles on emergency routes-Duty to keep vehicle in proper condition. 
    No person operating a motor vehicle on a snow emergency route on which there is a covering of snow, sleet or ice shall allow such vehicle to become stalled wholly or partly because the drive wheels are not equipped with effective tire chains or snow tires. 
    No person operating a motor vehicle on a part of a snow emergency route on which there is a covering of snow, sleet or ice or on which there is a parking prohibition in effect shall allow such vehicle to become stalled because the motor fuel is exhausted or the battery has become inoperative. 
(Code 1972, § 21.19) 
Sec. 11-29. - Same-Duty to remove vehicle. 
    Whenever a vehicle becomes stalled for any reason, whether or not in violation of this article, on any part of a snow emergency route on which there is a covering of snow, sleet or ice or on which there is a parking prohibition in effect, the person operating such vehicle shall take immediate action to have the vehicle towed or pushed off the roadway of such snow emergency route, either into the first cross street which is not a snow emergency route, or onto the public space portion of a nearby driveway. No person shall abandon or leave his vehicle in the roadway of a snow emergency route (regardless of whether he indicates by raising the hood, or otherwise, that the vehicle is stalled) except for the purpose of securing assistance during the actual time necessary to go to a nearby telephone or to a nearby garage, gasoline station or other place of assistance and return without delay. 
(Code 1972, § 21.19) 
Sec. 11-30. - Public announcement of declarations. 
    The mayor shall cause each declaration made by him pursuant to this article to be publicly announced by means of radio broadcasts, and he may cause such declaration to be further announced in a newspaper when feasible. Each announcement shall describe the action taken by the mayor, including the time it became or will become effective, and shall specify the streets or areas affected. 
    The mayor shall make or cause to be made a record of each time and date when any declaration is announced to the public in accordance with this section. 
(Code 1972, § 21.19) 
Sec. 11-31. - Precedence of temporary regulations. 
    Any provision of this article which becomes effective by declaration of the mayor or upon the occurrence of certain weather conditions shall, while temporarily in effect, take precedence over other conflicting provisions of law normally in effect; except that such provisions shall not take precedence over provisions of law relating to traffic accidents, emergency travel of authorized emergency vehicles, or emergency traffic directions by a police officer. 
(Code 1972, § 21.19) 
Sec. 11-32. - Removal of vehicles by police; impoundment. 
(a)  Vehicles subject to removal. Members of the police department are hereby authorized to remove or have removed a vehicle from a street to the nearest garage or other place of safety (including another place on a street), or to a garage designated by the police department, when: 
(1)  The vehicle is parked on a part of a snow emergency route on which a parking prohibition is in effect. 
(2)  The vehicle is stalled on a part of a snow emergency route on which there is a covering of snow, sleet or ice on which there is a parking prohibition in effect and the person who was operating such vehicle does not appear to be removing it in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(3)  The vehicle is parked in violation of any parking ordinance or provision of law and is interfering or about to interfere with snow removal operations. 
(b)  Notice to owner. Whenever an officer removes or has removed a vehicle from a street as authorized in this section and the officer knows or is able to ascertain from the registration records in the vehicle the name and address of the owner thereof, such officer shall immediately give or cause to be given notice in writing to such owner of the fact of such removal and the reasons therefor, and of the place to which such vehicle has been removed. 
(c)  Procedure upon inability to give notice to owner. Whenever an officer removes or has removed a vehicle from a street under this section and does not know and is not able to ascertain the name of the owner, or for any other reason is unable to give the notice to the owner as provided in this section, and, in the event the vehicle is not returned to the owner within a period of three days, then and in the event the officer shall immediately send or cause to be sent a written report of such removal by mail to the department of motor vehicles and file a copy of such notice with the proprietor of any public garage in which the vehicle may be stored. Such notice shall include a complete description of the vehicle, the date, time and place from which removed, the reasons for such removal, and the name of the garage or place where the vehicle is stored. 
(d)  Recovery by owner. No person shall recover any vehicle removed in accordance with this section except as provided in this subsection. Before the owner or person in charge of such vehicle shall be allowed to recover it from the place where it has been placed or impounded, he shall present to the personnel of the business at which the vehicle has been placed or impounded, evidence of his identity and right to possession of the vehicle, shall sign a receipt for its return, and shall pay the cost of removal, and shall pay any cost of storage accrued. 
(e)  Records. It shall be the duty of the police department to keep a record of each vehicle removed in accordance with this section. The record shall include a description of the vehicle, its license number, the date and time of its removal, where it was removed from, its location, the name and address of its owner and last operator, if known, its final disposition, and the parking violation involved. 
(f)  Provisions of section supplemental. This section shall be supplemental to any other provisions of law granting members of the police department authority to remove vehicles. 
(Code 1972, § 21.19; Ord. No. 892, 1-29-01) 
Sec. 11-33. - Issuance of citation; penalty for violation of article. 
    Whenever any motor vehicle without a driver is found parked or left in violation of any provision of this article, and is not removed and impounded as provided for in this section, the officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number and any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user, and shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a citation charging the owner with a municipal infraction, the fine for which shall be $25.00, and every day that a violation continues, after due notice has been served in conformity with the terms and provisions of Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3(b), shall be deemed a separate offense. This penalty may be used as an alternative to any other penalty that may be available. 
(Code 1972, § 21.19; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 8-29-88) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Sec. 11-34. - Failure to comply with citation. 
    If a violator of this article does not appear in response to a traffic citation affixed to such motor vehicle in accordance with this article within a period of five days, the city clerk shall send the owner of the motor vehicle to which the traffic citation was affixed a letter informing him of the violation and warning him that, in the event such letter is disregarded for a period of 30 days, a warrant of arrest will be issued. 
(Code 1972, § 21.19) 
Sec. 11-35. - Evidence of violation. 
    In any prosecution with regard to a vehicle parked or left in a place or in a condition in violation of any provision of this article, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked or left in violation of a provision of this article, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute prima facie evidence that the defendant was the person who parked or left the vehicle in violation of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 21.19) 
ARTICLE IV. - BICYCLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate bicycles, Ann. Code of Md. art. Transportation, § 25-102(a)(8); bicycles generally, Ann. Code of Md. art. Transportation, § 21-1201 et seq. 

Sec. 11-36. - Inspection; permit card and license tag. 
    Every operator of a bicycle within the city shall submit his machine, on or before January 1 of each year, for inspection as to brakes, lights, signalling devices, tires, wheels, frame and handlebars, and such other inspection as may be required. The inspection shall be made under the supervision of the police department, and if the examination is satisfactory the operator shall be given a permit card, bearing an identifying number, certifying that the bicycle has been satisfactorily inspected. All of the permit cards shall expire on December 31 in each year, after which time all bicycles are subject to the annual examination and issuance of a new permit card. No person shall operate any bicycle in the city without having first obtained such permit card. A license tag bearing the same number as the permit card shall be attached to each bicycle, and shall remain thereon constantly. Such operator of a bicycle shall be required to pay a fee, to be established from time to time by the board of commissioners, at the time such permit card and license tag are issued. 
(Code 1972, § 22.02; Ord. No. 487, § 1) 
Sec. 11-37. - Rules of operation. 
    The operator of any bicycle upon the streets of the city shall not carry any other person upon the bicycle, and it shall be unlawful for any other person than the operator to ride upon such bicycle. No person while riding a bicycle shall hang onto any other vehicle while the same is in motion. No person shall proceed along the streets abreast of more than one other bicycle proceeding in the same direction. No person while riding a bicycle shall ride same upon any sidewalk or pavement of the city. 
(Code 1972, § 22.02) 
Sec. 11-38. - Records of persons trading in secondhand bicycles or parts; purchases from minors. 
    Every person engaged in the business of buying, selling, exchanging or trading in new, used or secondhand bicycles shall keep a daily record of all used or secondhand bicycles bought, exchanged or traded in and of all used or secondhand parts of bicycles bought by each person during the preceding day. Each such record shall specify a full and complete description of such used or secondhand bicycle or used or secondhand bicycle parts, and, in addition thereto, wherever available, the serial number, factory number, frame number, color, type, model, frame size, wheel size, name of brake and other marks of identification, and the date of purchase or trade, together with the name, address, age, height and weight of the person or persons selling or trading in such bicycle. No person engaged in the buying of secondhand bicycles shall purchase any secondhand bicycle from a minor under 18 years of age. 
(Code 1972, § 22.03) 
Sec. 11-39. - Removing or altering frame number; report of change in ownership; damaging or removing license plate or registration card. 
    No person shall wilfully or maliciously remove, destroy, mutilate or alter the number of any bicycle frame licensed pursuant to this article. Within seven days after any bicycle registered under this article shall change ownership or be dismantled and taken out of operation, the person in whose name the bicycle has been registered shall report such information to the police department. No person shall remove, destroy, mutilate or alter any license plate, seal or registration card. 
(Code 1972, § 22.04) 
Sec. 11-40. - Suspension of registration; impoundment. 
    The chief of police, or some reliable person designated by him, shall have authority to suspend the registration, remove the license tag and retain possession of any bicycle operated contrary to any state law or city ordinance. Such suspension, removal and possession is to continue for a period not to exceed 30 days and shall be in addition to other penalties provided for under this article. Registration cards shall be shown to any police officers on demand or when ordered to appear for any violation of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 22.05) 
Sec. 11-41. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Except where it is otherwise provided, any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of an infraction, the fine for which shall be $20.00, and every day that a violation continues, after due notice has been served in conformity with the terms and provisions of Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3(b), shall be deemed a separate offense. This penalty may be used as an alternative to any other penalty that may be available. 
(Code 1972, § 22.06; Ord. No. 735, § 1, 8-29-88) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Chapter 12 - OFFENSES-MISCELLANEOUS 

Sec. 12-1. - Loitering. 
(a)  As used in this section, the word "loitering" shall mean remaining idle in essentially one location, and shall include the concept of spending time idly or loafing or walking about aimlessly, and shall also include the colloquial expression "hanging around." Public places shall include not only streets, alleys and sidewalks, but also those establishments generally open for the public convenience. 
(b)  No person shall loiter in a public place in such manner as to: 
(1)  Create or cause to be created a danger of a breach of the peace. 
(2)  Create or cause to be created any disturbance or annoyance to the comfort and repose of any person. 
(3)  Obstruct the free passage of pedestrians or vehicles. 
(4)  Obstruct, molest or interfere with any person lawfully in any public place. 
    This subsection shall include the making of unsolicited remarks of an offensive, disgusting or insulting nature, or which are calculated to annoy or disturb the person to or in whose hearing they are made. 
(c)  Whenever the presence of any person in any public place is causing or is likely to cause any of the conditions enumerated in subsection (b) of this section, any police officer may order that person to leave that place. Any person who shall refuse to leave after being ordered to do so by a police officer shall be guilty of a violation of this section. 
(d)  Any person violating this section may be deemed to be guilty of an infraction, the fine for which shall be $50.00. Repeat offenses occurring within a period of one year from the initial violation shall be subject to a fine of $100.00. 
(Ord. No. 618, § 1, 10-15-79; Ord. No. 690, § 1, 2-11-85) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 618, § 1, adopted Oct. 15, 1979, repealed former § 12-1 relative to assemblies and enacted a new § 12-1 relative to loitering. The former provisions derived from Code 1972, § 23.05A. 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Sec. 12-2. - Disorderly conduct. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the corporate limits of the city to disturb, tend to disturb or aid in disturbing the peace of others by violent, tumultuous, offensive or obstreperous conduct, and no person shall knowingly permit such conduct upon any premises owned or possessed by him or under his control. Any person violating this section may be deemed to be guilty of an infraction, the fine for which shall be $50.00. Repeat offenses occurring within a period of one year from the initial violation shall be subject to a fine of $100.00. 
(Ord. No. 477; Ord. No. 689, § 1, 2-11-85) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3; disturbing the peace and disorderly conduct, Ann. Code of Md. art. Criminal Law, § 10-201. 
Sec. 12-3. - Disorderly houses. 
    No person shall keep any disorderly house, any bawdy house or any house where persons meet for purposes of prostitution, or any house, building, tenement or outhouse for gambling or for disorderly or other disreputable purposes, including the maintenance of a common nuisance as defined in Ann. Code of Md. art. 27, as from time to time amended, and no owner, occupant, tenant or person in charge of any house, building, tenement, outbuilding or outhouse or any room or apartment thereof shall allow or permit the same to be used for the purposes enumerated in this section. Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than $5.00 and not more than $100.00. 
(Code 1972, § 23.19; Ord. No. 497, § 1) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3; keeping disorderly house, Ann. Code of Md. art. Criminal Law, § 10-202. 
Sec. 12-4. - Disturbances. 
    No person shall indulge in loud and boisterous talking or laughing, engage in the blowing of horns, or with the voice or by any other means make any loud or unseemly noises to the disturbance of the quiet or comfort of the people who may reside or be in the neighborhood. Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than $1.00 and not more than $100.00. 
(Code 1972, § 23.05) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3; disturbing the peace and disorderly conduct, Ann. Code of Md. art. Criminal Law, § 10-201. 
Sec. 12-5. - Siphoning water from fire protection service equipment. 
    No person except recognized fire departments for purposes of extinguishing fires and the city shall take any water from any fire hydrant or other fire protection service apparatus or equipment, including sprinkler systems, without the express permission of the municipal utilities commission, which permission is subject to such rules and regulations as may be prescribed by the municipal utilities commission. Any person who shall violate this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction by a court of competent jurisdiction shall be fined not more than $500.00 or be imprisoned for not more than one year, or both. 
(Code 1972, § 6.09; Ord. No. 780, § 1, 3-2-92; Ord. No. 833, 9-23-96) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
Cross reference- Fire protection, ch. 6; water, ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Sec. 12-6. - Gambling. 
(a)  No person in any house or vessel or at any place on land or water within the corporate limits of the city shall participate in any game or gaming device which is not permitted by the laws of the State of Maryland. 
(b)  No owner, tenant, or occupant of any building, house, vessel or place on land or water shall knowingly permit any game or gaming device to be played for money, stakes, wagers or any other thing of value which is not permitted by the laws of the State of Maryland, in such building, house, vessel or place, or in any part of any building, house, vessel or place owned or occupied by him, or of which he is a tenant. 
(c)  The prohibitions set forth in this section shall not apply to any game, gaming device or activity which is expressly permitted by the laws, statutes and/or regulations of the State of Maryland. Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than $5.00 and not more than $25.00. 
(Code 1972, § 23.15; Ord. No. 903, 4-22-02) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3; gaming, Ann. Code of Md. art. Criminal Law, § 12-101 et seq.; gaming events in certain counties including Dorchester County, Ann. Code. of Md. art. Criminal Law § 13-201 et seq.; gaming in Dorchester County, Ann. Code of Md. art. Criminal Law, § 13-1201 et seq. 
Sec. 12-7. - Indecent acts. 
(a)  No person in any house or building, outhouse or outbuilding, or other place where people are assembled shall make any indecent exposure of the person, or perform any indecent pantomime or any indecent drama or play, or sing or give any indecent or lewd songs or speeches. 
(b)  No person shall offer to sell any foul, indecent or lewd papers, pamphlets, books or pictures. 
(c)  Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than $5.00 and not more than $100.00, or be imprisoned for not less than ten days. 
(Code 1972, § 23.17) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83.

Sec. 12-8. - Indecent language. 
    Any person who shall indulge in loud cursing, swearing or profane or indecent language within the hearing of persons passing on the streets, sidewalks or public places in the city shall be fined not less than $1.00 and not more than $100.00. 
(Code 1972, § 23.18) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3; obscene matter generally, Ann. Code of Md. art. Criminal Law, § 11-201 et seq. 
Sec. 12-9. - Minors in pool halls. 
    No owner, manager, operator or person in charge of any place where pool or billiards is played shall permit any minor under the age of 18 years to play pool or billiards or to loaf or loiter in such place. No minor under the age of 18 years shall play pool or billiards in or loaf or loiter in any public pool or billiard room or place. Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than $5.00 and not more than $25.00. 
(Code 1972, § 23.14)

Sec. 12-10. - Missiles, throwing. 
    Any person who shall throw any brick, ball, snowball or other missile at any person or car along any street, sidewalk or public place, or in such manner as to frighten or annoy any person, shall be fined not less than $5.00 and not more than $100.00. 
(Code 1972, § 23.03; Ord. No. 498, § 1) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Sec. 12-11. - Police officers, impersonating. 
    No person, not being an officer of the city, shall impersonate any police officer or falsely represent or pretend that he is a police officer. No person shall wear in public the uniform, badge or insignia prescribed for the peace officers of the city, without the authority of the chief of police. Any person violating this section shall be fined not more than $100.00 for each and every violation of this section. 
(Code 1972, § 23.13; Ord. No. 450, § 1)

Sec. 12-12. - Property offenses-Damaging public property. 
    Any person who shall injure, mutilate, disfigure, deface or damage any of the real or personal property belonging to the city or any of its agencies shall be fined not less than $100.00 and not more than $500.00, or be imprisoned for not more than 30 days. Any person committing any of the acts enumerated in this section shall make full restitution of the damages done to the city. 
(Code 1972, § 23.09; Ord. No. 647, § 1, 11-9-81; Ord. No. 671, § 1, 10-31-83)

Sec. 12-13. - Same-Damaging cemetery property. 
    No person shall, without the consent or authority of those in charge thereof, injure, mutilate, deface or destroy any wall or fence enclosing any burial ground or graveyard or cemetery, or disfigure, deface, injure, mutilate or destroy any gravestone or monument in such burial ground or graveyard or cemetery, or injure, cut down or destroy any tree or shrub or open or attempt to open any grave therein. Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than $5.00 and not more than $100.00, or be imprisoned for not more than 30 days.

    No person shall deface or disfigure the walls or other parts of any private dwelling house or any shop, store or other house or building belonging to private individuals, or interfere with any such house, shop, store or other house or building by taking down signs, or by removing knockers, shutters or doors therefrom, or by piling up wood, lumber, boxes or other obstructions against or in front thereof. One-half of any fine imposed for violation of this section may be appropriated by the commissioners to the owner of the property to compensate the owner for injuries. Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than $1.00 and not more than $100.00. 
(Code 1972, § 23.11)

Sec. 12-15. - Refuse, dumping. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dump earth, dirt, sand, ashes, garbage, gravel, rocks, trees, bricks, refuse, debris or other matter upon any property within the corporate limits of the city, without written permission from the owner or owners thereof. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction before a court of competent jurisdiction shall be fined not less than $10.00 and not more than $100.00 for each and every offense, and shall stand committed to jail until such fine and costs are paid, and each and every violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1972, § 23.20) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, ch. 8; discharge of refuse into city waters, § 19-35. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3; littering, Ann. Code of Md. art. Criminal Law, § 10-110. 
Sec. 12-16. - Unlawful urination and defecation; acts of urination and/or defecation prohibited on public or private property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to urinate and/or defecate: 
(1)  On any public street, alley, parking lot or sidewalk, or on the ground or floor of any other place where the public has the right to gather, or to which the public has access; or 
(2)  On any public or private property within the city unless these acts are performed into a toilet or other device designed and intended for the receipt or disposal of such wastes. 
(3)  Penalty. Any person who violates this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction is subject to a fine of $50.00 for the first offense and $100.00 for each subsequent offense, or imprisonment not exceeding 30 days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 1086, 7-11-16) 
Sec. 12-17. - Theaters and public halls, crowding aisles and passageways. 
    No person in charge of any public hall or theater shall allow any person, during the time that the public hall or theater is open for public use and filled or partly filled with people, to stand or sit in the aisles or passageways of such public hall or theater. 
(Code 1972, § 23.08) 
Sec. 12-18. - Weapons-Discharge of firearms. 
(a)  No person shall discharge any cannon, gun, rifle, pistol, pellet gun, bb-gun, dart gun or any other firearm within the corporate limits of the city, unless otherwise permitted by exemption set forth in subsection (b) hereof. 
(b)  Exemptions. This provision, however, shall not apply to: 
(1)  Supervised pyrotechnic displays, to the discharge of cannons for ceremonial purposes, or to the abatement of nuisances when the city police department determines such act to be necessary or causes the same to be actively supervised, and the city council approves such activity; or 
(2)  The discharge of a firearm for the purpose of self-defense within the owner's home. 
(c)  Any person violating this section may be deemed to be guilty of an infraction, the fine for which shall be $100.00. 
(d)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit or restrict the legal possession of a firearm within the city, or the reasonable discharge of the firearm for the purpose of the self-defense within the home. 
(Code 1972, § 23.01; Ord. No. 674, § 1, 1-23-84; Ord. No. 987, 5-11-09) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3; handgun permits, Ann. Code of Md. art. Public Safety, § 5-301 et seq.; sale of deadly weapons to minors, Ann. Code of Md. art. Public Safety § 5-134. 
Sec. 12-19. - Same-Concealed weapons. 
    No person in the corporate limits shall wear under his clothes or conceal about his person or display in a threatening manner any dangerous or deadly weapon with intent to use it unlawfully against another, including but not limited to any pistol, revolver, slingshot, cross knuckles or knuckles of lead, brass or other metal, or any dagger, dirk, razor, stiletto or knife with a blade longer than three inches or switch blade or device whereby the blade or blades can be opened by a mechanical contrivance, or garrote, billy or other heavy device intended to batter another, and for the purposes of this section the term "dangerous weapons" shall include imitation pistols. Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than $25.00 and not more than $300.00, or be imprisoned for not more than six months, or both. 
(Ord. No. 478) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3; carrying or wearing concealed weapons, Ann. Code of Md. art. Criminal Law, § 4-101. 
Sec. 12-20. - Worship, disturbance of. 
    No person shall enter any church or other place of divine or religious worship and by unseemly acts, noises or words interfere with or disturb such worship or services. No person shall with intent to disturb any religious service make any loud and unseemly noises or cries or indulge in any unseemly conduct on the outside of any church or other place of worship. Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than $5.00 and not more than $100.00. 
(Code 1972, § 23.07) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3; disturbing the peace, Ann. Code of Md. art. Criminal Law, § 10-201. 
Sec. 12-21. - Possession of alcoholic beverages in open containers in certain places. 
(a)  A person may not possess in an open container any alcoholic beverage, as defined in Ann. Code of Md. art. 2B, while: 
(1)  On the mall adjacent parking area, or other outside area of any combination of privately owned retail establishments, commonly known as a shopping center, to which the general public is invited for business purposes, unless authorized by the owner of the establishment; 
(2)  On an adjacent parking area or other outside area of any other retail establishment, unless authorized by the owner of the establishment; 
(3)  In any public park or publicly owned land, unless properly licensed therefor; 
(4)  In any parked vehicle located on any of the places enumerated in this section, unless authorized; or 
(5)  On any property generally open to the public for purposes of amusement or recreation, either publicly or privately owned, unless properly licensed. 
(b)  Anyone who shall violate any provision of this section shall be deemed guilty of an infraction, the fine for which shall be $50.00. 
(Ord. No. 695, § 1, 7-29-85; Ord. No. 698, § 1, 8-28-85) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and public places, ch. 16. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Sec. 12-22. - Operational standards and restrictions in the arts and entertainment district. 
(a)  Operational standards and restrictions. Property owners and business owners within this arts and entertainment district shall comply with the following general standards and limitations: 
(1)  No business shall be open to the general public between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m., unless otherwise exempted herein. 
(2)  No use or combination thereof shall present or pose a threat to the health, welfare, or safety of neighboring residences or general public. 
(b)  Exceptions. The following businesses shall be permitted to be open to the general public at all hours within the arts and entertainment district: 
(1)  Medical offices, dental offices and pharmacies; 
(2)  Transportation service businesses, including taxi-cab businesses, limousine service businesses, and bus charter businesses; 
(3)  Hotels, motels, inns, and bed & breakfast businesses, with the exception of any restaurant, bar, lounge and nightclub facility located within such a business shall not be open to the public between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. 
(c)  Penalty for violation. Any person, business or corporation owning a building within the arts and entertainment district, and/or any person, business or corporation operating a business within the arts and entertainment district, which violates any provision of this section shall be deemed guilty of an infraction, the fine for which shall not to exceed $1,000.00, and every day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1023, 4-23-12) 
Chapter 13 - PERSONNEL[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 820, adopted Nov. 13, 1995, amended ch. 13 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former ch. 13 contained §§ 13-1-13-11, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 609. 
Charter reference- Salaries, § 3-23.

Sec. 13-1. - Policies and procedures; administering. 
    The city shall adopt personnel policies and procedures from time to time. Responsibilities for administering the personnel system shall be set forth in the personnel policies and procedures. 
(Ord. No. 820, §§ 1-3, 11-13-95) 
Sec. 13-2. - Ethics and conduct; political activities. 
(a)  No employee shall directly use or seek to use his official position, authority or influence to control or modify the political action of any other person, nor shall any employee, during duty hours, engage in any form of political activity other than by casting his own ballot. 
(b)  No elected or appointed officer or employee of the city shall accept any gift, favor or service that might reasonably tend to improperly influence him in the discharge of official duties. 
(c)  No public officer or employee shall be employed or be engaged in any business or professional activity with commercial enterprises conducting business with the city when such person is, by virtue of his city employment, in a position to influence the acceptance and consummation of such business or provide significant information not generally made available to other similar commercial enterprises. 
(d)  Any individual employed by the city whose principal employment is in connection with an activity which is financed in whole or in part by loans or grants made by the United States or a federal agency may not: 
(1)  Use his official authority or influence for the purpose of interfering with or affecting the result of an election or nomination for office. 
(2)  Directly or indirectly coerce, attempt to coerce, command or advise a state or local officer or employee to pay, lend or contribute anything of value to a party, committee, organization, agency or person for political purposes. 
(3)  Take an active part in partisan political management or in political campaigns. 
(e)  Nothing contained in this section shall affect the right of an officer or employee of the city to hold membership in and support a political party, to vote, to express publicly or privately opinions on all political subjects and candidates, to maintain political neutrality and to actively participate in political meetings. However, the officer or employee must engage in all such activities as a private citizen and shall not engage in these activities while on city premises, during working hours or while on duty in service to the city. 
(f)  Violation of any provision of this section shall constitute grounds for dismissal. Officers or employees shall have the right to appeal a dismissal, as provided in the personnel regulations. 
(Ord. No. 820, §§ 1-3, 11-13-95) 
Cross reference- Ethics, § 2-14. 
Chapter 14 - PLUMBING AND SEWERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of city to enforce plumbing regulations, § 3-27(51); municipal utilities commission, § 3-43; sewer system generally § 3-44; financing and constructing utilities, § 3-45; sewage treatment plant, § 3-46. 
Cross reference- Extraterritorial sewer service, § 2-16; buildings and housing, ch. 4; health and sanitation, ch. 8; license for septage haulers, § 10-10; underground utilities, § 16-23; subdivisions, ch. 17; utilities in mobile home parks, § 17-28; water, ch. 18; sanitary facilities for marinas, § 19-32; watercraft toilets, § 19-33; discharge of refuse, sewage, etc., into city waters, § 19-35; swimming pools, § 20-5(b). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Adoption of plumbing code; fees. 
(a)  The State Plumbing Code of the state department of licensing and regulation, adopted June 1, 1972, as revised and as may be revised from time to time, is hereby adopted as the plumbing code of the city, excepting amendments made to section .09.20.12.02, subsections A(1) and (2), which amendment shall read as follows: 
    A(1) Every part of a building sewer shall be coated or uncoated service weight cast iron pipe. This provision may be waived by the city if a satisfactory substitute is used. 
(b)  The plumbing inspector may establish such fees as he deems advisable, subject to the approval of the commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 458, § 1; Ord. No. 596, § 1) 
Sec. 14-2. - Sewer taps. 
(a)  Permit required. No person shall tap, enter, join or connect with any public sewer within the city, or cause the tapping, entering, joining or connecting with any sewer, without a permit from the commissioners authorizing such tapping, entering, joining or connecting with the public sewer. 
(b)  Application for permit; fee. The application for the permit required in this section shall be made by the owner or lessee of the property to be served by the sewer, or by the agent of either, or by a licensed plumber employed in connection with the proposed work. The application shall show the name of the plumber who is to make the tap, who must hold a master plumber's certificate. The application shall be accompanied by a fee or tapping charge, to be established from time to time by the director of public works with the approval of the city council, for each dwelling or other building containing not more than two apartments or separate family living units, and an additional fee or charge, to be established from time to time by the director of public works with the approval of the city council, for each and every apartment or separate family living unit over two contained in the building sought to be connected. No permit shall be issued until such charges have been paid. 
(c)  Inspection fee. In addition to the fee or charge provided for in subsection (b) of this section, an inspection fee, as from time to time established, shall be paid to the commissioners by the applicant before the issuance of the permit. The city engineer or his duly authorized agent or employee shall have the right of entry at all reasonable hours upon any private property and premises within the city for the purpose of inspecting sewer connections and making necessary repairs or improvements, and he shall not be restrained or hindered in such entry by any owner, tenant or other person. 
(d)  Connection.
