No. 646, § 1, adopted Sept. 14, 1981; and Ord. No. 661, § 1, adopted May 9, 1983. 
Sec. 14-13. - Pollution control fund. 
(1)  All charges and fees, including but not limited to application fees, permit fees, monitoring fees, laboratory fees and treatment and disposal fees, rendered and collected by the city for carrying out the pretreatment program, as well as any civil or administrative penalty or any fine imposed by a court under the provisions of this section, shall be paid into the pollution control fund. 
(2)  The control authority shall use the pollution control fund for activities that are related to identifying, monitoring and regulating proper discharge into the city's sewage collection system and POTW. 
(3)  Notwithstanding any law to the contrary, unexpended monies in the fund shall not revert to the city's general fund at the end of a fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 774, § 1, 7-8-91) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 14-12. 
Chapter 15 - POLICE COMMISSIONERS[1] 
  

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of city to establish police force, § 3-27(47); police force generally, § 3-31. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; personnel, ch. 13. 
State Law reference- Police mutual aid agreements, Ann. Code of Md. art. 27, § 602B. 

Sec. 15-1. - Generally. 
(a)  There is hereby created a police advisory board, consisting of seven members. The members of the police advisory board shall consist of the mayor, a resident of each ward of the city nominated by the commissioner for that ward, and a resident of the city nominated by the mayor. 
(b)  Each city commissioner has the right of nominating one person from the ward of his residence to serve on the police advisory board, and the mayor has the right of nominating one person who is a resident of the city; all of whom are subject to the approval of the majority of the Commissioners of Cambridge. In the event of a vacancy, the commissioner from the ward in which the person creating the vacancy left, has the privilege of nominating someone to fill the vacancy subject to the approval of a majority of the commissioners. The members so appointed must be over the age of 21 years and a resident of the city. 
(c)  The said members of the advisory board shall serve at the pleasure of the commissioners, and shall be responsible for advising the police department on complaints from the citizens and improvements in the operation of the police department. The board shall also be responsible for making recommendations to the city council for areas in which police activities can better serve the citizens of Cambridge. 
(d)  The police advisory board shall meet bi-monthly and at such other times as may be necessary only upon the call of the chairman or when the said chairman instructs the vice-chairman to call same. 
(e)  The chairman and his duly authorized representative of the advisory board shall report quarterly to the commissioners or at such times as the commissioners' request. 
(Code 1972, § 23A.01; Ord. No. 451, § 1; Ord. No. 681, 7-30-84; Ord. No. 803, 1-13-94; Ord. No. 831, 8-5-96; Ord. No. 863, 1-25-99; Ord. No. 893, 9-11-00; Ord. No. 890, 1-22-01; Ord. No. 907, 10-28-02) 
Sec. 15-2. - Duties; appointment of police officer; police force. 
    The city commissioners are authorized and required to maintain at all times a trained police force suitable to the needs and requirements of the city. The term of service of any member of the police force so appointed shall commence on the day of his/her appointment, provided, that the member shall have fulfilled the minimum requirements of the job classification and passed all appropriate testing. The commissioners shall arm and equip such police force as to them may seem proper under such rules and regulations as they may from time to time prescribe. The number of police officers who shall comprise the police force of the city shall be increased from time to time as in the discretion of the city commissioners may be appropriate. The chief of police of the police department of the city shall be appointed by the city commissioners and serve at their pleasure. The salaries of the police force shall be paid in conformity with the personnel policy, as it from time to time may exist, by the city treasurer from the general levy made for the purpose of maintaining a police department in such sums as the commissioners may designate. 
(Code 1972, § 23A.02; Ord. No. 452, § 1; Ord. No. 491, § 1; Ord. No. 610, § 1; Ord. No. 907, 10-28-02) 
Sec. 15-3. - Examinations for police officers. 
    Whenever a vacancy may occur in the police force, the police department shall hold a preliminary examination for applicants for police officers. Any applicant therefore must have reached his twenty-first birthday. The applicant must be a citizen of the United States and possess a high school diploma or a general educational development certificate recognized by the board of education. The applicant must be of good moral character and emotionally stable as determined by a comprehensive background investigation, which includes fingerprints of the applicant, a search made of local, state and national criminal record files and random drug testing. A conviction for any state or federal crime may be grounds for rejection of the applicant by the police department. The investigation may also include a check of military records, local draft board records, school records and credit agency records. Personal references given by the applicant may be interviewed to aid in determining the applicant's habits and fitness for police duties. The applicant will be examined by a licensed physician in order to determine his/her physical, emotional and physiological fitness for normal police functions. The police department shall have prepared a written examination to be given the applicant and may also conduct an oral interview to assess the applicant's abilities. Applicants that satisfactorily pass the examination and meet the minimum requirements outlined in this section, in addition to have successfully completed the Maryland Police and Correctional Office Training Academy may be appointed as a probationary officer for the city, with all the powers and duties of a regular police officer, for a period of one year. Upon the satisfactory completion of said one-year probationary period, the said probationary officer may be appointed a regular police officer of the city to serve as may be now provided by law. 
(Code 1972, § 23A.03; Ord. No. 907, 10-28-02) 
Sec. 15-4. - Authority to provide for headquarters alarm receiving unit. 
    The board of police commissioners is hereby authorized to enter into such instruments which may be required for the installation of a headquarters alarm receiving unit. The board of police commissioners may, in its discretion, grant the exclusive right for the installation and maintenance of a headquarters alarm receiving unit to one firm or individual, or it may, in its discretion, grant such rights to more than one firm or individual. 
(Ord. No. 587, § 1) 
Chapter 16 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
  

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Authority of city to remove obstructions from streets, § 3-27(43); authority of city to regulate use of sidewalks, § 3-27(52); power of city with regard to streets, § 3-29; sidewalks generally, § 3-36. 
Cross reference- Duties of city forester, § 2-2; allowing animals to go into streets, § 3-2; building numbers, § 4-90 et seq.; peddler's license, § 10-2; motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 11; use of streets by garage operators, § 11-19; possession of alcoholic beverages in open containers prohibited in certain places, § 12-21; subdivisions, ch. 17. 
State Law reference- General authority relative to streets, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 2(b)(28). 

Sec. 16-1. - Obstruction of street or sidewalk-Generally. 
(a)  No person shall place in or along any street, public alley or sidewalk anything which obstructs, in whole or in part, any street, public alley or sidewalk or interferes with or endangers the free passage of any person or vehicle, without the permission of the commissioners with such conditions as they may choose to impose, or except as provided in this chapter. Any sidewalk, however, which exceeds the width prescribed by the specifications adopted by the department of public works, may be utilized by the owner or occupant of the abutting property, with the prior approval of the city council, to the extent of 100 percent of the excess width so long as such area utilized is adjacent to the abutting property, and so long as such use is in full compliance with the requirements and specifications set forth in the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), or other applicable federal, state or local law or regulation, as amended from time to time. The approval granted pursuant to this article shall constitute a license, which license may be rescinded by the commissioners should the use of the excess width be found: (1) not to comply with any federal, state or local law or regulation, as amended; (2) to create a safety hazard; (3) not to be maintained in a safe, clean and attractive manner, or (4) to adversely affect the public health, safety and/or general welfare. For the purpose of this section, chattels of evicted tenants shall be considered an obstruction, and the person or landlord responsible for creating such obstruction shall be subject to penalties contained in this chapter. 
(b)  No person shall place any materials on property belonging to the city without a permit; except that any commercial or industrial establishment may, for decorative purposes, place ferns or flowers on the sidewalk directly in front of its property if such ferns or flowers do not unreasonably interfere with pedestrian traffic. The right to withdraw this exception at any time is reserved to the commissioners. 
(c)  The term "public alley," as used in this section, means any alley or way dedicated to the use of the public at large, and does not mean any private alley generally restricted to the use of the adjoining property owners and their invitees and agents. In the event that there is any question as to whether an alley is public or private, it shall be deemed to be private. 
(Code 1972, § 4.01; Ord. No. 561, § 1; Ord. No. 523, § 1; Ord. No. 717, § 1, 9-21-87; Ord. No. 737, § 1, 8-29-88; Ord. No. 790, § 1, 1-11-93; Ord. No. 1022, 4-23-12) 
Sec. 16-2. - Same-Goods. 
    When any materials or goods or chattels are deposited on any street, public alley or sidewalk to be afterwards carried to or upon the premises of the person to whom the materials belong, the owner or person having control or charge thereof shall remove such materials within six hours after they have been deposited. Upon notice from the chief of police or any police officer, the person shall remove the materials as directed. 
(Code 1972, § 4.02; Ord. No. 561, § 1; Ord. No. 738, § 1, 8-29-88) 
Sec. 16-3. - Same-Building materials. 
    A permit shall be obtained from the commissioners before placing any building materials on or along any street, public alley or sidewalk. If need of using such things is urgent, the mayor and one other commissioner may grant a permit until the next meeting of the commissioners. The person receiving the permit shall conform to the conditions of the permit and any directions that the chief of police may issue in connection with such permit. Obstructions shall be adequately provided with warning lights at night. 
(Code 1972, § 4.03; Ord. No. 561, § 1; Ord. No. 738, § 1, 8-29-88) 
Cross reference- Buildings and housing, ch. 4. 
Sec. 16-4. - Same-Encroachments. 
    No person shall erect or place in, along or across any street, public alley or sidewalk any fence or enclosure or any building or other structure which shall include or obstruct any part of any street, public alley or sidewalk; or cut any ditch or trench along such street, public alley or sidewalk so as to include any part thereof. Upon notice from the chief of police or any police officer, the encroachment shall be removed as directed. 
(Code 1972, § 4.04; Ord. No. 561, § 1; Ord. No. 738, § 1, 8-29-88) 
Sec. 16-5. - Same-Removal of obstructions. 
    Any obstruction or encroachment on any street shall be removed or so dealt with under the order of the commissioners that the street is restored to its proper condition. The commissioners shall, by an order directed to the chief of police, give notice to the person to remove the obstruction or encroachment or to appear before the commissioners and show cause to the contrary. If such person fails to appear, the commissioners may, by further order, make provision for removal of the obstruction or encroachment. 
(Code 1972, § 4.05; Ord. No. 738, § 1, 8-29-88) 
Sec. 16-6. - Bicycling, skating and skateboarding. 
(a)  Prohibition. It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or operate a bicycle, skateboard, scooter or roller skates upon any sidewalk or pavement in any commercial or business district in the city, or in a block of a residential district in which a notice is posted which prohibits such acts. It shall be unlawful for any person above the age of 14 years to ride a bicycle or tricycle upon any public sidewalk or pavement in any residential zoning district in the city. The term "pavement" shall not be construed to mean public street or highway. It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or operate a skateboard, scooter or roller skates upon any street, public parking lot or public right-of-way unless otherwise specifically designated. 
(b)  Special vehicles for handicapped persons permitted. Wheelchairs and special vehicles for handicapped persons may be operated on sidewalks and pavements in the city, pursuant to Ann. Code of Md. § 21-1102 of the State Transportation Article. 
(c)  Penalty for violation. Any person who shall violate this provision shall be deemed guilty of an infraction, the fine for which shall be $25.00. 
(Code 1972, § 4.06; Ord. No. 710, 9-30-86; Ord. No. 894, 6-4-01) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 11. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Sec. 16-7. - Barbed wire fences. 
    No person shall erect any enclosure of barbed wire extending along any street, alley or thoroughfare, and no person shall place barbed wire on the outside of any enclosure extending along any street, alley or thoroughfare or on top of any such enclosure, unless such barbed wire be placed in a position so elevated as to make injury to persons passing impossible if they use ordinary care and caution. 
(Code 1972, § 4.07; Ord No. 738, § 1, 8-29-88) 
Sec. 16-8. - Water running over sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit wastewater to run across the sidewalks in the city, except when water drains across a grass plot of land before reaching the sidewalk. No wastewater from cleaning operations, air conditioning units or other similar uses or rain downspouts shall be permitted to drain across sidewalks. Where the wastewater is of a contaminated nature, it shall be connected to the public sanitary sewer. Water from downspouts and other noncontaminated water may be piped directly to the public storm drain, where such exists, or may be piped under the sidewalk and curb to the gutter in a manner approved by the city engineer. 
(Code 1972, § 4.08; Ord. No. 737, § 1, 8-29-88) 
Sec. 16-9. - Depositing debris in gutters or sidewalks. 
    No person shall deposit in the gutters or streets any ashes, leaves or other debris or material which might or could obstruct the free flow of water. 
(Code 1972, § 4.09; Ord. No. 738, § 1, 8-29-88) 
Sec. 16-10. - Merchants to clean pavements. 
    Every merchant, occupant or person in charge, or manager of any store, shop or other place of public business within the city shall remove all waste paper, peels, peanut hulls and trash from the pavement, streets and premises in front of their respective places of business, and sweep their pavements clean, or see that the pavements and premises and the street in front thereof are clean and tidy, on every Saturday night at the usual closing hour of the places of business. 
(Code 1972, § 4.10; Ord. No. 496, § 1; Ord. No. 738, § 1, 8-29-88) 
Sec. 16-11. - Distribution of handbills. 
(a)  No person shall put, place or in any manner cause to be thrown put or placed any handbills, dodgers, posters, leaflets, folders, circulars or almanacs or any other form of advertising matter or any scrap or waste paper in, on, along or upon any yard of any private or public property within the city, or on, along or upon any street, alley, square, lot, park, pavement, sidewalk, crossing, gutter or thoroughfare in the city. 
(b)  Any such advertising matter that is placed upon any step, porch or walk, or in any vehicle, shall be placed in such a manner that it will not be strewn upon the streets. 
(c)  Any person desiring to distribute handbills, advertising matter or leaflets as enumerated in this section, residing outside of the county, shall obtain a license from the clerk in the sum of $10.00 before proceeding to distribute such advertising matter. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to carriers of newspapers. 
(Code 1972, § 4.11; Ord. No. 737, § 1, 8-29-88) 
Cross reference- Licenses, ch. 10. 
Sec. 16-12. - Removal of snow from sidewalk. 
    Every person who owns, uses or occupies any house or other building or owns any unoccupied building or lot shall remove snow from the adjacent sidewalk in a manner that allows pedestrian traffic to utilize same without impediment within 36 hours after snow has ceased to fall. Any person violating this section shall be deemed guilty of a municipal infraction and fined $20.00, with each day the violation continues considered as a separate offense, with each recurring offense being subject to a fine of $40.00. 
(Code 1972, § 4.12; Ord. No. 622, § 1, 1-21-80) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Authority to so require, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 2(b)(28); penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Sec. 16-13. - Trees or shrubbery overhanging street or sidewalk. 
(a)  Every person who owns or controls trees or bushes shall trim or cut the trees or bushes in such a manner that no branches or parts thereof shall protrude or hang over any sidewalk at a height less than seven feet from the ground or sidewalk and so that no branches or parts thereof shall protrude or hang over any street at a height less than 12 feet from the ground or street. 
(b)  The maintenance or existence of trees or bushes, or any part thereof, protruding or overhanging any sidewalk at a height less than seven feet from the ground or sidewalk or protruding or overhanging any street at a height less than 12 feet from the ground or street is a nuisance. The commissioners, after due notice to remove such branches of trees or bushes or parts thereof, may cut, trim or otherwise remove such branches or parts of the trees or bushes. The cost of such action shall be a charge or lien against the property of the owner of the lot or parcel of land on which the trees or bushes are located, and shall be collectible against the property and the owner as are the city taxes or other debts due to the commissioners. 
(c)  The notice shall be served upon the owner or person in control of the trees or bushes, or, if the owner or person in control be absent or out of the city, the notice may be served by registered letter to his last known address or his agent. 
(Code 1972, § 4.13; Ord. No. 737, § 1, 8-29-88) 
Cross reference- Duties of city forester, § 2-2. 
Sec. 16-14. - Injuring trees on public property. 
    No person shall cut down, injure, mutilate or destroy any tree on any street, alley or thoroughfare, or on any lot or land belonging to the city or to the county within the city, without order of the city commissioners or the county commissioners authorizing the same. 
(Code 1972, § 4.14; Ord. No. 738, § 1, 8-29-88) 
Sec. 16-15. - Signs overhanging sidewalk. 
(a)  No person shall erect, suspend or affix any suspended or swinging sign, board or advertising structure over any public sidewalk without a permit issued by the city engineer. 
(b)  The application for the permit shall be in writing by the owner or lessee of the building or structure to which the sign is to be attached, and shall contain the specifications of the proposed sign and its installation, including the material contained therein, its size, its proposed height above the sidewalk, whether it is to be lighted or unlighted, and if lighted the method of lighting, the wording and illustrations to appear thereon, the method or manner of attaching the sign to the building or other structure, and the exact location of the proposed sign. 
(c)  No part of any sign, board or structure shall be less than 12 feet above the public sidewalk. 
(d)  No such sign or structure shall be placed except on the premises of the business or undertaking sought to be advertised. 
(e)  No such sign shall be erected, suspended or affixed to or from a structure unless it is securely attached thereto by currently approved methods. 
(f)  No such sign of a permanent nature shall extend over any public street. 
(g)  No such sign shall contain any obscene or immoral matter. 
(Code 1972, § 4.15; Ord. No. 456, § 1; Ord. No. 737, § 1, 8-29-88) 
Cross reference- Zoning, ch. 20. 
Sec. 16-16. - Moving buildings. 
(a)  Permit required. No person shall move any permanent building of a greater size than 100 square feet or measuring more than ten feet by ten feet over any street without a permit from the commissioners. A fee of $25.00 shall be paid prior to the issuance of such permit. No permit shall be issued without prior approval of the commissioners. 
(b)  Application for permit. Application for such permit shall be in writing and signed by the applicant. Such application shall show: 
(1)  The dimensions and types of construction of the building to be moved. 
(2)  The present location of the building. 
(3)  The type vehicle to be used to move the building. 
(4)  The route to be followed. 
(5)  The estimated time required for the moving. 
(6)  The location and size of the lot on which the building is to be placed, and the name of the owner of the lot. 
(7)  The proposed location of the building on the lot with relation to property lines. 
(8)  The name and address of the owner of the building, and the name and address of the person or persons who will supervise the moving of the building. 
(9)  Evidence that adequate liability insurance covering injury to persons and damage to property will be in full force and effect during the moving operations. 
(Code 1972, § 4.16; Ord. No. 482, § 1; Ord. No. 737, § 1, 8-29-88) 
Cross reference- Buildings and housing, ch. 4. 
Sec. 16-17. - Permit for sidewalk construction. 
(a)  Permit required. No person shall lay any sidewalk in the city without a permit from the city engineer. 
(b)  Application. The application for a permit to lay a sidewalk shall be upon a form provided by the city engineer, filled in completely and signed by the applicant. The applications shall be kept in a permanent file. 
(c)  Preissuance inspection. Before issuing any such permit the city engineer shall ascertain that there are no poles, guy wires or other obstructions in the path of the proposed sidewalk which could become a hazard to pedestrians. 
(d)  Contents. The permit shall show all pertinent information as to the specifications of the sidewalk to be built, and if one or more low curbs for drive-over purposes are applied for the permit shall clearly show the specifications thereof. The original of the permit shall be given to the applicant and a copy thereof filed permanently by the city engineer with the applications. 
(e)  Review of denial. Any application which may be rejected shall be subject to review by the commissioners, and such applicant or his counsel may appear before the commissioners at any one of their regular sessions. 
(Code 1972, § 4.17; Ord. No. 543, § 1; Ord. No. 737, § 1, 8-29-88) 
Sec. 16-18. - Opening of streets. 
(a)  Permit required. No person shall open the surface of any street or public thoroughfare without receiving permission from the city engineer. 
(b)  Application for permit; emergency procedures; security. Any person desiring to open the surface of any street or public thoroughfare for the purpose of installing or repairing water pipes, sewer lines, gas lines, telephone cables or electrical cables, or for any other purposes, shall make application to the city engineer in such form as he may require. In the event of an emergency, however, the city engineer may waive formal application thereof. Anyone applying for such permit shall exhibit satisfactory security to the city engineer that section 16-19 shall be complied with, and any such person receiving or anticipating receiving three or more such permits annually shall furnish the engineer with a memorandum copy of an insurance policy in current force covering public liability and indemnifying the city, and shall post a $5,000.00 bond with the engineer insuring compliance with section 16-19. 
(c)  Permit fee. The fee for such application shall be $2.00, and the fee for each street opening shall be based upon the number of square feet of street surface actually removed, on the basis of a square foot cost determined by the city engineer and based upon the annual contract price awarded by the city for the repairing of streets. 
(Code 1972, § 4.18; Ord. No. 466, § 1) 
Sec. 16-19. - Backfilling and repairing of streets. 
(a)  Technical requirements. All openings which are made in streets shall be temporarily repaired by placing compacted bank run gravel to within two inches of the surface and two inches of cold-mix bituminous concrete, bringing the final grade to match the existing grade, all of which will be accomplished by the opener. Permanent repairs will be made by the city and shall consist of cutting out the temporary patch a distance of one foot all around and excavating to nine inches below street grade. Eight inches of concrete shall be poured to within one inch of the surface and one inch of hot-mix bituminous concrete rolled into place, all of which will be accomplished at the expense of the opener. 
(b)  Thirty-day liability for repairs. The applicant shall be responsible for the repairs for 30 days after completion. If the concrete slab settles unduly or cracks occur in it, the applicant shall remove and replace it. 
(c)  Replacement of brick paving. In High Street between Poplar Street and Water Street the applicant shall replace the brick paving with brick furnished by the city at the department of public works yard at a price to be determined by the city engineer. 
(Code 1972, § 4.19; Ord. No. 466, § 1; Ord. No. 528, § 1) 
Sec. 16-20. - Parking during street sweeping operations. 
    No vehicle shall be parked on the following posted public streets between the hours of 5:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. on Wednesdays and Sundays: 
No Parking        Between (1) High Street Water Street to Washington Street (2) Court Lane All (3) Spring Street All (4) Poplar Street All (5) Gay Street All (6) Pine Street High Street to Washington Street (7) Muir Street High Street to Academy Street (8) Race Street Gay Street to Washington Street (9) Market Street All (10) Maryland Avenue Trenton Street to Sunburst Highway (11) Cedar Street Pine Street to Peachblossom Avenue (12) Elm Street Pine Street to Race Street.  
(Code 1972, § 4.20; Ord. No. 542, § 1; Ord. No. 737, § 1, 8-29-88) 
Cross reference- Parking generally, § 11-11 et seq. 
Sec. 16-21. - Sidewalk construction generally. 
(a)  Authority to require construction. Whenever the commissioners deem it to be in the public interest and for the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city, they may require sidewalks to be constructed on properties where curb and gutter exist. The city shall determine, through inspection by the department of public works, code enforcement division, areas of the city where a substantial percentage of the sidewalks are in need of replacement (as established in the current property maintenance code). In the area so designated, the city shall notify all property owners by certified mail, that a sidewalk replacement project will be taking place on their property within 90 days of the notice. 
(1)  Notification. The notice shall include the following information: 
a.  The date of a public hearing on the matter. 
b.  The locations of the proposed replacement project. 
c.  A preliminary cost estimate for each property owner's part of the proposed project. 
d.  A timeline showing the schedule of the work, including: 
1.  Date of the inspection. 
2.  Publication date for a public hearing of the proposed work plan. 
3.  Date for publication of the request for proposals. 
4.  Date for the opening of bids. 
5.  Date for awarding of bid, and publication of final unit costs based on low bid award. 
6.  The approximate date proposed for the commencement of work. 
7.  The estimated date for full completion of work. 
e.  Payment options available to assist property owners with the costs involved. 
Notification of the public hearing shall also be published in a local newspaper with general circulation within the city on two occasions, the first publication to be not less than 15 days prior to the date of the public hearing, and the second publication to be not less than seven days prior to the date of the public hearing. 
(2)  Procurement. The city shall prepare a request for proposals to be publicly advertised for the solicitation of competitive bids from qualified contractors. The RFP shall include the specific addresses and streets where the work shall be performed. The proposals shall be received, considered and awarded in conformance with the city's procurement procedures. 
(3)  Finance mechanism. The city shall maintain a revolving loan fund from which the costs of sidewalk construction shall be drawn to pay the contracted cost of the work. The cost of the work shall not exceed the available balance in the revolving loan fund. 
The cost of the work shall be divided by the total area of work in square feet to arrive at a unit cost, and distributed over the affected property owners proportionally to the actual square footage installed, to within one-tenth of a square foot. 
This calculation shall apply only to sidewalks parallel to the public street that connect with sidewalks at the adjoining properties. Any sidewalks constructed from the public way to the house, or any other sidewalks on the property are not eligible for funding under this program, and the cost therefore shall be the sole responsibility of the property owner. 
The pro-rated cost for the public way portion, shall be the responsibility of the property owner as defined in section 16-21A, and paid back to the revolving loan fund under the following options: 
a.  Payment in full. The city shall accept payment in the full amount of the pro-rated cost without an interest charge within 90 days of the invoice date. 
b.  Payment via tax lien. After 90 days, the city shall attach a lien in the amount of the pro-rated cost to the city property tax bill, which will then be paid by the property owner over a period of one to five years, as determined by the commissioners of the city, with an interest charged at the rate of one-half the legal rate charged for delinquent real property taxes. 
c.  The commissioners may institute legislation to modify the terms of the lien for the benefit of owners who can demonstrate a bona find hardship and/or income eligibility based on an index of the area median income as determined by HUD. 
d.  Funds, including interest collected, recovered by the revolving loan fund shall be returned to that fund for the express purpose of continuing and expanding this program for the benefit of the citizens of the city. 
e.  Property owners may, at their option, undertake the installation of the replacement sidewalks on their property at their own expense, with all work subject to the usual permit fees and inspection for compliance with the all applicable codes. 
These options shall be published and provided to the property owners in the project area as part of the official notice outlined above. 
(4)  Existing replacement sidewalks. Properties that have replaced sidewalks after July 1, 1995 may be exempted from the replacement program, subject to inspection by the city code enforcement division. 
(b)  Specifications. 
(1)  All sidewalks shall be four-inch thick Portland cement 3,000 lb. mix (six inches thick at driveways with six × six wire mesh reinforcement), shall be at least four feet wide, and shall have one-half-inch expansion joints every 16 feet in accordance with sections 383.20 through 383.26 of the city standard specifications. With the approval of the city engineer, comparable masonry sidewalks may be installed in lieu thereof. 
(2)  The sidewalk shall be located immediately behind the curb unless the alignment in the block has been previously established, in which case the existing alignment shall be maintained. 
(3)  In the event that trees have been planted immediately behind the curb, the sidewalk may be located behind the line of trees, provided the property owner shall obtain the prior approval of the city engineer. 
(c)  Permit. A permit for the construction of the sidewalk shall first be secured from the city engineer in accordance with section 16-17. 
(Code 1972, § 4.21; Ord. No. 588, § 1; Ord. No. 986, 4-27-09) 
Sec. 16-22. - Curb cuts. 
(a)  Permit required. No person shall begin to construct, reconstruct, repair, alter or grade any curb or curb cut on the public street without first obtaining a permit from the director of public works as provided in this section. 
(b)  Application. An applicant for a permit shall file with the director of public works an application including: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner or agent in charge of the property. 
(2)  The name and address of the party doing the work. 
(3)  The location of the work area. 
(4)  Attached plans showing details of proposed alterations. 
(c)  Completion of work on noncompliance by permittee. In any case where a permittee under this section shall be in default or shall fail to comply with the requirements of this section, the director of public works shall order the completion of the work by the city and shall recover the cost from the permittee as required by law. 
(d)  Supervision of work. All operations for which a permit is granted under this section shall be under the direction and supervision of the director of public works. 
(e)  Authority to order alterations. Where the use, convenience and necessity of the public require, the director of public works shall have the authority to order the owners or agents in charge of property adjacent to which curb cuts are maintained to alter the curb cut in such manner as he shall find reasonably necessary under the circumstances. 
(f)  Protection of opening; cleanup. All such cuts left open overnight shall be adequately illuminated and barricaded to ensure the safety of the public. At the completion of each project, the project site shall be promptly cleared of all debris, rubbish, piles of earth, etc., resulting from the project; all holes shall be filled or mounds leveled to match the grade of the adjoining grounds; sod shall be replaced in grassy areas; and the site shall otherwise be left in good condition. 
(g)  Work to be done by licensed contractor. The work shall be done by a building or general contractor licensed to do work in the city. 
(h)  Commercial entrances on state roads. Commercial entrances on state roads are subject to Policy Standards for Commercial Entrance Channelization, issued by the state roads commission, 1966. 
(i)  Conformance with city specifications. All work performed shall be in accordance with city standard specifications for water mains, sanitary sewers, storm drains, streets and roads. Copies of such specifications are available at the department of public works for a deposit of $5.00, which is refundable upon return. 
(j)  Location and width; relocation of utilities. 
(1)  No curb cut shall start closer than 25 feet from an intersection. 
(2)  Residential curb cuts shall be limited to 12 feet in width, with exceptions being granted for properties having two-car garages. 
(3)  No curb cut will be granted where the property width is such that less than ten feet exists between the existing building and the property line. 
(4)  Maximum openings into commercial property shall be limited to 35 feet wide. Where two openings are permitted, a ten-foot tangent between openings shall be maintained. 
(5)  Minimum frontage for two two-way entrances into a commercial property shall be as follows: 
a.  Interior locations: 76 feet. 
b.  Corner locations: 111 feet. 
(6)  The relocation and/or adjustment of any public or private utility shall be the responsibility of the permittee. This includes traffic signals, signs, fire hydrants, water meters, utility poles, etc. 
(7)  Where off-street parking is permitted at a commercial property and the location of the building is such that less than 45 feet exists from the building to the curbline, permission may be granted to increase the length of the curb opening to more than 35 feet. 
(k)  Reserved. 
(l)  Conflicting provisions. In any case where a provision of this section is found to be in conflict with a provision of any zoning, building, fire, safety or health ordinance or code existing on the effective date of this section, the provision which establishes the higher standard for the promotion and protection of the health and safety of the people shall prevail. In any case where a provision of this section is found to be in conflict with a provision of any other ordinance or code existing on the effective date of this section which establishes a lower standard for the promotion and protection of the health and safety of the people, the provisions of this section shall be deemed to prevail, and such other ordinances or codes are hereby declared to be repealed to the extent that they may be found in conflict with this section. 
(Code 1972, § 4.22; Ord. No. 737, § 1, 8-29-88; Ord. No. 986, 4-27-09) 
Sec. 16-23. - Underground utilities. 
(a)  Submission and approval of plans. No person shall bury a utility within the public right-of-way in the city without having first submitted plans to the director of public works and received written approval of such plans by the director of public works. 
(b)  Plan specifications. Such plans shall be no larger than 24 inches by 36 inches (unless bound in book form) and shall show the utility's proposed location within the public right-of-way in relation to the centerline of the right-of-way, its depth from the street surface or top of curb, and the size and type of utility to be laid. In preparing the layout of his utility, the owner shall show the location and depth of the buried utilities in the right-of-way. Drawings will be to a scale not greater than one inch equals 50 feet on reproducible paper showing north arrow, scale and names of streets and date. In the case where utilities are to be laid in a new street, the city will provide drawings showing all pertinent information as to city utilities and the owner shall place his information thereon. 
    The owner shall make copies of the original approved plan, with any changes made during construction as well as the date of completion, and marked "As Built," and submit one copy to the director of public works. 
(c)  Installation prior to approval. If the owner installs a buried utility without having first received written permission therefor from the director of public works, he shall be required to uncover such buried utility for verification. 
(Code 1972, § 4.23) 
Cross reference- Buildings and housing, ch. 4; electricity, ch. 5; plumbing and sewers, ch. 14; water, ch. 18. 
Sec. 16-24. - Pipes for private roads and driveways. 
(a)  Materials to be supplied by commissioners. When the need for such pipe or pipes is caused by a change in drainage made by the commissioners, the commissioners will provide the pipe and other material, as well as labor and equipment necessary for installation. 
    When the need for such pipe or pipes is caused by a change in drainage or a new street or driveway made by other than the commissioners, the commissioners will provide materials, other than pipe, as well as labor and equipment necessary for installations. 
(b)  Specifications. Pipe shall be new bituminous corrugated galvanized steel of sizes as determined by the department of public works, and shall be the following minimum lengths: 
(1)  Private drives: 20 feet. 
(2)  Field entrance: 24 feet. 
(3)  Commercial entrance: 32 feet. 
Property owners desiring other than the driveway entrances specified in this subsection or requesting permission to install longer lengths of pipe may purchase additional pipe from the department of public works. Installation of additional pipe and necessary cover material will be accomplished by private contractor, at the property owner's expense. In addition, a catchbasin or junction box built to the specifications of the department of public works will be installed where specified by the department of public works. The commissioners will provide cleanout and normal maintenance of pipe after installation, but, if any future changes are necessary, including replacement or change in pipe size, this will be at the property owner's expense. All work must be approved by and supervised during installation by the commissioners. 
(c)  Additional lengths. In an installation where the city is responsible for supplying pipe, any length in addition to the minimums stated in subsection (b) of this section will be at the expense of those requesting the additional length. 
(d)  Maintenance and replacement. When installed, all pipes become the maintenance and replacement responsibility of the commissioners, and therefore shall become the property of the commissioners, except as provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(e)  Supervision of private installation. No installation of pipe by the property owner shall be done unless supervised by the department of public works. It will determine size of pipe, amount of cover material, etc. 
(f)  Payment for materials. All pipes supplied by the city will be paid for before installation is made. 
(g)  Applicability. This section shall apply to all driveways and alleys adjacent to a city street. 
(Ord. No. 485, § 1; Ord. No. 737, § 1, 8-29-88) 
Sec. 16-25. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
    Except where it is otherwise provided, any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of an infraction, the fine for which shall be $50.00, and every day that a violation continues, after due notice has been served in conformity with the terms and provisions of Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3(b), shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 485, § 1; Ord. No. 739, § 1, 8-29-88) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3.

(Ord. No. 932, 12-28-04) 
Chapter 17.5 - TAXATION 

Sec. 17.5-1. - Real property tax credits for seniors. 
(a)  Tax credit for seniors who purchase a primary residence within the City of Cambridge: 
(1)  During the period from the effective date of this section [February 9, 2015] through December 31, 2020, qualifying seniors who purchase a residential unit within the City of Cambridge and who will reside in the said residence as his or her primary residence, shall receive a tax credit on their municipal real property tax bill equivalent to 50 percent of the annual real property taxes for the primary residence for three consecutive years beginning with the tax/fiscal year immediately following the date of acquisition of the property. 
(2)  To qualify, the qualifying Senior must: 
a.  Not have owned a home which was their principal residence in the City of Cambridge for at least five years prior to purchasing the qualifying residential unit; 
b.  Acquire title to the residential unit on or before December 31, 2020; 
c.  Make application with the clerk/treasurer's office of the city, on or before the 1 st day of May immediately following the date on which he or she acquired title to the residential unit; 
d.  Reside in the residential unit as his or her primary residence; and 
e.  Have a legal ownership interest in the residential unit. 
(3)  The tax credit shall apply for the three consecutive years, beginning on the July 1 st immediately following the date on which the senior acquired title to the property, provided they make application for the credit on or before May 1 st , subject, however to the following condition: the annual real property taxes shall be paid on or before December 31 st of each year. The failure of the owner to pay the property taxes on or before December 31 st shall result in the rescission and termination of the tax credit for that year and all future years remaining of the credit. 
(b)  Definitions. 
(1)  Senior. As used herein the term "Senior" shall be defined as an individual who (a) has attained the age of 60 years or more on the date that he or she purchases and acquires title to a residential unit within the City of Cambridge, (b) did not own a principal residence in the City of Cambridge prior to purchasing the new residence; and (c) intends to reside in the said residential unit as his/her primary or principal residence. 
(2)  Qualifying residential unit. To qualify for the tax credit, the residential unit can be either new or previously occupied, and must serve as the purchasing senior's primary or principal residence. 
(Ord. No. 1043, 2-9-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1043, adopted February 9, 2015, did not specifically amend the Code. Therefore such ordinance has been added as § 17.5-1 at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 17.5-2. - Tax credits for property within designated redevelopment zone. 
(a)  Tax credit for investments made within the Downtown/Waterfront Development District. 
(1)  During the period from the effective date of this Ordinance [January 1, 2015] until June 30, 2020, any and all property owners who complete at least $50,000.00 of improvements to their real property which is located within the Downtown/Waterfront Development District as defined in the city's Comprehensive Plan March 28, 2011 ("qualifying improvements"), shall receive a tax credit on their municipal real property tax bill equivalent to a percentage of the tax increase generated by the increase in assessed value as a result of the said improvements. The tax credit shall be in the amounts and duration as follows: 
Year 1: The tax credit shall be 80 percent of the increase in taxes resulting from the increased assessed value following the completion of the improvements (the owner will pay 20 percent of the increase in taxes); 
Year 2: The tax credit shall be 60 percent of the increase in taxes resulting from the increased assessed value following the completion of the improvements (the owner will pay 40 percent of the increase in taxes); 
Year 3: The tax credit shall be 40 percent of the increase in taxes resulting from the increased assessed value following the completion of the improvements (the owner will pay 60 percent of the increase in taxes); 
Year 4: The tax credit shall be 20 percent of the increase in taxes resulting from the increased assessed value following the completion of the improvements (the owner will pay 80 percent). 
Year 5: The tax credit is no longer applicable and the owner shall pay 100 percent of the taxes. 
(2)  Any property owner who completes the qualifying improvements on or before June 30, 2020 shall be entitled to the four-year tax credit from municipal real property taxes as set forth above. 
(3)  The approved tax credit shall run with the subject property and inure to the benefit of the owner who made application and to his/her successors and assigns. 
(b)  Downtown/Waterfront Development District defined. The Downtown/Waterfront Development District is hereby defined as the area designated as such in the city's Unified Development Code as approved by the Commissioners of Cambridge on December 8, 2014 by Ordinance No. 1041, which became effective January 1, 2015, which district is more particularly shown and delineated upon Exhibit A which is attached hereto and incorporated herein by reference. [A copy of Exhibit A can be found in the city offices.] 
(Ord. No. 1044, 2-9-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1044, adopted February 9, 2015, did not specifically amend the Code. Therefore, such ordinance has been added as 17.5-2 at the editor's discretion.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Water service; rates.

Sec. 18-2. - Water charges-Collection. 
    The municipal utilities commission is hereby authorized and directed to charge for the water supplied and the services rendered by such commission through such water supply and distribution system in accordance with the schedule set out in section 18-1, and the commission may bill its customers for services performed at such times as it may desire. All applications and accounts for water service shall be in the name of the owner of the property. 
(Code 1972, § 6.02; Ord. No. 540, § 1; Ord. No. 564, § 1; Ord. No. 576, § 1; Ord. No. 694, § 1, 7-15-85; Ord. No. 841, 6-9-97) 
Sec. 18-3. - Same-Lien for unpaid charges. 
    From and after November 1, 1959, all charges for water supplied or services rendered by the water supply and distribution system of the city, with respect to taxable properties, located within the corporate limits of the city, as now or hereafter fixed by law, and whether such charges shall be calculated in accordance with the schedule of rates and charges adopted by this chapter or in accordance with any modification or amendment thereof, shall constitute liens on the property served from the date of billing until paid, in the same manner and with the same priority as property taxes levied by the city are made liens on any such property, and, when and as often as requested by the clerk and treasurer of the city, the municipal utilities commission shall furnish such clerk and treasurer with a list of all unpaid water bills constituting such liens, to the end that such clerk and treasurer may proceed with the enforcement of such liens and the collection of such bills in the same manner that delinquent city property taxes are enforced and collected. 
(Code 1972, § 6.03; Ord. No. 602, § 1) 
Sec. 18-4. - Same-Water used by city. 
    There shall be no charge for water supplied by the municipal utilities commission in the operation of its water supply and distribution system to the city, or any department, division or agency thereof, including but not limited to water supplied for fire hydrants. 
(Code 1972, § 6.04; Ord. No. 567, § 1; Ord. No. 611, § 1) 
Sec. 18-5. - Service outside city; delinquent bills. 
    The schedule of water rates and charges adopted by this chapter shall be fully applicable to consumers both within and beyond the present or any future corporate limits of the city, irrespective of whether the property of such consumers is subject to city taxation and irrespective of whether such consumers, the property thereof serviced, or both, are exempted in whole or in part by law from state, county and municipal taxation; except, however, that all consumers outside of the corporate limits of the city are subject to a 100 percent surcharge for water consumed. Whenever and as often as requested by the city attorney, the municipal utilities commission shall furnish said city attorney with a list of all delinquent water bills sent to such consumers, to the end that said city attorney may proceed promptly with the collection of such bills in the name and on behalf of the city by appropriate judicial proceedings. 
(Code 1972, § 6.05; Ord. No. 642, § 1, 7-20-81; Ord. No. 888, 12-4-00) 
Sec. 18-6. - Private water sources. 
    No person shall hereafter proceed or undertake to provide or develop a private or separate source of water supply within the present or future corporate limits of the city, either through the sinking or deepening of new or existing wells, the purification of saline or stream water, the accumulation and storing of rainwater or otherwise, for the use of such person or for distribution to others, unless such person shall first obtain from the municipal utilities commission a permit for any such undertaking. For the purpose and in the interest of protecting the public health, welfare and safety of the residents of the city, authority is hereby delegated to the municipal utilities commission to promulgate and adopt and from time to time to modify or amend reasonable rules and regulations governing the granting or withholding of any such permit, the reasonable and proper conditions to be imposed with respect to any such grant, and the duration thereof. Any such rules and regulations shall be suitably printed or otherwise duplicated by the municipal utilities commission, and copies thereof shall be made available by said commission to all interested persons. 
(Code 1972, § 6.06)

Sec. 18-8. - Amendments to chapter. 
    Nothing contained in this chapter shall be taken or deemed as in any manner preventing the city hereafter from exercising its right, power and duty to modify, amend or add to the schedule of water rates and charges adopted by this chapter, such right, power and duty being subject only to the covenant made by the city with the holders from time to time of the water system revenue bonds and to the legally applicable laws of the state now or hereafter adopted and in effect. 
(Code 1972, § 6.08) 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL UTILITIES COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- The bond ordinance referred to in art. II is Ord. No. 263, adopted Oct. 20, 1959, as amended, a copy of which is on file in the office of the clerk and treasurer. 
Charter reference- Municipal utilities commission, § 3-43. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 18-9. - Organization generally. 
(a)  Composition. The agency of the city hereby perpetuated and known as the municipal utilities commission shall, as the effective date of this section be composed of six members, all of whom shall be residents of the city. 
(b)  Membership. The membership of the municipal utilities commission shall consist of the mayor, during his/her term of office, who shall act as chairman of the commission; and five residents of the city, who shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice, consent and approval of the commissioners. 
(c)  Successor members. Successors to all the members of the municipal utilities commission, with the exception of the mayor, shall be appointed by the mayor, with the advice, consent and approval of the commissioners, for four-year terms, beginning on December 1 of the respective years in which the terms of their predecessors expire; however, if no appointment is made within 30 days of the expiration of an incumbent's term of office, the commissioners shall make the appointment exclusively. Any incumbent members of the commission may be so appointed to succeed themselves for any number of successive terms and, in any event, shall hold office until their successors are duly appointed and qualified. 
(d)  Oath of office. Each person so appointed, before assuming his office, shall be sworn into office in the same manner as provided by the city charter for other elected or appointed city officials. 
(e)  Compensation of members. All members of the commission shall serve without compensation, except that the commission may provide for reimbursement of the reasonable and proper expenses of the members incurred in the performance of their duties. 
(f)  Ex officio members. In addition to the members otherwise specified in this section, the director of public works shall serve as member of the commission, ex officio, without vote and without additional compensation. 
(g)  Meetings; hearings. The commission shall meet in the city at such regular intervals as it shall deem necessary for the proper discharge of its powers and duties, but no less frequently than once each three months of each calendar year. Special meetings of the commission may be held upon proper notice, and the commission may, from time to time, hold public hearings on any matter or proposal pending before the commission and deemed by it to be of general public concern or interest. 
(h)  Rules of procedure. The commission may adopt suitable rules and bylaws for the conduct of its regular and special meetings, for any public hearings it may hold and for the notice required with respect to any such meetings or hearings. The mayor shall preside at all meetings and hearings and shall designate a secretary to keep the minutes of such meetings or hearings. The mayor may also appoint a member of the commission to preside at any such meetings or hearings in his absence. No official action of the commission shall be taken except upon the affirmative vote of three members thereof. The mayor shall have the right to vote only in the event of a tie vote of the commission members. 
(i)  Quorum. The presence at any such regular or special meeting of at least three voting members of the commission shall be necessary to constitute a quorum for the transaction of any business. 
(j)  Vacancies. The resignation, death or permanent incapacity of any voting member of the commission shall create a vacancy in the office of such member, and, in such event, the mayor shall promptly fill such vacancy by appointing a successor to such member for the unexpired balance of his term, with the advice, consent and approval of the commissioners, and if no appointment is made within 30 days of such vacancy the commissioners shall make the appointment exclusively. 
(Ord. No. 486, § 1; Ord. No. 555, § 1; Ord. No. 978, 9-22-08) 
Sec. 18-10. - Consulting engineers. 
    The Beavin Company of Baltimore, Maryland, are hereby appointed consulting engineers to said commission to perform all the duties and functions and to render the services prescribed for said consulting engineers in the bond ordinance, and to perform or render such other duties and services as said commission may from time to time prescribe with respect to the water system of the city, said consulting engineers to be compensated for such work from the operating fund for said water system as provided in the bond ordinance. The commission, with the approval of the city, shall have the power to remove said consulting engineers and, in the event of their resignation or such removal, successor consulting engineers shall be appointed as provided in the bond ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 486, § 2) 
Sec. 18-11. - Legal services. 
    The city attorney shall render all necessary legal services to said commission whenever requested to do so, and his reasonable compensation for such services, payable from the operating fund, shall be in addition to but shall be deemed and treated as part of his compensation for serving as city attorney. Any other attorney acting on behalf of the municipal utilities commission without the express permission of the commissioners shall be compensated personally by the members of said municipal utilities commission. 
(Ord. No. 486, § 3) 
Sec. 18-12. - Powers and duties generally. 
    There is hereby transferred and delegated to the municipal utilities commission created by this article the power and duty, on behalf of the city, to administer, maintain, manage, operate, repair, expand, enlarge and charge for the service of the water supply and distribution system acquired by the city. Subject to the limitations of and in compliance with the covenants and agreements of the city contained in the bond ordinance, there are hereby conferred on and delegated to said municipal utilities commission, with respect to said water supply and distribution system, the powers, duties and functions set forth in the city charter, with the express exception that compensation, leave and fringe benefits of the employees of the municipal utilities commission shall be designated and in accordance with merit system pay plans or personnel ordinances established by the commissioners from time to time, and at the discretion of the commissioners an independent audit of the municipal utilities commission may be required by the commissioners from time to time. Said commission is hereby further authorized and directed, from time to time, to recommend to the city such action on its part, by ordinance or otherwise, or the addition to or enlargement of its powers, as may be necessary to or desirable for the proper, effective and continuing maintenance, operation, extension or enlargement of said water supply and distribution system. pursuant to the provisions of the city charter, the municipal utilities commission is to collect the sewer service charge levied by the city without cost or obligation to the city, and in no event shall water lines outside the city limits be extended without the permission of the commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 486, § 4) 
Sec. 18-13. - Cooperation with city engineer; disbursement of funds. 
    The municipal utilities commission is hereby authorized to confer with the city engineer jointly with the manager of the water supply and distribution system, appointed by it pursuant to the powers conferred in this article and in the manner prescribed by the bond ordinance, and shall have authority to receive, acknowledge payment of, deposit and disburse all funds or moneys received or collected in the management and operation of said water supply and distribution system; provided that all such receipts and disbursements shall be handled in compliance with the provisions of the bond ordinance and any rules and regulations of the commission promulgated pursuant thereto; and provided, further, that the city engineer and manager shall, at each regular or special meeting of the commission, render a full and complete accounting of their transactions pursuant thereto since the next preceding regular or special meeting of said commission. All checks or other instruments evidencing withdrawals or disbursements of the funds or moneys in the custody of the commission shall be signed by the manager and countersigned by the city engineer or the town clerk and treasurer, and each such check or other instrument shall indicate thereon, by suitable reference, the budget item on the bond ordinance provision authorizing the withdrawal or payment evidenced by such check or other instrument. Any bond required of the manager will be kept by the town clerk and treasurer in his vault. 
(Ord. No. 486, § 5) 
Sec. 18-14. - Disposition of revenues. 
    As provided in the bond ordinance, all gross revenues collected by the municipal utilities commission in the operation of the water supply and distribution system shall be deposited in and disbursed through the following funds and in the following order of priority, which funds shall be named by the municipal utilities commission to the extent permitted by the bond ordinance and secured or insured as therein provided: 
(a)  Revenue fund. All collections of water rates and charges, after the initial apportionment thereof provided for in the bond ordinance, shall be deposited in the reserve fund on the business day next after the receipt thereof. 
(b)  Operating fund. As often as is necessary in each calendar month, there shall be withdrawn from the revenue fund and deposited in the operating fund an amount sufficient to cover the current expenses for such month as defined in the bond ordinance and as provided for in the commission's annual budget or any supplemental budget thereof. 
(c)  Debt service fund. At the regular six-month intervals specified in the bond ordinance, there shall be withdrawn from the revenue fund and deposited in the debt service fund the amounts necessary to enable the fiscal agent to make the payments of principal, if any, and interest on the water system revenue bonds of the city issued under the bond ordinance and coming due on the first day of the month following such withdrawal. 
(d)  Mandatory sinking fund. Beginning October 1, 1974, and on the first day of each month in each year thereafter, there shall be withdrawn from the revenue fund and deposited in the mandatory sinking fund 1/12 of the face amount of such bonds maturing October 1, 1989, which the city is required by the bond ordinance to redeem in each such year. 
(e)  Bond reserve fund. As soon as there shall be accumulated in the revenue fund sufficient moneys to meet the requirements of subsections (b) and (c) of this section through the next interest payment date, any surplus therein up to the annual amounts set forth in the bond ordinance shall be withdrawn and deposited in the bond reserve fund until the amount so deposited shall reach $87,000.00, and thereafter deposits shall be made into the bond reserve fund only if and when the amount therein, or the current market value of the investment of such deposits, shall fall below $87,000.00. 
(f)  Bond redemption and improvement fund. As soon as (1) the monthly deposits required by subsection (e) of this section shall have been met, (2) the monthly deposits required by subsections (b) and (d) of this section have been made, and (3) there shall be on deposit in the revenue fund sufficient moneys to meet the next monthly and semiannual deposits required under subsections (b), (c) and (d) of this section, any surplus in the revenue fund shall be withdrawn and deposited in the bond redemption and improvement fund. 
(g)  Interest on investments. Any interest earned on any investment of moneys in the funds described in this section shall be regularly deposited in the bond redemption and improvement fund. 
(h)  Disbursements from bond reserve fund. Moneys, or the proceeds of investments in the bond reserve fund, shall be withdrawn and used only to make up any deficiency occurring at any time in the debt service fund or the mandatory sinking fund by reason of insufficient moneys in the revenue fund to make the required deposits in the debt service fund or the mandatory sinking fund and ultimately to make the final payment due on outstanding bonds at maturity or redemption. 
(i)  Disbursement from bond redemption and improvement fund. Moneys accumulated in the bond redemption and improvement fund or the proceeds of sale of any investments thereof shall, at all times, be subject to withdrawal to supplement disbursements from the bond reserve fund for the purposes specified in subsection (h) of this section, to restore such fund to $87,000.00, and, if not so used or needed, shall be expended for optional redemptions or purchases of bonds, at the prices specified in the bond ordinance, or for repairs and capital additions to the water system, or both, as determined by the municipal utilities commission. 
(Ord. No. 486, § 6; Ord. No. 825, § 1, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 18-15. - Authority to adopt additional regulations; penalty for violation of chapter. 
    As provided in the bond ordinance and in this article, the municipal utilities commission shall have the power to adopt and, from time to time, modify, amend or repeal reasonable rules and regulations with respect to the maintenance, operation, repair and extension of said water supply and distribution system, with respect to the connection therewith, with respect to the provisions of proper equipment, facilities and outlets for the use of the service rendered thereby, with respect to the restriction or elimination of other sources of water supply and with respect to the willful or negligent injury to or damage of any part of the system. The commission shall also have the power, in administering said water supply and distribution systems in the name of the city, to adopt reasonable rules and regulations for the protection and preservation of the public health and safety. Except where it is otherwise provided, any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of an infraction, the fine for which shall be $50.00, and every day that a violation continues after due notice has been served in conformity with the terms and provisions of Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3(b), shall be deemed a separate offense. This penalty may be utilized in addition to any other legal proceeding which may be available. 
(Ord. No. 486, § 7; Ord. No. 740, § 1, 9-12-88) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Sec. 18-16. - Charges due; unpaid charges. 
(a)  All sums of money due and owing to the municipal utilities commission for sanitary sewer, water, trash disposal services, or rental registration fees shall be and constitute a lien upon the real property to or in which such sewer, water, and/or trash disposal services are supplied, or to which rental registration fees apply. 
(b)  In the event any water or sewer charge remains unpaid 30 days after notice of nonpayment and pending termination is sent by the municipal utilities commission, service of water may be terminated and remain terminated until such time as payment of all such outstanding charges is made, together with any applicable reconnection charges as permitted by law. 
(Ord. No. 804, 9-12-94; Ord. No. 924, 7-19-04) 
Chapter 19 - WHARVES AND WATERWAYS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) ---

The existing sections of ch. 19, being §§ 19-1-19-5, have been redesignated as §§ 19-01-19-05 by the editor to facilitate the inclusion of Ord. No. 696 in the manner described.
