Cross reference- Use of trash receptacles at yacht basin, Long Wharf, Franklin Street Boat Ramp, Great Marsh and Cornish Park, § 8-17. 
State Law reference- Vessels, Ann. Code of Md. art. Natural Resources, § 8-701 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19-01. - Use of yacht basin. 
(a)  No person shall fasten, tie up, park or dock any yacht, boat or vessel in any berth which is staked out for such purpose in what is known as the yacht basin at Long Wharf in the city without first obtaining a lease from the city or a temporary permit from the dockmaster. The lease shall be on a rental basis for the term of one year and payable annually or semiannually at a rental to be determined from time to time by the commissioners. 
(b)  The lessee or permittee shall be subject to such rules and regulations as may be approved by the commissioners for the use of the yacht basin, which rules and regulations may be obtained from the commissioners. Failure of the lessee or permittee to comply with the rules and regulations shall be sufficient power and authority for the commissioners to deny or cancel the permit or lease without further notice. 
(c)  No person shall anchor any yacht, boat or vessel in the yacht basin. All yachts, boats or vessels utilizing any of the berths constituting the yacht basin or seawall of the bulkhead, either permanently or temporarily, shall pay rent for a berth or docking space. 
(d)  No person shall fasten, tie up, park or dock any yacht, boat or vessel at any of the bulkheading around the property of the city at Long Wharf without obtaining permission to do so from the dockmaster or city clerk-treasurer. 
(Code 1972, § 5.01; Ord. No. 566, § 1; Ord. No. 741, § 1, 9-12-88) 
Sec. 19-02. - Obstructing Cambridge Creek. 
(a)  No person shall tie up or anchor any vessels or craft in Cambridge Creek in such a manner as to prevent or obstruct the passage of other vessels or craft; or voluntarily or carelessly sink or permit or cause to be sunk, or abandon or cause to be abandoned, any vessel or other craft in Cambridge Creek; or float loose timber or logs or any other objects or debris in Cambridge Creek in such a manner as to obstruct, impede or endanger navigation by craft of any size or description. Whenever a vessel, raft or other craft is sunk in Cambridge Creek, accidentally or otherwise, it shall be the duty of the owner of such sunken craft to commence the immediate removal of the same and prosecute such removal diligently, and failure to do so shall be considered as an abandonment of such craft. 
(b)  Whenever any such sunken vessel, boat, watercraft, raft or other similar obstruction shall exist for more than 30 days or whenever the abandonment of such obstruction can be legally established earlier, the sunken vessel, boat, watercraft, raft or other obstruction shall be subject to be broken up, removed, sold or otherwise disposed of by the commissioners at their discretion, without liability for any damage to the owners. The expense of such removal, over and above any amount of money received by the sale of such vessel, craft or other object by the commissioners, shall be a charge against the owner of or the person sinking or permitting or causing the sinking of such vessel or other watercraft or object and may be recovered in an action at law by the commissioners. The commissioners may cause reasonable notice of such obstruction to be given to such person by publication addressed "To whom it may concern" in a newspaper published in the city, requiring the removal thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 5.02; Ord. No. 741, § 1, 9-12-88) 
Sec. 19-03. - Excursion permits. 
    No person in control or command of or in authority on any train, steamboat, boat or vessel shall bring in, dock, land, or permit to dock or land any excursion or excursionists without a permit from the mayor. 
(Code 1972, § 5.03; Ord. No. 741, § 1, 9-12-88) 
Sec. 19-04. - Speed of boats. 
    No person shall operate any motorboat or power boat at a rate of speed greater than six knots in the municipal yacht basin or its entrance or in Cambridge Creek within the line drawn from the east corner of Long Wharf to the end of the finger pier in the Cambridge-Dorchester Port. 
(Code 1972, § 5.04; Ord. No. 741, § 1, 9-12-88) 
Sec. 19-05. - Ladders on bulkheads. 
(a)  Any property owner abutting the waters of Cambridge Creek and having as a retaining wall a bulkhead shall construct a ladder extending into the waters of said creek so that anyone found within the waters thereof may emerge therefrom by use thereof. Any property owner having a bulkhead frontage of more than 200 feet abutting said creek shall have at least two such ladders erected for the purposes stated in this section. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(Ord. No. 673, § 1, 1-23-84; Ord. No. 741, § 1, 9-12-88) 
Sec. 19-06. - Fishing and crabbing. 
    It shall be unlawful for persons to fish or crab from the mooring docks in the yacht basin or the Trenton Street Marina. 
(Ord. No. 748, § 1, 8-21-89) 
ARTICLE II. - HARBORS, DOCKS, WATERWAYS, WATERFRONT AREAS AND RELATED MATTERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Marine facilities commission, §§ 2-7, 2-8; buildings and housing, ch. 4; grading, erosion and sediment control, ch. 7; zoning, ch. 20; planned water community zoning district, § 20-15B. 

Sec. 19-1. - Purpose of article. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide regulations for the orderly development, control and management of the waterways, structures installed in the waterways and associated waterfront areas within the city. 
    This article is not intended to deprive a riparian owner of any right or privilege associated with riparian ownership of land or ownership or use of any fixed and permanent structure in the waterways which was lawfully installed and lawfully in use prior to the date of the adoption of this article. The provisions of this article do not transfer the title or ownership of any waterway or interest in a waterway. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(1), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-2. - Applicability of article; conflicting provisions. 
    The provisions of this article and any rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto shall be applicable to and shall govern the control of all activities and the construction and use of all marinas and community and private piers and mooring piles within the waterways of the city. 
    The location of shorelines, the location of harbor lines and lateral lines for those areas of the waterways which have been developed, and the provisional location of harbor lines and lateral lines for those areas of the waterways which have not been developed are as shown on the maps entitled "Cambridge Harbor." Detailed procedures for determining the location of harbor lines and lateral lines are as set forth in sections 19-7 and 19-8 of this article. Said maps and all notations, dimensions, references and other data shown thereon, as well as properly attested amendments to the maps, are a part of this Code. 
    The provisions of this article shall be in addition to existing federal, state and county regulations governing the same matters and are not intended to preempt other valid laws. The more restrictive regulations shall take precedence. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(2), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-3. - Severability. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the mayor and commissioners of the city that the several provisions of this article are separable, in accordance with the following: 
(a)  If any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge any provision of this article invalid, such judgment shall not affect any other provisions of this article not specifically included in such judgment. 
(b)  If any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge the application of any provision of this article to a particular property, building or other structure invalid, such judgment shall not affect the application of such provisions to any other property. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(3), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-4. - Nonliability of city. 
    Any person using the facilities owned or operated by the city within the waterways of the city shall assume all risk of damage or loss to his life or property. The city assumes no risk on account of fire, theft, act of God or damages of any kind to watercraft and other properties within the waterways of the city. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(4), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-4.1. - Long Wharf crane. 
(a)  The crane shall be used at the sole risk of the user; he/she assumes the entire risk of the use of the crane. 
(b)  A deposit in the amount of $10.00 shall be paid to the clerk/treasurer for the use of a security key which unlocks the crane. 
(c)  The key shall be returned to the clerk/treasurer, or the dockmaster, within a reasonable time period following the use of the crane; upon the return of the key, the security deposit shall be refunded to the user. 
(d)  The crane shall be used for the boat owner's personal use, or for recreational uses only. 
(e)  The crane shall only be used during the following time period: one-half hour prior to sunrise until one-half hour after sunset. 
(f)  The following weight limitation shall be strictly adhered to: no object or vessel in excess of one and one-half tons (3,000 pounds) shall be permitted on the crane. 
(g)  Each user shall be liable and responsible for any and all damage to the crane and to the other property, and for injuries to himself and others, which arise from his/her use of the crane. 
(h)  No one shall assign or transfer his/her key to another person; permission to use the crane is expressly limited to the persons who obtain a key from the clerk/treasurer and who execute a release/hold harmless agreement; each user shall be liable and responsible for any and [all] damages or injuries caused by persons using his/her key. 
(i)  Each user shall execute a release/hold harmless agreement at the time he/she obtains a key from the city clerk/treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 834, 6-3-96) 
Sec. 19-5. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Anchoring means to secure a watercraft to the bottom of water by dropping an anchor or anchors with a buoy or other ground tackle. 
    Berth means a place where a watercraft may be secured to a fixed or floating structure and left unattended. 
    Berthing area means the water area in which boats are berthed. 
    Bulkhead means a structure or partition to retain or prevent sliding of the land into the water. A secondary purpose is to protect the upland from wave action. 
    Developable waterfront land means any waterfront property from which access to a waterway area can be achieved. 
    Developable waterway area means the waterway area lying between the shoreline, the harbor line and the lateral lines of waterfront property. 
    Finger pier means a small pier structure attached (and usually perpendicular) to the headwalk of a multislip pier, usually provided to facilitate access to the berthed watercraft. 
    Gabion means a connected system of wicker or metal cages filled with brush or rock and used as bulkhead for slope protection or stabilization. 
    Harbor line means a line, either fixed or provisional, defining the maximum channelward limits of marine construction for a given developable waterway area. 
    Harbor line, fixed means the line defining the maximum channelward limits of marine construction, defined by and encompassing that construction lawfully installed in a given developable waterway area, and identified by solid unbroken lineation on the harbor line maps. 
    Harbor line map means a map of the federal navigation channel, entitled "Cambridge Harbor," dated June 15, 1984, scale one inch equals 50 feet, graphically showing, but not limited to, lateral lines, shorelines of the waterways of the city, channel markers and harbor lines. 
    Harbor line, provisional means the line defining the maximum channelward limits of marine construction in a given developable waterway area which has not been fully developed, and identified by solid unbroken lineation on the harbor line maps. 
    Harbormaster means the officer of the city who executes the regulations respecting the use of the harbor and the waterways. 
    Lateral lines means lines extending from the shoreline to the harbor line separating adjacent developable waterway areas. 
    Marina means any arrangement of piers, slips, mooring piles, wharves and/or buoys emplaced in the water and on abutting land and which is intended to be used for the berthing, storing, mooring, securing, servicing, repairing, selling or trading and/or renting of watercraft and is not a private or community pier and mooring. 
    Mooring means: 
(a)  A place where watercraft are secured other than a pier. 
(b)  The equipment used to secure a watercraft. 
(c)  The process of securing a watercraft other than by anchoring. 
    Mooring buoy means an appliance used to secure to the bottom by anchors and provided with attachments to which a watercraft may be secured by use of its anchor chain or mooring lines. 
    Municipal infraction means any violation of this Code, which violation has been specifically declared to be a municipal infraction. For purposes of this Code, a municipal infraction is a civil offense. See section 1-9 of this Code. 
    Piers and moorings, community means any type of structure, fixed or floating, and extending from community, condominium-owned or leased property, generally referred to as a pier, dock or wharf, including pilings, buoys and other such facilities, and used for the berthing of watercraft registered to residents of the community within which the property is located or to residents or co-owners of the condominium-owned property from which the facility extends. A community pier may also be used only for the temporary berthing of watercraft owned by and registered to visitors of residents of the community or condominium, but only during such a visit. 
    Piers and moorings, private means any type of structure, fixed or floating, generally referred to as a pier, dock or wharf, including pilings, buoys and other such facilities, used primarily for the berthing of watercraft owned by and registered to the owner and/or tenant of the property from which the facility extends. 
    Port warden means the officer of the city who shall have the power to determine upon and regulate all matters relating to the creating or building of wharves or piers in Cambridge Creek and shall have the authority to promulgate specifications and regulations pertaining to the distance of the wharves or piers or other improvements that may be extended into the waters of said Cambridge Creek, the materials of which they shall be constructed, the manner and form of construction, their location and such other matters as may pertain to said wharves, piers or improvements. 
    Riprap means a layer, facing or protective mound of stones randomly placed to prevent erosion, scour or sloughing or a structure or embankment. 
    Shoreline means the mean high-water line or the waterward line of an existing bulkhead, riprap or gabion as shown on the harbor line maps. 
    Slip means any arrangement of a pier and/or one or more mooring piles and/or buoys designed and intended to be used for the wet storage of a single watercraft. 
    Storage, dry means the keeping of watercraft on the land, excluding watercraft owned by and registered to the property owner upon which the watercraft sits, and excluding watercraft awaiting repairs for a period of up to seven days and further excluding watercraft displayed as part of a watercraft sales operation. Covered storage is dry storage within a building. 
    Storage, wet means the docking, mooring, berthing or otherwise securing of watercraft to any sort of pier, wharf, dock, piling, buoy or other such facility, other than temporary berthing. Covered slips are wet storage within a building. 
    Watercraft means any boat or vessel used for either pleasure or commercial purposes in any waterway. 
    Waterway means any water area providing access from one place to another, primarily a water area providing a regular route for water traffic. 
    Yacht club means a bona fide private, nonprofit club, owned and operated by the members, providing limited marina facilities for the use of members and their guests. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(5), 8-12-85) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 19-6. - Boundaries of developable waterway area. 
    The developable waterway area is the area bounded by the shoreline, the harbor line, and the lateral lines of a waterfront lot or tract. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(6), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-7. - Harbor line location. 
    The location of the harbor lines in the waterways of the city are as shown on the maps entitled "Cambridge Harbor." 
    The harbor lines in the waterways are located at a distance from the shoreline depending on the location of the federal navigation channel and the configuration of the shoreline. 
    The location of the harbor lines in the waterways as shown on the harbor line maps are to be utilized as guidelines by the port warden in approving or disapproving applications for licenses or permits under the provisions of section 19-24 of this article, but shall not restrict the authority of the port warden to limit or prescribe, on a case by case basis, the placement, erection or construction of any structures in the waters of the city. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(7), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-8. - Lateral lines of waterfront property. 
(a)  The lateral lines for any waterfront property are to be determined, from time to time, graphically on a scaled drawing as follows: the port warden shall indicate on the harbor line maps the lateral lines extended in a perpendicular direction from the mean high-water line/property line intersection to the harbor line unless mutually agreed to otherwise by adjoining property owners and the port warden. 
(b)  Any person desiring to erect a structure in the waterways of the city must have a professional land surveyor prepare, according to the method described in this article, a plat showing the owner's property lines and lateral lines mathematically coordinated and tied into the Maryland State Plane Grid System. The lines shall be developed based on the shoreline as it exists at the time such plat is drawn. The lateral lines will be deemed to remain as shown on the plat regardless of future changes in the shoreline. 
(c)  Upon review and approval of the survey plat by the port warden, it shall be the responsibility of the applicant to have said plat recorded among the land records of the county and submit a certified copy of the document as recorded to the office of the port warden. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(8), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-9. - Determination of developable waterway area. 
    The developable waterway area shall be determined for all properties having a pair of lateral lines as shown on the harbor line maps and the applicant's drawing. For an acceptable developable waterway area, the following conditions must be met: a pair of lateral lines extended as outlined in section 19-8 to the harbor line and the mean high-water line at the shoreline define the developable waterway area for the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(9), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-10. - Waterway setbacks. 
(a)  Harbor line setbacks. Any piers, "T" heads, "L" heads, mooring piles, mooring buoys and/or anchorages must be set back from the harbor line an appropriate distance to ensure that no moored watercraft or permanent or temporary obstruction extends channelward beyond the harbor line. 
(b)  Fuel dock setback. Docks used to provide a fueling station for watercraft shall be set back a minimum distance of 50 feet from the harbor line. A clear space of 100 feet by 50 feet shall be provided for parallel berthing at "T" or "L" head fuel docks. 
(c)  Lateral line setback. No portion of the structures of a marina, yacht club and community or private pier and moorings installed in the waterways after the date of the adoption of this article shall be located less than 25 feet away from a lateral line. No watercraft shall be moored so as to cause an obstruction within 25 feet of a lateral line. A clear space of 50 feet, 25 feet on each side of a lateral line, shall be provided and mutually utilized by adjoining waterfront property owners for waterway navigation, maneuverability, and access to and from the respective developable waterfront lands and waterway areas. The lateral line setback may be reduced if a letter of no objection is obtained from the adjacent property owners and filed with the port warden of the city. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(10), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-11. - Nonconforming structures or uses. 
    Any structure of a marina, yacht club or community or private pier lawfully installed in the waterways and lawfully in use as of the date of the adoption of this article, but not in conformance with the dimensional or use regulations as prescribed in this article, may continue as a nonconforming structure and/or use, subject to the following provisions: 
(a)  Additions and enlargements. A nonconforming structure which is nonconforming as to waterway setback shall not be added to or enlarged in any manner unless such additions or enlargements thereto are made in such a manner that the resulting structure conforms to the waterway setback provisions of section 19-10. 
(b)  Restoration of damaged structures. A structure which is being used for a nonconforming use or which is a nonconforming structure and which is destroyed by fire, ice, neglect, casualty or act of God may be restored to its original configuration; provided, however, that such damage does not exceed 50 percent of the cost to replace the existing structure, at current prices. 
(c)  Discontinuation of nonconforming use. If the nonconforming use of a structure is discontinued for a continuous period of one year, it shall not be renewed, and any subsequent use of the structure shall conform to the use regulations of this article. 
(d)  Expansion or change of nonconforming use. The nonconforming use of a structure shall not be expanded, extended or changed to another nonconforming use. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(11), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-12. - Determination of legality of fixed and permanent structures installed at the time of the adoption of this article. 
    Any fixed and permanent structure existing in the waterways of the city at the time of the adoption of this article and lawfully conforming to all of the provisions of this article shall be considered as lawfully installed, unless the port warden shall decide, after notice to the property owner and a public hearing before the port warden and the planning commission in accordance with the provisions of this article, within two years of the date of the adoption of this article, that such structure or portion thereof was installed without lawful authority. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(12), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-13. - Building permit required. 
    A city building permit is required to rebuild, modify, construct or enlarge any structure intended to be permanently installed in the waterways of the city. This permit is obtained from the department of public works. An application for a building permit under either section 19-15 or section 19-16 of this article shall be filed and the permit obtained in accordance with the procedures of the department of public works before any work is initiated. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(13), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-14. - Concept and project review. 
(a)  Prior to filing an application for a building permit under the provisions of section 19-15 or 19-16 of this article, a prospective applicant may file with the port warden a sketch setting forth a concept plan of the proposed improvements. The sketch shall contain, at a minimum, an outline of the developable waterway area for the property, as well as the location and dimensions of all existing and proposed piers, mooring piles, mooring buoys and shore protection structures. 
(b)  Following submission of the sketch of a concept plan as provided by subsection (a) of this section, the chair of the port warden, or the chair's designee, shall meet with the prospective applicant, together with the planning commission, in accordance with the procedures for approval of specific development projects as set forth in section 20-15B of this Code. At these meetings, city officials shall review the project plans with the prospective applicant and provide objections or suggestions, as appropriate. Submission to the city for building permits or project plan approval shall be made only pursuant to meeting the requirements of section 20-15B. Thereafter, an application for a building permit may be filed pursuant to the provisions of sections 19-15 and 19-16 of this article. To the extent practicable, the application shall take into account any objections or suggestions provided at the project review meetings. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(14), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-15. - Application for building permit to rebuild or repair structure. 
    A person may not repair or rebuild any structure permanently installed in the waterways of the city without a permit issued by the department of public works. An application shall be submitted to the director of public works and shall be accompanied by such drawings and specifications as the director requires in order for him to determine the nature and scope of the work to be performed. If the director and the port warden determine that the structure to be repaired or rebuilt was lawfully authorized by the port warden or by section 19-11 or 19-12 of this Code and was damaged or destroyed not more than one year prior to the date of application, and that the proposed structure: 
(1)  Is substantially the same as the structure to be repaired or rebuilt; and 
(2)  Does not exceed the maximum channelward encroachment of the structure to be repaired or rebuilt; 
the director shall issue the permit; otherwise he shall submit the application to the port warden to be processed under the provisions of section 19-16 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(15), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-16. - Application for building permit to construct, modify or enlarge structure. 
    Except as provided in section 19-15 of this article, an application for a building permit to construct, modify or enlarge any structure installed or intended to be permanently installed in the waterways shall be filed with the director of public works. Upon determination by the director of public works and the city engineer that the application satisfies all applicable regulations of this article, the application, with supporting data, shall be submitted to the port warden for approval or disapproval. 
(a)  Private pier with four or less boat slips. A site plan shall be submitted with the application for a building permit for a private pier with four or less boat slips. The site plan shall include the following: 
(1)  A map at a scale of 200 feet to the inch shall be included unless specified otherwise by the city engineer. Such map will show: 
a.  All properties with riparian rights within 150 feet of the boundaries of the applicant's property, structures permanently installed in the waterways extending therefrom, and the adjacent streets. 
b.  The location and description of any existing deterrents or aids to navigation within 500 feet of the boundaries of the applicant's property. 
(2)  A detailed site plan at a scale of 50 feet to the inch shall be included unless specified otherwise by the city engineer. Such site plan will show: 
a.  Vertical control based on city datum. 
b.  Horizontal control on Maryland State Plane Coordinate System based on city control monuments. 
c.  Bathymetry of the developable waterway area shown at two-foot intervals at mean high water (unless otherwise specified by the city engineer). 
d.  Mean high-water and mean low-water lines. 
e.  Wetlands, if any. 
f.  Location and dimensions of all existing and proposed piers, mooring piles, mooring buoys, shore protection structures (including groins, jetties, riprap and bulkheads) and material for the proposed structures. 
g.  Location and dimensions of all areas to be dredged, including proposed depths (if applicable). 
h.  Volume of dredged spoil to be removed, type of material, and location and dimensions of disposal areas, including dikes (if applicable). 
(3)  Unless otherwise specified by the city engineer, each site plan submitted shall include coordinates of all property corners and breakpoints along the applicant's property line boundaries, as certified by a registered land surveyor, including but not limited to lateral line/mean high-water line/property line intersections, lateral line/harbor line intersections, and line controls for locating proposed waterway improvements. 
(b)  Piers with five or more boat slips. A site plan shall be submitted with the application for a building permit for a marina, yacht club, community pier or private pier with five or more boat slips. Unless specified otherwise by the city engineer, the site plan shall include the following: 
(1)  A map at a scale of 200 feet to the inch shall be included. Such map will show: 
a.  All properties within 500 feet of the boundaries of the applicant's property and their uses, and streets. Structures permanently installed in the waterways extending from those properties with riparian rights will also be shown. 
b.  The location and description of any existing deterrents or aids to navigation within 500 feet of the boundaries of the applicant's property. 
(2)  A detailed site plan at a scale of 50 feet to the inch shall be included. Such site plan will show: 
a.  Vertical control based on city datum. 
b.  Horizontal control on Maryland State Plane Coordinate System based on city control monuments. 
c.  Bathymetry of the developable waterway area shown at two-foot intervals at mean high-water, and topography of the property at one-foot intervals, unless otherwise specified by the city engineer. 
d.  Mean high-water and mean low-water lines. 
e.  Wetlands, if any. 
f.  Location and dimensions of all existing and proposed piers, mooring piles, mooring buoys, shore protection structures (including groins, jetties, riprap and bulkheads) and material for the proposed structures. 
g.  Location and dimensions of all boat launching ramps. 
h.  Location and capacity of all travel lifts, railways and hoists. 
i.  Location and dimensions of all areas to be dredged, including proposed depth (if applicable). 
j.  Volume of dredged spoil to be removed, type of material, and location and dimensions of disposal areas, including dikes (if applicable). 
k.  Proposed regraded surface of the land. 
l.  Location of all existing and proposed site improvements such as storm drains, culverts, retaining walls and fences. 
m.  Description, method and location of water supply and sewage disposal facilities. 
n.  Location, dimensions and proposed use of all buildings. 
o.  Location of outdoor storage, including dry boat storage. 
p.  Location and quantity of all parking spaces, location of truck loading areas, location and width of internal access and egress drives, and location and width of streets and roadways which access the property. 
q.  Location and dimensions of all outdoor maintenance and repair facilities. 
r.  Location of fuel dock and location, and capacity of fuel storage tanks. 
s.  Number and size of existing and proposed dwelling units by type (where applicable). 
t.  Total property area. 
u.  Phasing and timing of development, including dredging, waterway area structure and shoreline protection construction, clearing, grading, building construction, surfacing, planting and completion. 
(3)  Unless otherwise specified by the city engineer, each site plan submitted shall include coordinates of all property corners and breakpoints along the applicant's property line boundaries as certified by a registered land surveyor including but not limited to lateral line/mean high-water line/property line intersections, lateral line/harbor line intersections, and line controls for locating proposed waterway improvements. 
(4)  Unless otherwise specified by the city engineer, each site plan submitted shall include supporting evidence as to how and on what basis environmental requirements have been or shall be met with regard to: 
a.  Marine life. 
b.  Water quality (including but not limited to effect on dissolved oxygen, suspended solids, oil and greases, nutrients and fecal coliforms). 
c.  Wildlife. 
d.  Stormwater management, including grading and sediment control. 
e.  Conservation. 
f.  Circulation and flushing. 
g.  Aquatic vegetation. 
h.  Wetlands. 
i.  Shoreline protection and erosion control. 
j.  Types of and method of disposal of any wastes or byproducts resulting from boat building and/or the maintenance and repair of boats and/or engines. 
(5)  Unless otherwise specified by the city engineer, supporting evidence for evaluation of the environmental requirements shall include but not be limited to the following items: 
a.  The name, address and qualifications of each individual or firm involved in or consulted with regard to the environmental assessment. 
b.  A documentation of the process by which the assessment was formulated. 
c.  A description of existing environmental conditions related to the site. 
d.  A detailed list of each resource document or other resource material used to support the environmental findings, including a copy of the pertinent portions thereof where feasible, or a reference to the location where the documents or material may be reviewed. 
e.  A copy of each study containing environmental data prepared with regard to the site, whether or not the study was prepared in connection with the pending application. 
f.  Any other relevant data, documents or materials which support the environmental findings. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(16), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-17. - Construction standards. 
(a)  Building permit applications for all marina, yacht club, community pier and private pier installations with five or more boat slips shall have plans and proposed construction details prepared by a licensed engineer. 
(b)  All structures intended for installation in the waterways shall be constructed to meet at least the minimum standards as may be established by the port warden, city engineer and director of public works of the city. 
(c)  All piers shall be of the open pile design. Filled piers are not permitted. 
(d)  Piers, mooring piles, bulkheads and shoreline protection structures may not be constructed in the waterway, except as approved by the city engineer, the port warden and state and federal agencies. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(17), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-18. - Fees for building permits. 
(a)  A nonrefundable application fee for a building permit to repair, modify, enlarge or construct any fixed and permanent structure in the waterways will be paid at the time the application is filed. 
(b)  A fee for a building permit to repair, modify, enlarge or construct any fixed and permanent structure in the waterways will be paid at the time the permit is issued. 
(c)  The amount of the application and permit fees required by this section shall be established from time to time by the mayor and council, by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(18), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-19. - Mooring permit. 
    No person shall place any mooring buoys or floating wharves in the developable waterway area without first obtaining a permit for same from the department of public works. Every permit so issued shall be valid for not more than one year from date of issuance and shall expire on April 30 of each year unless renewed. An application for a mooring permit shall be filed with the city engineer. When the city engineer has determined that the application satisfies the applicable regulations of this article, he shall submit the application to the port warden for approval or disapproval. 
    A nonrefundable fee for an application for a mooring permit shall be paid at the time the application is filed. An annual fee for a mooring permit shall be paid at the time the permit is issued, and for each year thereafter for which the permit is renewed. 
    The amount of the application and permit fees for a mooring permit required by this section shall be established from time to time by the mayor and council, by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(19), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-20. - Grading permit. 
    A grading permit is required for any dredging, filling or other activity which would result in a waterway bottom or shoreline modification, except when spoil is removed by barge to a site outside of the city limits. 
    Application for this grading permit shall be filed with the city engineer. When the city engineer has determined that the application satisfies all applicable city codes, he shall submit the application, with all supporting data, to the port warden for approval or disapproval. 
    The nonrefundable fee for the application for a grading permit shall be paid at the time the application is filed. The fee for this grading permit shall be paid at the time of issuance. 
    The fees for the application and the grading permit shall be established from time to time by the mayor and council, by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(20), 8-12-85) 
Cross reference- Grading permits, § 7-5 et seq. 
Sec. 19-21. - Other permits and approvals. 
    State and federal permits and approvals required for construction, modification, enlargement, reconstruction, repair, etc., of marinas, community and private piers, mooring piles, mooring and dredging shall be obtained by the applicant and submitted to the department of public works as a prerequisite to issuance of a city building, mooring, grading or dredging permit. The applicant shall furnish to the city engineer a certified copy of the plans, with supporting data, showing approval of same by state and federal agencies. If the application approved by the port warden is subsequently modified by state or federal agencies, it shall be resubmitted to the port warden for approval prior to issuance of any city permit required by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(21), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-22. - Expiration and transfer of permits. 
    A building, mooring or grading permit issued by the department of public works shall be valid for work commenced within a period of six months after issuance of the permit; otherwise, it shall be void and of no effect. Work permitted by a building, mooring or grading permit shall be completed within 18 months of the date of issuance of the permit, unless a longer period is specified in the permit or an extension is granted by the port warden for good cause. 
    No building, mooring or grading permit issued by the department of public works shall be transferable without the concurrence of the city engineer and a request for the transfer of same submitted by the original applicant and acceptance by the transferee of the conditions under which the original permit was issued. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(22), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-23. - Removal or disconnection of unlicensed or unauthorized structures; numbering of mooring permits. 
    Any unlicensed mooring, mooring pile, floating wharf, buoy or anchored boat found within the waters of the city, or any licensed mooring found in an area not authorized by the port warden, shall be posted with a notice requiring the owner thereof to remove the same within seven days from the date of the notice. Unless removed or a permit is obtained within the time required by such notice, any such structure may be disconnected and/or removed at the option of the harbormaster of the city, and may be disposed of, at the expense of the owner. 
    Any unlicensed mooring, mooring pile, floating wharf, buoy or anchored boat found restricting or blocking navigation within the waters of the city may be removed immediately by the harbormaster of the city, at the expense of the owner. 
    Mooring permits issued by the department of public works shall be consecutively numbered, and the number on commercial permits shall bear the letter "C" as a prefix. Every mooring permit number so issued shall be clearly legible at all times and shall be placed conspicuously on the mooring, mooring pile, floating wharf, buoy or boat for which issued in numerals not less than two inches tall, and every such commercial permit so issued shall also bear the letter "C" at least two inches tall. 
    Violation of any of the provisions of this section shall, in addition to any other remedy available to the city, be a municipal infraction. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(23), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-24. - Port warden-Generally. 
    The warden of the port of the city shall be appointed by the mayor subject to confirmation by the city council. 
    The port warden shall regulate the placement, erection or construction of structures or other barriers within or on the waters of the city. The port warden shall regulate the materials and construction and make certain that such placement, erection or construction in the waters of the city does not render the navigation too close and confined. The port warden shall not approve any application for a license or permit involving placement, erection or construction in the waters of the city beyond the harbor lines, either fixed or provisional, as shown on the harbor line maps, but shall have the authority to approve or disapprove any such application within the developable waterway areas as defined in this article, in accordance with the criteria of this section and the provisions of sections 3-48 and 3-50A of the charter of the city. The location of the harbor lines in the waterways, as shown on the harbor line maps, are to be utilized by the port warden as guidelines and to define the maximum channelward limits of construction. 
    The port warden shall approve or disapprove applications for licenses or permits to construct, enlarge, rebuild or modify any and all marinas, community or private piers, wharves, mooring piles, floating wharves, buoys, anchors and bulkheads, including any dredging and modification of the natural shoreline. 
    The port warden will consider, in accordance with subsection 19-16(b), the effect of present and proposed uses on marine life, wildlife, conservation, water pollution and erosion, navigational hazards, the effect of the proposed use on congestion within the waters, the effect on other riparian property owners, and the present and projected needs for any proposed commercial or industrial use. 
    No person may build any wharf or pier or carry out any earth or other material for the purpose of building a wharf or pier, nor shall any person place or erect mooring piles, floating wharves, buoys or anchors without approval of the port warden and the city council. If any person violates these provisions, or erects any structure regulated by this article in a different form or of different materials than determined and allowed by the port warden and the city council, he is in violation of applicable provisions of this article and subject to the penalties for such violations. Any violation of this section is a municipal infraction. All decisions of the port warden and the city council will be filed with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(24), 8-12-85) 
Charter reference- Harbor, § 3-48; port warden § 3-50A. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 19-25. - Same-Review of development projects. 
    Whenever an application is submitted by the director of public works or city engineer to the port warden of the city, the port warden shall initiate the review process for approval or disapproval of the specific development project in accordance with the provisions set forth in sections 20-15B, 20-21, 20-22 and 20-23 of this Code, unless otherwise modified in this article. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(25), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-26. - Restricted mooring and anchoring areas. 
    The port warden will designate restricted areas within the waterways of the city where mooring and anchoring will not be permitted. Such areas will be so designated for reasons of public and navigational safety. Such areas will include those in the vicinity of fueling docks, cable crossings, the entrance to the city dock, a holding area for boats awaiting the Maryland Avenue Bridge opening, and such other areas where congestion can become a safety and navigational hazard. The port warden may also designate areas in the waterways where anchoring is restricted to specified periods of time or purposes. 
    The restricted area designated by the port warden will be posted in the water. The harbor master will enforce compliance with this section. Violation is a municipal infraction. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(26), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-27. - Public moorings. 
    The port warden shall designate areas within the waterways of the city where public mooring buoys shall be placed by the department of public works. These public mooring buoys shall be made available to the public upon payment in advance of a mooring rental fee. The amount of the fee shall be determined from time to time by the mayor and council by resolution. The mooring shall be of two types, longterm (one month or more) and transient (less than one month). 
    The harbor master shall receive applications and fees for the rental of these public mooring buoys. Use of these public mooring buoys without payment of the prescribed fee is a municipal infraction. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(27), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-28. - Number of watercraft at moorings and floating wharves. 
    No more than one watercraft shall be moored at any one mooring pile or buoy. The number of watercraft permitted at a floating wharf shall be at the discretion of the port warden, except that a rowboat, dinghy or yacht tender regularly used by a larger watercraft for transportation of persons or property to and from shore may be secured to such watercraft or to the mooring regularly used by such larger watercraft. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(28), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-29. - Mooring at city property. 
    Any person who moors or ties his watercraft to any portion of the city dock or other property belonging to the city designated for mooring, or rafts to another watercraft or watercraft moored or tied to any bulkhead in the inner harbor of the city dock area, shall first obtain permission of the owner of the other watercraft and then obtain the permission of the harbor master for such mooring privileges. The applicant will pay such fees to the harbor master for mooring privileges as may be specified from time to time by the mayor and council by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(29), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-30. - Navigational safety. 
(A)  Hazardous obstructions. An obstruction which presents a hazard to any watercraft or person may not remain in the waterways of the city. 
(B)  Prohibited acts; remedies. 
(1)  A watercraft: 
(a)  May not be anchored in the waterways of the city where prohibited or restricted by the port warden, except in an emergency. 
(b)  May not lie at anchor or be moored in the waterways of the city in a position to obstruct navigation. 
(c)  May not be tied or moored to any public dock, wharf or bulkhead without the permission of the harbor master, unless the watercraft is loading or discharging its load. 
(d)  Which is either not in a condition to keep afloat or is sunk may not remain in the waterways of the city. 
(2)  Any person who permits any activity prohibited by subsection (B)(1) of this section is guilty of a municipal infraction. 
(3)  Removal of vessel. 
(a)  Upon discovering a watercraft in violation of subsection (B)(1) of this section, the harbor master shall request the owner or master of the watercraft to remove the vessel if the owner or master is aboard the vessel or if the harbor master finds the owner or master in the immediate vicinity of the vessel. If the request is refused or if the owner or master is not found in the immediate vicinity of the vessel, the harbor master may have the watercraft removed to a boat storage facility and placed in storage, and the harbor master shall then attempt to notify the owner of the boat as to the storage location. The watercraft may not be released without an order for its release signed by the director of public works. 
(b)  The owner of the watercraft shall be responsible for all costs and expenses associated with the towing and storage of the vessel. All such costs and expenses shall constitute a lien upon the watercraft and shall be paid before an order for the release of the vessel may be issued. 
(C)  Excessive wake and speed. A person may not propel or navigate any motor-driven watercraft in any of the waters of the city, except the Choptank River, at a speed greater than six miles per hour, nor create a wash which endangers persons or property. Violation of this subsection is a municipal infraction. 
(D)  Condition of watercraft docked in city harbor. A person may not dock a watercraft which is not in an operating condition in the city harbor, nor may major repairs be made to watercraft in the dock area. Violation of this subsection is a municipal infraction. 
(E)  Cooking equipment on watercraft at city dock. A person may not cook by means of charcoal burning on his watercraft in the city dock. A person may not use or operate any type of outdoor cooking equipment on city dock property without consent of the mayor and council. Violation of this subsection is a municipal infraction. 
(F)  Swimming and waterskiing prohibited at city dock. A person may not swim or water ski in the city dock waters. Violation of this subsection is a municipal infraction. 
(G)  Fueling watercraft at city dock. A person may not fuel watercraft at the city dock. Violation of this subsection is a municipal infraction. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(30), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-31. - Boarding or tampering with watercraft. 
(a)  No unauthorized person shall climb into or upon any watercraft moored, docked or anchored within the waters of the city without the consent of the owner or other person having charge thereof. Violation of this subsection is a municipal infraction. 
(b)  No person shall willfully injure or tamper with or break or remove any part of or from any watercraft within the waters of the city, or tamper with the lines securing such watercraft, without the consent of the owner or other person having charge thereof. Violation of this subsection is a municipal infraction. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(31), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-32. - Sanitary facilities for marinas. 
    All marinas renting berthing slips shall provide sanitary facilities in accordance with the applicable federal and state requirements and the following city requirements: 
(a)  Not less than one toilet and not less than one lavatory available on a 24-hour basis shall be provided for each sex by each owner or operator of a marina within the city. Additional such facilities above this minimum shall be provided as appropriate by each such owner or operator. 
(b)  Such sanitary facilities shall be located ashore not more than 200 feet from the closest access point on shore to each pier, arrangement of piles, mooring or other such facility. The sanitary facility shall be connected into the city sanitary sewer system, and shall have hot and cold running water. 
(c)  Owners and operators of each such marina facility shall prominently label such facilities and shall erect prominent notices at the shore and water ends of all piers and docks notifying the tenants and users thereof of the location of such sanitary facilities. 
(d)  Sanitary facilities required for tenants, guests and users of such slips, docks, arrangements of piles, moorings or other such facilities shall be in addition to those required for other uses. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(32), 8-12-85) 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, ch. 8; plumbing and sewers, ch. 14. 
Sec. 19-33. - Watercraft toilets. 
    No person shall operate the toilet fixtures of a watercraft within the waterways of the city at any time so as to cause or permit to pass or to be discharged into the waters of the city any sewage or other waste matter or contaminant of any kind which does not meet the state, county and federal requirements for water quality. Violation of this section is a municipal infraction. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(33), 8-12-85) 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, ch. 8; plumbing and sewers, ch. 14. 
Sec. 19-34. - Leaving property on public wharf. 
    No person shall leave any property on any public wharf, or public property adjacent thereto, for a period of more than 24 hours. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(34), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-35. - Discharge of refuse or other materials into city waters. 
    No person shall discharge or permit or allow any other person on a watercraft under his control or command to discharge any human or animal excreta or other refuse from any head, toilet or similar facility on a watercraft into the waters within the city. No person shall throw, discharge, deposit or leave, or cause, suffer or permit to be thrown, discharged, deposited or left, either from the shore or from any pier or watercraft, oil, fuel, toxic materials or any refuse matter of any description into the waters within the city, or on the shore thereof, where the same may be washed into the harbor or waters either by tides or by floods or otherwise. Violation of this section is a municipal infraction. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(35), 8-12-85) 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, ch. 8; dumping of refuse, § 12-15; plumbing and sewers, ch. 14. 
State Law reference- Throwing or dumping refuse in water, Ann. Code of Md. art. Natural Resources, § 8-726. 
Sec. 19-36. - Retail sale of seafood from watercraft at city dock. 
    No watercraft shall be permitted to lie at any of the city docks or wharves for the purpose of selling fish or other seafood at retail without consent of the mayor and council. Violation of this section is a municipal infraction. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(36), 8-12-85) 
Sec. 19-37. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
    Any person, firm, corporation or other entity, or any agent of such, who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a municipal infraction as defined by section 1-9 of this Code and shall be subject to a fine of $50.00 for any single, initial such violation and a fine of $100.00 for each repeat or continuing violation, and each day the violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 696, § 1(37), 8-12-85; Ord. No 741, § 1, 9-12-88) 
Charter reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, § 3-83. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, Ann. Code of Md. art. 23A, § 3. 
Chapter 20 - ZONING[1]

Charter reference- Powers of city with regard to planning and zoning, § 3-27(58). 
Cross reference- Planning and zoning commission, §§ 2-3, 2-4; architectural board of review, § 2-13; commercial district management authority, § 2-15; kennels, § 3-5; buildings and housing, ch. 4; grading, erosion and sediment control, ch. 7; trailers, § 8-12 et seq.; junkyards, § 10-4; signs overhanging sidewalk, § 16-15; subdivisions, ch. 17; design and development standards of lots, § 17-17; harbors, docks, waterways and waterfront areas, § 19-1 et seq.

Sec. 20-1. - Zoning ordinance. 
    By ordinance adopted May 12, 2003, the Commissioners of Cambridge adopted a comprehensive revision to its zoning ordinance, which zoning ordinance is codified separately from the city's code of laws. Said zoning ordinance dated May 12, 2003, is hereby incorporated herein by reference, and shall constitute the Zoning Code for the City of Cambridge. 
(Ord. No. 928, 12-13-04)

Article 1
General Provisions
§ 1.1 Title
§ 1.2 Authority
§ 1.3 Jurisdiction
§ 1.4 Purpose
§ 1.5 Severability
§ 1.1 Title
These regulations shall be known as the City of Cambridge Unified Development
Code. They may be referred to herein as this Ordinance.
§ 1.2 Authority
The Mayor and City Commissioners have the authority to adopt this Ordinance
pursuant to the Land Use Article of the Annotated Code of Maryland, as amended.
§ 1.3 Jurisdiction
This Ordinance shall apply to all lands, structures, and buildings within the
corporate limits of Cambridge, including all submerged lands and water areas.
§ 1.4 Purpose
§ 1.4.1 General Purpose
The purpose of this Ordinance is to protect and promote the public health, safety
and general welfare of the City of Cambridge, the orderly development of lands, and
protection of natural resources and the environment. It is a comprehensive and
unified set of regulations that govern the subdivision, development, and use of land.
§ 1.4.2 Specific Purposes
This Ordinance is adopted for the following particular purposes:
? Implement the Cambridge Comprehensive Plan. To implement the goals,
policies, and provisions of the adopted Comprehensive Plan and its subsequent
updates and amendments.
5
? Protect and support the physical integrity of the Citys built environment and
historic areas. To promote the development of vacant lots, to revitalize
neighborhoods, promote the prosperity of downtown Cambridge, to encourage
good civic design, and use of building patterns and practices that reinforce
traditional patterns of building within the City.
? Provide a regulatory approach that facilitates real estate investment and
enhances property values especially in the downtown area and its surrounding
neighborhoods. To provide regulatory mechanisms that include appropriate and
clear standards for new development, streamlined procedures for development
approvals, and rules for oversight, inspection, and conformance with approved
plans.
? Promote efficient land use and infrastructure. To promote the efficient use of
land, the orderly and efficient development of essential public facilities and
services including bicycle facilities, and land use and construction practices that
align with historic, ongoing, and planned public investments in infrastructure.
? Promote sound and sustainable development practices. To promote
development practices which conserve and restore water, energy and other
resources, prevent damage to natural resources and protect people, property,
and public infrastructure from environmental hazard including flooding and
coastal inundation impacts related to rising sea levels, and discourage land
consumptive, low density, and single-use development patterns which run
counter to traditional building practices in the City.
? Encourage mixed-use development and interconnectivity. To encourage multiple
uses of land within close proximity of each other and interconnectivity between
properties and within developments.
? Encourage the creation of a greenbelt around the City of preserved natural and
open spaces that are shown in the adopted Comprehensive Plan as providing a
perpetual recreational and natural resource for future generations.
§ 1.5 Severability
The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses, and phrases of this Ordinance are
severable. If any court of competent jurisdiction declares any such part
unconstitutional or otherwise invalid in a valid judgment or decree, such
unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining parts of this
Ordinance.
6
Article 2
Administration and Enforcement
§ 2.1 Roles of Official Bodies
§ 2.2 General Permit and Application Procedures
§ 2.3 Hearings of the Board of Appeals
§ 2.4 Nonconforming Lots, Structures, and Uses
§ 2.5 Enforcement of this Ordinance
§ 2.1 Roles of Official Bodies
§ 2.1.1 Zoning Official
A. Establishment
It shall be the duty of the Zoning Official to administer, interpret, and enforce this
Ordinance and to take all actions that are required by this Ordinance.
B. Enforcement
If the Zoning Official finds that this Ordinance is being violated, he/she shall notify
in writing the person responsible for such violations, indicate the nature of the
violation and order action necessary to correct it. The Zoning Official shall:
1. Order discontinuance of the illegal use of land, buildings, or structures;
2. Order removal of illegal buildings or structures or of additions, alterations, or
structural changes thereto;
3. Order discontinuance of any illegal work being done; or
4. Take any other action authorized to ensure compliance or to prevent
violation.
C. Issuance of Permits
The Zoning Official shall issue permits for the erection, construction, addition,
demolition, and moving or structural alteration of buildings and structures and for
the use of land.
1. No building or other structure shall be erected, moved, added to, or
structurally altered, or use of land changed without a permit authorizing
such work.
2. No permit shall be issued except in conformity with this Ordinance.
D. Notice to Critical Area Commission
7
When the City receives an application for any development, subdivision, site plan,
rezoning, special exception, variance, or timber harvesting pertaining to land in the
Critical Area, the Zoning Official shall send notification thereof and a copy of the
application to the Critical Area Commission except in the following circumstances:
1. The proposed structure is 250 square feet in size or less.
2. The proposed structure is a single-family house.
E. Appeals
Any person or agency aggrieved or affected by a decision of the Zoning Official may
appeal such decision to the Board of Appeals per § 2.2.6 of this Ordinance.
F. Discharge of Duties
In the discharge of his/her duties, the Zoning Official shall have the authority to
enter at any reasonable hour, any building, structure, or premise in the City to
enforce the provisions of this Ordinance. The assistance and cooperation of
sheriffs and/or police, fire, and health departments and all other City officials shall
be available to the Zoning Official as required in the performance of his/her
duties.
§ 2.1.2 Planning Commission
A. Establishment
The Planning Commission shall have the authority to:
1. Prepare and recommend a Comprehensive Plan for the City of Cambridge
and review and update that plan at least once every six (6) years;
2. Advise the City Council on all matters relating to the orderly planning and
growth of the City;
3. Prepare and recommend amendments to this Ordinance, including the
Official Zoning Map;
4. Review and make recommendations to the Board of Appeals on special
exceptions based on findings of fact;
5. Annually review and make a recommendation on the Citys Capital
Improvements Plan (CIP) prior to City adoption of the CIP and review all
proposed public facilities for consistency with the Comprehensive Plan;
6. Review and decide on Category 1 Site Plans as provided for in § 3.1 of this
Ordinance;
7. Review and decide on requests for certain modifications to site plan
requirements as authorized by § 3.1 including parking, landscaping, and
building design modification;
8. Review and decide on subdivision plats;
9. Prepare, adopt, and distribute to the public an annual report; and
8
10. Conduct other activities and duties as set forth in this Ordinance, as
requested by the City Council, or as provided for by the Land Use Article of
the Maryland Annotated Code.
11. Planning Commission members may be compensated at the discretion of the
City Council.
B. Membership
1. The Planning Commission shall consist of seven members, and one ex officio
member, appointed in the following fashion:
a. The City Council shall appoint five members. Each City Council shall
have the right to nominate one person from the ward of his/her
residence, subject to the approval of the majority of the City Council.
b. The Mayor shall appoint one member subject to the confirmation of the
majority of the City Council.
c. The City Council shall have the right to appoint one member upon the
nomination by the Dorchester County Planning Commission of a
person from among its membership who shall serve concurrently on
both the City and County Planning Commissions and whose
appointment is subject to approval of the majority of the City Council.
In the event that this provision does not result in the appointment
of a person serving on the County Planning Commission, the Mayor
shall nominate a person to fill this seat, subject to the approval of the
majority of the City Council.
d. The City Council shall appoint one of its members, ex officio.
2. Members shall be appointed to five-year terms and terms of appointment
shall be staggered except for the members appointed per paragraphs c and
d above.
3. Vacancy in membership for an unexpired term shall be filled for the
unexpired term by appointment by the City Council. The City Council shall
consider a recommendation from the Planning Commission if one is
provided.
C. Officers
1. The Commission shall elect from its membership a Chairperson and Vice-
Chairperson, annually by the 31st day of January.
2. The terms of the officers shall be one year, with eligibility for reelection.
3. If the Planning Commission fails to elect a Chairperson per this section, the
City Council may appoint a Chairperson.
D. Proceedings of the Planning Commission
1. The Planning Commission shall adopt written rules necessary to the conduct
of its affairs.
9
2. The Planning Commission shall establish a regular meeting schedule and
shall meet frequently enough so that it can take action on all complete
applications in an expeditious manner. The Planning Commission shall hold
meetings quarterly or more often, as the Planning Commissions duties
require. If there is no business before the Planning Commission, the
Chairperson may cancel the meeting. The Planning Commission shall hold
regular meetings at a regular schedule to conduct the business to be brought
before it and shall at least meet every three months or four times per year.
3. The Chairperson may call special meetings of the Commission.
4. All meetings shall be open to the public.
5. The Planning Commission shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the
vote of each member upon each question, or if absent or failing to vote
indicating such fact, and shall keep records of its examinations and other
official actions, all of which shall be a public record.
6. Four members of the Commission shall constitute a quorum and no action of
the Commission shall be valid unless authorized by a majority vote of those
present and voting.
7. The Chairperson and Vice-Chairperson may take part in all deliberations and
vote on all issues.
8. All decisions of the Planning Commission, whether favorable or unfavorable
to the applicant, shall be based on and supported by written findings of fact
pertaining to the case under review. No decision of the Planning Commission
shall be final until the written decision of the Commission is signed and filed.
E. Modifying the Provisions of this Ordinance
The Planning Commission may, upon the review of a site plan, but only where and as
so provided in this Ordinance, modify certain provisions upon its finding that such
modification is the minimum necessary to faithfully implement the purposes of this
Ordinance and implement the adopted Comprehensive Plan. This authority is
distinctly different from the authority to grant a variance as provided in § 2.2.5,
which authority rests solely with the Board of Appeals.
F. Appeals
Any person aggrieved by a decision of the Planning Commission and desiring to
appeal such decision may file a petition for review through the Board of Zoning
Appeals.
§ 2.1.3 Board of Appeals
A. Establishment
The Board of Appeals shall have the authority to:
1. Hear and decide appeals from any order, requirement, decision, action, or
determination made by the Planning Commission and the Zoning Official. The
Board may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the order,
10
requirement, decision or determination as ought to be made, and to that end
shall have powers of the Planning Commission and the Zoning Official from
whom the appeal is taken. The Board of Appeals is only authorized to hear
and decide on appeals of the Planning Commission, the Zoning Official and
Historic Preservation Commission.
2. Hear and decide Special Exceptions, provided that Planning Commission has
had the opportunity to review and offer a recommendation to the Board, as
authorized under § 2.2.7 of this Ordinance.
3. Authorize a variance from the terms of the Ordinance as provided for in §
2.2.5 of this Ordinance.
4. Decide matters of interpretation of zoning district boundaries as provided in
§ 4.1.1(C)(6) of this Ordinance.
B. Membership
1. The Board shall consist of five members. The Mayor shall appoint the
members subject to confirmation by the City Council.
2. Members shall be appointed to three-year terms and terms of appointment
shall be staggered. Vacancies shall be filled by appointment for the unexpired
term.
3. The Mayor shall appoint one alternate member for the Board of Appeals who
may be empowered to sit with the Board in the absence of any member.
4. Board members may be compensated at the discretion of the City Council.
C. Officers
1. The Board shall elect from its membership a Chairperson and Vice-
Chairperson, annually by the 31st day of January.
2. The terms of the officers shall be one year, with eligibility for reelection.
3. If the Board fails to elect a Chairperson per this section, the City Council shall
appoint a Chairperson.
D. Proceedings of the Board of Appeals
1. The Board shall adopt rules necessary to the conduct of its affairs.
2. Meetings shall be held at the call of the Chairperson. The Chairperson, or in
his/her absence, the Acting Chairperson, may administer oaths and compel
the attendance of witnesses.
3. All meetings and hearings shall be open to the public.
4. The Board shall conduct its hearings according to the procedures set forth in
§ 2.3.
5. The Board shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of each
member upon each question, or if absent or failing to vote indicating such
fact, and shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions, all
of which shall be a public record.
11
6. Three members shall constitute a quorum and no action of the Commission
shall be valid unless authorized by a majority vote of those present and
voting.
7. The Chairperson and Vice-Chairperson may take part in all deliberations and
vote on all issues.
8. Decisions Based on Findings of Fact. All decisions of the Board, whether
favorable or unfavorable to the applicant, shall be based on and supported by
written findings of fact pertaining to the case under review. No decision of
the Board shall be final until the written decision of the Board is signed and
filed.
E. Special Procedural Provisions
1. The concurring vote of the majority of the members of the Board shall be
necessary to reverse any order, requirement, decision, or determination of
the Zoning Official, or to decide in favor of the applicant on any matter upon
which it is required to pass under this Ordinance, or to effect any variation in
the application of this Ordinance.
2. If any application or request is disapproved by the Board, thereafter the
Board shall not accept application for substantially the same proposal on the
same property for a period of one year from the date of such disapproval.
3. If an appeal to the Board is filed and the public hearing date set and public
notice given, and thereafter the applicant withdraws the appeal, the
applicant shall not file another application for substantially the same
proposal on the same property for a period of one year from the date of
withdrawal.
F. Appeals
Any person aggrieved by a decision of the Board of Appeals and desiring to appeal
such decision may file a petition for judicial review through the Circuit Court of
Dorchester County.
§ 2.1.4 Historic Preservation Commission (HPC)
A. Establishment
The Historic Preservation Commission shall have the authority to:
1. Hear applications for development activities concerning a designated
landmark, site, or structure, or site or structure within a designated historic
district.
2. Review all proposed National Register nominations for properties within the
boundaries of the local government. Public notice of the date, time and place
of the HPCs review of a National Register nomination, including an agenda of
the items to be considered, will be publicly advertised or posted in
accordance with established rules of procedures as adopted by the City
Commission.
12
3. Accept and use gifts in the performance of its functions, consistent with
adopted City policies and procedures.
4. Accept or otherwise acquire historic preservation easements on designated
landmarks, structures, or sites and when deemed appropriate by the
Commission, sites or structures located in, or adjacent to, a designated
district, consistent with the Citys charter, ordinances, resolutions, policies,
and procedures governing acquisitions of easements.
5. Direct studies, reports and surveys to identify historical, archeological, or
architecturally significant sites, structures, and districts that exemplify the
cultural, social, economic, political, or architectural history of the City of
Cambridge, the State of Maryland, or the United States of America.
6. Recommend to the Mayor and City Council any area within the limits of
Cambridge for designation as a landmark, site, structure or district and the
boundaries thereof.
7. Recommend to the Mayor and City Council for approval, guidelines for
rehabilitation and new construction and criteria for construction, alteration,
reconstruction, moving, and demolition of designated landmarks, sites,
structures, and districts which are consistent with the United States
Secretary of Interiors Standards for the Treatment of Historic Properties (36
CFR Part 68). Guidelines may include design characteristics intended to meet
the needs of types of sites, structures, and districts, and may identify
categories of changes that, because they are so minimal in nature, they do not
affect historic, archeological, or architectural significance and do not require
review by the Commission. These guidelines shall be made available to the
public in an HPC Guidelines document and posted to the Citys website. They
shall be used by an applicant in applying for a Certificate of Appropriateness
and by the HPC in the review of applications.
8. Take actions set forth in § 4.5.6 in cases where demolition by neglect is
determined to exist with respect to a designated property or property in a
designated district.
9. To undertake any other action or activity necessary or appropriate to the
implementation of its powers and duties or the implementation of the
purpose of this article.
B. Membership
1. The HPC shall consist of five standing members and one alternate member
appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by City Council. A majority of the
members of the HPC shall be residents of the City, with at least one member
being a resident of a Cambridge historic district. Nonresident appointees
must possess professional or academic qualifications as defined by the HPCs
By-Laws or Rules of Procedures. Each member including the alternate
member shall possess a demonstrated special interest, specific knowledge, or
professional or academic training in such fields as history, architecture,
architectural history, planning, archaeology, anthropology, curation,
conservation, landscape architecture, historic preservation, urban design, or
13
related disciplines. Attention shall be given to the required expertise needed
to retain the Certified Local Government state designation when appointing
new members to the HPC.
2. Members are appointed for staggered terms of three years, commencing
Sept. 1st of a calendar year, so that no more than three appointments shall
expire in a given year. HPC members are eligible for reappointment. The
Mayor and City Council shall fill any vacancy on the HPC for the unexpired
term. Any vacancy of the HPC shall be filled by the appointing authority
within 60 days. In the case of expired terms, members may continue to serve
until the successors are appointed and confirmed. The alternate member
may be appointed to fill an unexpired term.
3. Removal for Cause. After a hearing, a member may be removed from the HPC
if such hearing is requested in writing by the member, by the City
Commissioners or the Mayor with the consent and prior approval of the City
Commissioners. In each case, the cause for removal shall be stated in writing.
4. HPC members may be compensated at the discretion of the City Council.
C. Officers
1. The HPC shall elect, from its membership, a Chairperson and Vice-
Chairperson annually by the 31st day of January. The terms of the
Chairperson and Vice-Chairperson shall be for one year, with eligibility for
reelection. In the absence of the Chair or Vice-Chair, the majority present
shall elect a commission member to serve as acting chair for the duration of
the meeting.
D. Proceedings of the Historic Preservation Commission
1. The HPC shall adopt rules of procedure to conduct its affairs in keeping with
the provisions of this Ordinance and these rules will be made available to the
public.
2. All meetings of the HPC shall be publicly announced and be open to the
public. The agenda shall be publicly advertised before any scheduled
meeting. The HPC will hold meetings at regular intervals at least four times a
year. Public notice must be provided prior to any special meetings.
3. An interested person or their representative may appear and be heard at a
public hearing or public meeting.
4. The HPC shall keep a public record of its resolutions, proceedings, and
actions that shall be kept available for public inspection during normal
business hours. Minutes of all decisions and actions of the commission,
including the reasons for making these decisions, must be kept on file and be
available for public inspection. Recorded transcripts will be made available
to the public upon request.
5. Three members shall constitute a quorum and no action of the Commission
shall be valid unless authorized by a majority vote of those present and
voting.
14
E. Decisions Based on Findings of Fact
All decisions of the HPC, whether favorable or unfavorable to the applicant, shall be
based on and supported by findings of fact pertaining to the case under review. In
cases of approval or disapproval over public opposition, or in case of dissent among
Commission members or at the Chairs discretion, the Chair will designate a
member of the majority to write an opinion regarding the decision. Any member
may write a concurring or dissenting opinion. All opinions shall be based on the
public record and all written opinions shall be made part of the record.
F. Appeals
Any person aggrieved by a decision of the Historic Preservation Commission has the
right of appeal therefrom to the Board of Zoning Appeals, which will review the
Commissions decision based on the record of the proceedings before the Historic
Preservation Commission.
§ 2.1.5 Mayor and City Council
